debate.para: The Clerk—I inform the House of the absence of the Speaker, who is attending a Centenary of Federation ceremony. The Speaker will be in attendance later this day. In accordance with standing order 14, the Deputy Speaker, as Acting Speaker, will take the chair.

talk.start.para: thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —It is timely that the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000 comes before parliament, as it is directly related to recent revelations of breaches of the public confidence and the public interest for which this government is squarely responsible. I refer to the recent breaches in public confidence, including the former Senator Colston affair, the radiologists MRI scan scam and the Reith telecard affair. These three breaches have greatly angered the people of Australia. It is not the seriousness of the offences alone that has angered the Australian community but the lengths gone to to hide those breaches from the public. Thank God for the watchdog—the media.

speech.para: The moral reasoning behind the introduction of this legislation is that Australia is a signatory to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the ICCPR. Australia's first attempt to comply with its obligations under this bill resulted in the ill-fated Australia Card in the 1980s. The Australia Card failed to be introduced because it was seen as an intrusion into privacy. However, the residual part of the privacy package survived and became known as the Privacy Act 1988, which we have today. The provisions of that act essentially regulate the management of private information in the hands of Commonwealth government agencies. From the outset then, the original purpose of the Privacy Act was compromised. Whilst it afforded more rights in the hands of individuals, it did not and does not make provision for powers to preserve the public interest.

What is the purpose of today's bill? The purpose is to protect individual rights against advances in technology, principally information technology, which may collect, disseminate and analyse information about a person and hence constitute intelligence against that person. This bill seeks to fulfil its obligations under the ICCPR by making provisions that cover the collection, dissemination and analysis of privately held as well as publicly held data.

What moral goods are in issue here and do these moral goods conflict with other goods? There are two positive goods in question: first, an individual's right to privacy and, second, the necessity for Australia to fulfil its moral and legal obligations. Competing against these goods is something I have already mentioned: the public interest. I do not for one moment suggest that the Australia Card was the proper way to provide for the preservation of the public interest. However, I note that in the existing Privacy Act there is precious little public policy rationale that balances the two goods of the individual's interests and our obligations under an international instrument as against the good of preserving the public interest.

I have referred to gap analysis in this house on a previous occasion. Gap analysis is looking at changes to the legislative scheme that exists before an amendment is made, then looking at the scheme after the amendment is made. In this case, the pre-existing law on privacy was a weighted scheme of mutual obligations between citizen and state. Bills Digest 193 of 1999-2000 cites the two rationales for this bill: a positive reason for this bill being analogous to a `human rights' argument, and, secondly, a so-called `pragmatic' argument of financial and trade implications that would affect Australia if we did not become signatories to this bill.

These two arguments truly sum up the liberalism that is the hallmark of this government's attitude to practically every bill it has raised during the last two terms of Commonwealth government. This government first looks to the line of least resistance—that is, the line of law-making that reaches the least amount of resistance from a public morality perspective. This is so even if the law itself would trammel fundamentally matters of grave importance in the public interest. I will in a moment demonstrate the logical consequences of this government's reasoning. With the benefit of the Colston example, which is in all the newspapers this morning, I will show how the existing privacy legislation works—or should I say does not work—in light of this government's misguided policies. For now, it is only necessary for me to say that the rationale for this bill is neither a human rights argument nor a pragmatic one about financial repercussions against Australia if we do not bend to the letter of the backdoor legislation called external affairs powers through the use of international instruments to make laws without the mandate of the public.

What is the intention of the Bills Digest in drawing our attention to privacy being increasingly considered a human right? It is clear from the Bills Digest summary that privacy, like other post-industrial phenomena under the banner of human rights, includes a growing number of so-called rights which in effect deny the good operation of government. Prior to this post-industrial liberalism contaminating our legislative scheme, the duty relationship of the state was as mediate right holder over the citizen. This relationship was based on the intrinsic dignity of the individual, rather than the present case that some international instrument says privacy is a right. Who says privacy is a human right? The answer given by the government is that an OECD instrument says it is. What sort of answer is that? Are our rights as individuals to be determined by the OECD? Or are our rights to be determined by something higher than what is effectively an international trade lobby? It is no less true that a human being's dignity must be preserved by virtue of the disclosive truth that `man is made in God's image'. However, this disclosive truth has been sidelined by this new, false god called the categorical imperative of the international instrument; that is, because the OECD says it is true, therefore it must be true. How false this new god is. Why should this parliament serve it? We must not.

The practical distinction between the human dignity model of moral law and the law afforded by the ratification of international instruments such as the IPP is that the international instrument is imbalanced. In the human dignity model, a system of mutual obligation exists—that is, an individual's immediate rights are measured in proportion to the powers obtained by the state and vice versa. This bill and the Privacy Act are imbalanced in favour of the private person, including corporations. So, too, is the issue of the so-called pragmatic reasoning for today's bill—that is, the bill is moved so as to ensure that pragmatic economic and trade pressures require the safe collection, storage and security of personal information for trade to be preserved. It is this so-called pragmatic argument with which I am particularly concerned. This argument is again making a priority of what is called pragmatism to justify this bill being passed.
There is a point at issue which is most sinister in this bill. I mentioned earlier that the bill is drafted so as to more fully comply with the ICCPR. In addition, Bills Digest No. 193 notes:

quote.para: ... the Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) are based on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines of 1980 on the protection of privacy, to which Australia is (also) a signatory.

speech.para: In a previous speech in this House I made a statement on the encroachment of globalisation. In that speech, I referred to the abortive effort of this government to fulfil its obligations to ratify domestic legislation in compliance with another international instrument to which Australia is a party—the Multilateral Agreement on Investment. In the MAI, an explicit attempt was made by this government to introduce legislation that would make it an offence to have legislation which hindered the free flow of capital.

It is interesting to note that both the IPPs and the MAI are OECD instruments. It is the OECD that is behind the policy rationales this government is pursuing with such vigour. Both the IPP and the MAI are built on an ethical foundation that private interest is paramount over public interest. Both seek to create a world where the government of the day must adhere to the private interest. In both instruments, the private interest is paramount. This line of reasoning appeals to notions of liberalism. Liberalism, especially of this present government, appeals to some people's senses. Some people think: `A thing is good to me, therefore it is good.' This line of thinking reduces everything to a `right'—`It is my right to do this or that.' Rights based legislation is defective, for it denies any meaningful analysis of means or end and, therefore, law based on the morality of obtaining means. The government is building a legislative scheme on rights alone. This government is denying the possibility of categorical imperatives that are immutable duty relationships between the citizen and the state. There are ontological truths based on the philosophy of mutual obligation. Citizens are duty bound to their country. We all abide by social contracts that we will prescribe to behave according to a minimum socially accepted code of conduct. This is the criminal code. By denying the ability to prosecute on behalf of the public interest, this government is denying the operation of the public interest. This government is saying that it is simply too hard to implement the public interest; so, in effect, this government is abandoning the public interest.

What is necessary for the good operation of government? It is necessary for all law to be balanced. On the one hand, it is never permissible for a public or national interest to override a person's dignity—that is dictatorship. Nor is governance of a country capable of cohesion if an individual's so-called rights are so great as to dash the prosecution of the state in enforcing the public interest. True, this balancing of competing public and private interests is a delicate balancing act, and often one side of the scale will tip to the detriment of the other. Indeed, it is always a series of perpetual adjustments with the development of extrinsic variables such as technology—the catalyst mentioned here today and the reason behind this bill.

I put to this House that the scales of the current legislative scheme in the Privacy Act and ancillary legislation are tipped against the public interest and in favour of the private interest. I say this specifically with many public interest issues in mind such as the travel rorts scandal of former Senator Mal Colston, the Reith $50,000 telecard affair and the billion dollar radiologists MRI scan scam.

What is the relevance of these three scandals to the bill before us today? I turn to the issue of former Senator Colston. Following the Attorney-General's reply to my question on notice No. 1154 of 15 February 2000, I asked the Attorney-General a further question, No. 1573, on 29 May 2000 on the application of the IPPs to the prosecution of former Senator Colston. The Attorney-General admitted that details of travel expenditure involve expenditure of public money and is a matter within the public interest and, hence, raise issues of protection of public revenue for the purposes of the Privacy Act 1988. The Attorney-General noted that disclosure of the former senator's medical records `is not reasonably necessary for the protection of the public revenue'. Under the IPP, the Attorney-General said that this policy did not compel him to disclose the names and reports of the two eminent and independent medical specialists, and concluded by saying that there is `insufficient public interest to justify the release of the information'. The Attorney-General just did not believe there was sufficient public interest and relied on the information privacy principles to deny me access to this information. In his media statement on 5 July 1999, the director noted:

quote.para: ... the Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth sets out factors which may arise in determining whether the DPP should decline to proceed further in a prosecution ... In the light of the medical evidence there is no prospect of this matter being able to proceed to trial ...

speech.para: On 4 September 2000 I asked the Attorney-General a further question on notice, No. 1925. This question was answered on 19 October 2000. At question (7) of question on notice No. 1925, I put to the Attorney-General:

quote.para: To what extent was the `necessity to maintain public confidence in such basic institutions as the Parliament and the courts' (Prosecution Policy subparagraph 2.10(t)) a paramount consideration in declining to proceed with prosecution.

speech.para: The Attorney General answered:

quote.para: It was of major importance.

speech.para: At question (10), I asked:

quote.para: Would the DPP consider obtaining a further medical examination in order to ascertain Mr Colston's current fitness to stand trial?

speech.para: The Attorney-General answered:

quote.para: The DPP's decision was based on independent expert medical advice that Mr Colston was not fit to stand trial and there was no prospect that he would be fit to stand trial in the future. If there was evidence contrary to that advice it would be considered.

speech.para: In light of the information privacy principles and how the director has applied them, can any member of this House explain how the public interest can be satisfied, given the Attorney-General's admission that the matter would be reconsidered if evidence contrary to earlier advice could be obtained? How is that evidence to be obtained but through an initiative of the Director of Public Prosecutions himself? My further question 13(e) asked:

quote.para: When did ... Mr Colston's legal counsel file evidence of his medical condition?

speech.para: The Attorney-General answered:

quote.para: The DPP was provided with medical reports by Mr Colston's solicitors on 3 and 13 November 1997 and 7 April 1999.

speech.para: Yesterday was 19 months to the day since 7 April 1999, since any medical evidence of former Senator Colston's condition was put before the DPP. However, I quote from today's media:

quote.para: Dr Colston's wife, Dawn, told Australian Associated Press yesterday that the DPP had been given medical reports on her husband's health four months ago which showed his condition had deteriorated.

speech.para: On 22 June 2000, at 12.13 p.m. precisely, my electorate officer, Ms Susan Sheather, received a telephone call in my office here in Parliament House from a woman who identified herself as Mrs Dawn Colston. She attempted to intimidate Ms Sheather and threatened to blow the whistle on all Labor Party members of parliament if I were to continue to ask questions in parliament about her husband. I have not noticed Mrs Dawn Colston tendering any evidence to the DPP, the parliament or anywhere else in respect of the behaviour of any members of this parliament, and I invite her to do so. She should know something about it.

Further, her husband is supposed to have a terminal illness. I do not wish former Senator Colston ill but, after 19 months, is it reasonable for the DPP to reconsider reopening this matter? I say that in light of reports that, since 7 April 1999, former Senator Colston has been seen dining out. He has been seen travelling inside and outside Queensland. He is well enough to write letters to the editor of the Brisbane Courier-Mail. However, we are advised that he is not well enough to stand trial. Why does it have to come to this point, when the application of the information privacy principles should so thwart the operation of justice as to make a mockery of the judicial system and turn privacy powers into a game of cat and mouse?

Why must the only notice of protection of the public interest in the Reith telecard scandal first come to the attention of the public through the media release of the Canberra Times? The telecard scandal went for six months without either rectification or discipline. Had it not been for the excellent journalism of the Canberra Times, we might never have discovered the $50,000 of alleged public theft at all. Now the figure could be even higher. And who knows what other unaccounted rorts, errors, omissions, et cetera, are going on, yet to be discovered?

The DPP continues to pursue the scoundrel Christopher Skase, and rightly so, who is seen regularly on television in a wheelchair complete with a mask and oxygen cylinders to give him life support. In other words, the DPP thinks Christopher Skase—a respiratory cripple—is fit enough to stand trial, but not former Senator Malcolm Arthur Colston, who is obviously active. What a joke the DPP is! As I have said, I have been pursing this matter with questions on notice since 15 February this year and it is like drawing blood out of a stone.

The IPPs discriminate against the public interest. I have personally witnessed the effects of the application of the IPPs in the context of the many questions I have asked in the Colston affair. We are still left wondering what evidence was relied upon by the director in refusing to pursue prosecution. Only public outcry and humiliation against Minister Reith compelled him to pay back the $50,000. The public demands accountability. The public wants justice. The public abhors politicians who have their snouts in the trough. This bill capitalises on the same information privacy principles that have contaminated public accountability. Whether public or private, this bill must make adjustment for a well-balanced role, through proportionate statutory reserve powers in the hands of government, for people to have access to information when there are public moneys or a matter of public interest at stake. Otherwise, we are creating a world where privacy may deny accountability, against the public interest. This new world of globalisation is precisely what the OECD and the corporate world want—a world where the corporations are increasingly non-accountable to the public. In the Colston affair, it is a government agency—namely, the DPP—that is judge, jury and executioner of the application of the IPPs. In this legislation it will be self-serving industry groups that will be responsible for prosecuting voluntary industry codes of conduct in compliance with the IPPs. Who watches the watchdog?

The DPP may sit there and simply deny the information under `privacy' because he believes there is insufficient public interest to release. However, the Attorney-General has on record contradicted him by establishing a test under fresh evidence that should be applied. Moreover, the likely outcome of the DPP's treatment of this matter is that, unless we persist with a line of questioning as I have done over the greater part of this year, the matter would be dead and buried. This seems to be the DPP's approach—let the sleeping dog lie. He is utterly uninterested in prosecuting this cause in the public interest. He just hopes the whole matter will go away. I am fortified to some extent that in today's newspapers he seems to be resurrecting his interest. So too there is a case of deja vu in the matter of the Reith telecard scandal. The government knew of the scandal before it made the front pages of the Canberra Times. However, it chose to do nothing. Not until the public outcry over the wrongness of the act did the government act.

What is the likely repercussion of this bill? It is a case of the same application of so-called privacy provisions in the private sphere. For who can ensure that the public interest will not be trammelled by determinations of the Privacy Commissioner or, worse still, an approved code adjudicator? This government is obsessed by privatisation, to the extent that even the adjudicators may be non-accountable persons. With regard to my questions to the Attorney-General, I believe that I have been denied information of significant public interest on matters involving the Commonwealth being defrauded of significant revenue. I am a federal member of parliament and I was denied this information. What hope does the public itself have in dealing directly with the Privacy Commissioner or any other government agency?

The IPPs as applied have demonstrated that they do not serve society or even the individual. They ignore collective powers and ensure that fraud against the Commonwealth, abuse of public revenues and other offences against the public interest cannot be prosecuted. In light of these demonstrated examples, I urge the government to make provisions that ensure that a balanced approach to privacy can work within a system of mutual obligation and not a system we currently see of individual exclusivity from public accountability. I oppose the bill. Finally, I draw to the attention of the DPP my question on notice No. 2145 in today's Notice Paper—again to the Attorney-General—in relation to the Colston affair. I reckon he should have a hard look at my questions.

talk.start.para: —In an age where our privacy is being eroded, in an age of computer technology, there is no more important legislation for us to consider than the privacy legislation that is before us today, the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000. As always, this government has been dragged kicking and screaming into the 21st century. The single most outstanding feature of this legislation is the time it has taken to find its way into this House. As always, the government has demonstrated a reluctance to legislate to protect consumers—and that is a real worry—ordinary Australians who rely on government to ensure that their privacy and wellbeing are protected, ordinary Australians who do not want their personal information widely distributed and used. That is what is happening at the moment. This personal information is being used to set up databases on Australians' likes, dislikes, spending patterns, personal preferences, income and where they live. This information is being collected and stored electronically. We have no protection whatsoever. We do not know what is happening. That is why this legislation is so important.

speech.para: We can ask why it has taken so long to introduce. My answer is that it is because, as always, this government has been stuck in a time warp. It is still back in the 1950s. We have a Prime Minister who has failed to recognise the advent of the information technology age, which is where I see that we are now. I have been led to question whether he can even use a computer. If he could, and if he ever used the Internet, he would see the plethora of web sites that exist and the information that is collected on those web sites. This is bad news for Australia and bad news for all Australians. Not only are we being left behind in the knowledge stakes by failing to ensure that all Australians have the education and the skills they need to embrace the new technology and to meet the challenges of our global economy; but also the government's hesitation has failed to ensure that the privacy of Australians is protected. That is a basic human right.

Australians have embraced the Internet. In fact, Australia is one of the countries with the highest Internet usage. Yet, until this legislation is passed, we have no privacy legislation governing information technology and the Internet. Not only is our privacy being interfered with but also our performance in the area of e-commerce is being affected. This legislation seeks to amend the 1988 Privacy Act. The Prime Minister promised before the 1996 federal election that his government would implement a national privacy framework. In 1996 a discussion paper was circulated but by 1997 the government had lost enthusiasm. The Prime Minister decided not to legislate to protect private information in the private sector. Rather, the Prime Minister requested that the Privacy Commissioner liaise with industry bodies with a view to establishing a voluntary self-regulation regime.

In the area of e-commerce, self-regulation is not going to work. The motive of the firms that are involved in e-commerce is profit, and to maximise their profit they need to maximise the information they have about us, the consumers—about all Australians. Each company involved in e-commerce will be pushing the parameters to ensure that it has as much information as it can because that means success, profit and a secure future.

I am really disappointed that the government failed to show leadership and introduce this legislation earlier. I think the only reason the legislation was finally introduced was that, if the federal government had not done it, the states would have done it. In December 1998 the government announced that it intended to legislate by means of a `light touch' legislative regime. I must say it is rather a light touch, but I will deal with that later. It has taken from December 1998 to get to where we are today. That is a long time. It hardly shows a government that is committed to ensuring that the privacy of Australian citizens is protected. While this legislation is most certainly better than nothing, it certainly does not go far enough. Information technology places the world at our fingertips. It enables us to communicate with each other. We can do our banking via the Internet, shop via the Internet and conduct most of our business via the Internet.
I was looking at some information the other day and I came across an article from the Reuters `business briefing'. I highlight one section from it:

quote.para: Privacy issues are complex because they touch on so many areas of our lives and involve such a wide range of activities: corporate data collection, the use of credit card numbers, computer hacking, telemarketing, emailed “spam” advertising, advertising on cell phone displays, and medical data collection, just to name a few.

speech.para: These are just a few of the things mentioned in the article. Along with the convenience of the Internet and e-commerce, there is the danger that our personal details can be used and our privacy abused. Many web sites that Internet users visit have `cookies' attached to them. These cookies save all sorts of information about the person who has visited the site—their personal data, their preferences and many other pieces of information. The user does not know that this information is being collected and stored, nor do they know for what purpose it will be used once it has been collected. The information is most frequently used for marketing, for looking at ways to manipulate our preferences and encourage us to purchase or behave in a certain way.

It is not that long ago that we saw the US Acxiom company establish a giant database with information on 15 million Australians. This information was obtained from a number of sources: ninemsn web site, Ticketek and many other sources. That information about 15 million Australians is stored on one gigantic database. Those 15 million Australians did not supply that to Acxiom and they still have no control over that information, but this legislation will not oversee it because it does not relate to access, correction, use and disclosure of information that already exists in databases. Though that information about 15 million Australians is there, those 15 million Australians can do nothing about that. That is one area of real concern about this legislation. I think it should be encompassed in the legislation that data that is already collected can be accessed and corrections and disclosure about the information on the database should be made public.

The government's procrastination in introducing this legislation has enabled more databases to be set up and more information to be collected on ordinary Australians, information that they themselves have no access to. The more I read about and consider this legislation, the more I am convinced that the government was reluctant to introduce any privacy legislation at all. This is weak and timid, but it is better than nothing. The government was forced to introduce this legislation because, if it failed to introduce national privacy legislation, Australia would have been faced with six or seven different privacy systems because each state would have had to develop its own legislation, as I mentioned a little earlier. Another reason that I believe the government finally decided to introduce national privacy legislation is that, if it had not, the European Community would not have dealt with Australia because the European Community data protection directive states that countries that do not extend their privacy regime to the private sector would not be able to exchange information with the European Community, or, in this case, the EC with Australia. That would have an enormous impact on Australian business and we would have been extremely disadvantaged. Other countries have already legislated in the area of privacy and many others are upgrading their legislation. In fact, at this stage even New Zealand has in place privacy legislation.

I also have some concerns with respect to the enforcement of this legislation. The legislation gives the Privacy Commissioner the power to recommend compensation for privacy breaches, but there is no provision in the legislation for civil penalties to punish corporations which engage in serious breaches. To be quite honest, I do not think that is good enough. Whilst I believe this is very weak legislation and legislation that has been introduced far too late, it is better than nothing. I refer to an article that appeared in the Age of 6 June this year. It highlights the need for privacy legislation and says:

quote.para: The drive to extract greater profit from budding e-commerce enterprises is starting to backfire as the online community expresses concern about privacy.

speech.para: The article points out that today the great threat of surveillance comes not so much from governments and their agencies, as predicted by George Orwell, as from surveillance by online businesses and corporations in the private sector. I hope that I have created a picture of that in what I have said today. It further says:

quote.para: Big Brother might be an overhyped fiction, but e-commerce's Little Brother—in the form of data-mining, CRM, data-matching and profiling—is a bigger threat.

speech.para: The article points out that too often we find ourselves handing over personal information about our private lives through surveys, membership applications, contracts and online forums. It is frightening and upsetting to think that here we are today in this House finally considering legislation that should have been looked at a long time ago. As the Age article rightly points out, Big Brother is no longer the government; rather, it is the private sector through online business and corporations in the enormous amount of data that is collected. This data details who we are, what we like, what we dislike and many other things about us—things that we often like to think are quite private. This data can predict the way we will act and goes to the core of who we are as people. This needs to have some controls placed on it. This data can be used to influence our choices and control our lives.

I encourage the government to accept the opposition's amendments and to give this legislation some real teeth. The government has already failed the Australian people by not recognising the need for privacy legislation. This has led to missed opportunities for business and loss of privacy for the many millions of Australians whose information has been stored in databases without their knowledge. I am pleased that this government has now introduced legislation into this House, but it was far too long coming and that certainly is not good enough.

talk.start.para: —It goes without saying that privacy is under more challenge and under greater threat than at any time in our history. Modern technology enables a sophisticated range of options for those who would pry into the personal and business lives of others for commercial gain, for political advantage or for other more devious means, perhaps blackmail. So it is encouraging to study the second reading speech on this bill, the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000, where the Attorney-General states:

quote.para: For the first time, Australians can be confident that information held about them by private sector organisations will be stored, used and disclosed in a fair and appropriate way. For the first time, Australians will have a right to gain access to that information and a right to correct it if it is wrong.

speech.para: Especially in electronic commerce, the Attorney-General rightly states that he has no doubt businesses which demonstrate they are committed to protecting the privacy of their customers will gain a competitive advantage. But I have concerns that this legislation relies too much on self-regulation rather than on mandated codes with strong enforcement and penalties.

It is encouraging to see that the National Principles for the Fair Handling of Personal Information, forming the basis of this legislation, were developed in a consultative process by the Privacy Commissioner with business, consumers and other stakeholders. It is good to see that the national privacy principles will deal with health information, one of the most personal and delicate areas of privacy. But on closer reading it is apparent that, despite recommendations from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, there are a large number of exceptions that serve to deny individuals access to their health records. It is encouraging to see the bill providing for private sector organisations to develop privacy codes of practice and that, where such codes do not have a complaints mechanism, the Privacy Commissioner will play that role. But there are many documented concerns that have not been addressed, including recommendations from government members of committees in both houses.

The House committee noted that the need for a small business exemption had been questioned, and there had been criticism of the turnover threshold of $3 million or less being, as they believed, an inappropriate measure in the context of privacy. In some ways the government has addressed this by a provision that small businesses deemed to be a risk to privacy can be brought within the legislation where that is necessary and in the public interest. There is also an opt-in/opt-out provision for small business, but in the government amendments there will be no ability to opt out so as to avoid any investigation of privacy breaches. That is a good thing.

However, it is sobering to note the evidence presented to the House committee by the Australian Privacy Charter Council that `something in the order of 93 per cent plus of all businesses would effectively be exempted under the definition and provisions in the bill'. The charter council argued that `there is nothing inherent in size that makes organisations more or less privacy invasive' and points to private detectives or debt collection as examples. Again, in e-commerce there would appear to be wide scope for such invasive activities by organisations with far less than the $3 million turnover. Indeed, the ABS statistics show that over 98 per cent of small businesses under its guidelines would fall under the $3 million threshold. The government uses the argument that it wishes to protect small business from unnecessary cost. That is an admirable ideal, but we are dealing with a serious issue and if individuals' rights are at risk of abuse, whether it be from the largest bank or the smallest Net based operator, they should all be under the cover of this legislation. Indeed, in her minority Senate report Senator Stott Despoja says:

quote.para: The lack of substantial compliance costs or other significant difficulties associated with small business may indicate why most countries that have implemented privacy regimes in the recent past do not have similar exemptions for small business.

speech.para: I look forward with interest to the regulation that is devised to bring privacy-risk small business under the umbrella of this proposed law. But, at the end of the day, this should not be the subject of regulation; it should be built into the law now. For example, New Zealand, Canada, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong and the European Union have all enacted similar privacy regimes to that proposed in the bill, but none of them has similar exemptions for small business.

Elsewhere, the government has not accepted a recommendation from the House committee that employee records be included under the cover of this legislation. Instead, the government states that the protection of employee records is more properly a matter for workplace relations legislation. I am unconvinced. The ACTU is also unconvinced and believes the Workplace Relations Act certainly does not deal adequately with privacy issues. The ACTU argument was backed up by the Australian Privacy Charter Council, the Investment and Financial Services Association and the Privacy Commissioner. The majority Senate committee report, at paragraph 3.20, says it is yet to be persuaded from available evidence that workplace relations or state and territory legislation `provides adequate protection of employee records from their access and disclosure'. This is one area of the bill where an amendment appears necessary.

While the exemption for the media appears to have widespread support, I place on the record my concerns that individual privacy is under constant threat from many media practices. The pressure for ratings, which is affecting and infecting judgment at the ABC as well, brings many opportunities to invade personal space. While I would in no way support legislation that impedes the necessary right of free speech and investigative journalism, I do not think the self-regulatory codes of conduct go anywhere far enough in protecting the vulnerable from exploitation. The code needs to be mandatory, overseen by a media council with teeth, and suspensions and fines of individuals and licensees need to be part of such a code, which itself is built into media legislation. The ALP minority report from the Senate inquiry points out that this bill does not strictly cover small business, employers, journalists—indeed, the media per se—members of parliament and big business if it develops its own code. That report suggests the legislation has been framed from the point of view of the organisation which must afford privacy rather than the person whose privacy is threatened. I must say I agree. I wonder, though, whether the ALP would be agreeable to political parties being included if the legislation covered issues such as unlimited access to electoral roll data and telephone polling.

Under the exemptions provided in the bill, the elector information databases currently maintained by the major political parties would remain unregulated. Not only are acts and practices of MPs exempted; so too are those of contractors and volunteers working for registered political parties or political representatives, but not those of nominated candidates. The New South Wales Privacy Commissioner says he is concerned about the exemption of political parties from the legislation and says it is inappropriate for such organisations to be exempt from the same practices and principles that are required for the wider community. In a former life, the New South Wales Privacy Commissioner was a prominent member of parliament and he brings a wide understanding of this profession to his judgment on that matter. He is concerned about the exemption of political parties. I suppose it follows that well-worn pattern such as the one we have with parliamentary superannuation, with one rule for the masses and another for us.

Let me raise some other concerns highlighted in the minority report from the Democrats in the Senate. The e-commerce provisions in the bill—which surely are one of the most essential roles this legislation will perform—`fail to give consumers the security they expect', according to the report. As for international obligations, despite the Attorney-General's second reading statement that `important trading partners are requiring an assurance that information will be given appropriate protection', the submission to the Senate inquiry from the European Commission says:

quote.para: ... we envisage the exclusion of small business would be problematical, since it would be very difficult in practice to identify small business operators before exporting data to Australia.

speech.para: It is important to note the conclusions drawn in the Bills Digest, whose research experts believe this parliament:

quote.para: ... has a complex task in assuring itself and the community that the Bill has struck, or as amended, will strike the right balance.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: The parliament might consider whether the broad exemptions found in the Bill that relate to employee records, the media, small business, and existing databases have tipped the balance in favour of business at the expense of individuals' rights to privacy.

speech.para: I am also concerned about aspects of this bill related to tenants or, indeed, the non- protection of their rights to privacy. I notice that the opposition, in its minority report in the Senate, details its concerns about the exclusion of tenancy databases. The report correctly states that information on those databases, where incorrect, has the capacity to seriously harm an individual's capacity to access one of the most basic human needs—housing. The report says:

quote.para: Where an increasing number of Australians are looking to rental accommodation for their long-term housing needs, it is imperative that individuals be equipped with an enforceable right to access information which is held about them on tenancy databases and to ensure this information is correct.

speech.para: I can think of one constituent and his concern about silent phone numbers given to police for investigations that have impacted on his rights to present and future rental accommodation—a campaign which he has been running for some time. I wish to mention briefly the situation regarding other telecommunications and privacy matters. Recently, I had cause to write to the federal Privacy Commissioner about several cases involving privacy issues and telecommunications suppliers, including Telstra. The commissioner informed me that, since Telstra is an incorporated company, it falls outside the definition of `agency' and therefore is not subject to the information privacy principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988. Even though the organisation is still 51 per cent publicly owned, it is not subject to the existing legislation. That perplexed many people who ran into problems, which I will detail in a moment. While the bill before us ostensibly amends part 6 of the Telecommunications Act to recognise the pre-eminence of the Privacy Act and the role of the Privacy Commissioner, it does so:

quote.para: ... without diminishing the integrity of the current telecommunications self--regulatory regime.

speech.para: That regime, dealt with through industry codes and industry standards, includes the protection of personal information, the intrusive use of telecommunications by carriers or service providers, the monitoring or recording of communications, calling number display and provision of directory products. In the current competitive climate of telecommunications, I believe these industry codes are being breached, at least in spirit, and I believe in intent too, by unconscionable conduct that is an invasion of privacy, and I see nothing in this bill that will properly address it. For instance, an 85-year-old man in Bathurst, hard of hearing, is rung by Primus Telecom, who he thinks is Telstra, once Telecom—he has not caught up with the fact that Telecom is now Telstra, and he thinks that Primus Telecom is something to do with Telstra—seeking his business. He is a bit confused: `I thought I was with Telstra.' Anyway, they give him the spiel. He agrees to a special deal, which he still thinks is coming from Telecom/Telstra, and then finds the account arrives in the name of a provider he has never heard of and that his Telstra account has been chopped off.

The provisions of part 6 allow the Australian Communications Authority to request development of a telecommunications industry code dealing with privacy. As the explanatory memorandum confirms, `no such power exists for the Privacy Commissioner'. However, while the bill does set in place a relationship between the Privacy Commissioner and the ACA to develop, strengthen or revoke industry standards, I believe these standards need to be mandated in legislation. Let me detail some more instances which I believe breach those industry standards. One Lithgow area telephone customer claims One.Tel changed over his phone without his or his wife's knowledge. They had received a call from One.Tel, asked for literature to be sent—they said, `Okay, send the stuff in the mail'—but had signed nothing and gave no verbal agreements. Their account was switched from Telstra to One.Tel and the first they knew about it was a letter, with their surname mispelt, congratulating them on the switch.

In another case, One.Tel claimed a 93-year-old Lithgow woman had given permission to switch her account from Telstra to One.Tel. She denies it. Somehow One.Tel claimed it had obtained the lady's birth date and bank account number for a direct debit. When asked by a relative to give the number, the bank account number given was not the woman's—which begs the question: whose number was it? A check with a Telstra regional complaints team revealed that others had been hassled by this organisation as well, mostly the elderly, thinking they were dealing with Telstra—so Telstra was copping the flak as well. The old lady is 93 and has been with Telecom and Telstra for 50 years. She had no intention of ever changing, yet she was put through this marketing rigmarole. And, yes, the whole episode, right from the initial misrepresented or misunderstood phone call, in my book is an invasion of privacy. The similarity of names—still using terms like `Telecom' and `Tel' in new company names—is part of a process that contributes to this deception—often, it seems, of old people. I do not know that the provisions that have been put in place in this bill or that the self-regulatory emphasis will in any way adequately deal with such situations.

In another case, a constituent claims she received a call from Telstra questioning her about her calling habits and why she had switched to a new carrier. The constituent's particular concern was that Telstra was using information about her call history to form the basis of questions. She regarded this, rightly or wrongly, as a breach of her privacy. On raising this with Telstra, I received a reply that Telstra—and no doubt other carriers—conducts its business in accordance with the industry privacy code, which is based on the national privacy principles. I really wonder, with the pressure to maintain clients on the one hand and the need to win clients on the other, whether the carriers in the market can be trusted to do the right thing, whether indeed the industry privacy code is worth anything at all. From the degree of concern I have seen in my own electorate about the sales practices of some of the newer players in the market, especially with older customers, I have grave doubts about that code.

The issue of privacy is an important and growing one in Australia. I well remember the fierce debate over the ill-fated Australia Card in the 1980s and the concerns of ordinary Australians about the intrusion of faceless government bureaucracy into their lives. That concern has only increased with the passage of intervening years and the computer driven technology that offers so much but that can intrude so much. The latest development is genetic engineering, with the mapping of the human genome and all the issues of privacy and the integrity of human data that it involves. That issue is not dealt with in this bill, and Senator Stott Despoja quite rightly points to the urgent need for legislation to protect Australians' genetic privacy.

In 1996, the government released a discussion paper on privacy to meet an election commitment that Australian privacy legislation would be developed in line with other policies worldwide. The legislation was supposed to bind the private sector to the international privacy principles that exist for the public sector. However, by 1997 the Prime Minister had backed away from this, deciding instead on a voluntary self-regulatory scheme for the private sector. It is suspected that the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry had something to do with that. So we have what has been called a `light touch' bill, which does not aggressively or adequately address many privacy issues of concern. The member for Shortland, prior to my speaking, was right when she described this bill as somewhat weak and timid but better than nothing. The bill does need strengthening in my humble estimation. I do not know if the government is of a mind to accept amendments, but I will support any moved here or in the other place that attend to the concerns I have outlined.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I would like to sum up the debate on the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000. I thank the numerous members who have participated for their valuable contributions to the debate on the bill. Australians have embraced the information technology revolution and the opportunities that the increasingly borderless commercial world has to offer. Advances in information technology have the potential to enrich our lives, work and wellbeing. Those same advances have the potential to erode our privacy. The privacy of personal information is of critical importance in an era when information is moved around the globe with the stroke of a keyboard. Clearly, privacy is an issue that must be addressed. On this, I think that both the government and the opposition agree. The amendments proposed by the opposition show that there is clearly disagreement between the government and the opposition on how this ought to occur.

speech.para: The Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000 implements the government's commitment to promote a light touch, coregulatory approach to privacy protection. The bill establishes a coregulatory framework that is responsive to both business and consumer needs. It has been drafted in such a way that it can be applied in both the conventional and electronic environments. The provisions in the bill represent an appropriate and workable balance between privacy interests and other important, competing public interests. The government's response to the recommendations made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs following their inquiry into the bill finetunes that balance. By comparison, the bill as proposed to be amended by the opposition would be quite different. It would be far more prescriptive and heavy-handed. It would not have the support of business and industry. It would not strike an appropriate balance between all interested parties, as the bill currently does.

Concerns have been expressed about the 12-month delay in the commencement of the legislation following royal assent. This delay is based on a realistic approach to the implementation of this significant legislation. This is not legislation amending existing rights and responsibilities; it is creating rights and responsibilities that have not existed before in Australia. Reassessment by an organisation of its process for handling personal information will take time, as will the development and approval of privacy codes. The government is of the view that 12 months is a reasonable time frame within which to expect organisations to implement systems and practices to ensure that they can comply with this legislation when it comes into operation.

The exemption for small business is based on the premise that not all private sector organisations pose the same risk to privacy. Many small businesses do not have significant holdings of personal information. They may have customer records that they use for their own business purposes; however, they do not sell or otherwise deal with customer information in a way that poses a high risk to the privacy interests of those customers. However, the government recognises that there are some small businesses, or acts and practices of small businesses, that pose a higher risk to privacy than others and should be caught by the privacy obligations set out in the bill. The bill makes it very clear that not all businesses with an annual turnover of $3 million or less can take advantage of the exemption. Small businesses that provide health services and hold health information are one example of this special category. Small businesses that trade in personal information are another. It is for this reason that small business operators that provide health services and hold health information, that trade in personal information or that are contracted to provide a service to the Commonwealth will be covered by the legislation.

I note that the opposition is strongly of the view that tenancy databases should be covered by this legislation and should not be able to take advantage of the small business exemption. The government does not accept the opposition's position. In doing so, the government is not saying that the issues surrounding the use of tenancy databases are not significant or that the acts and practices concerning such databases should not be covered by the bill. The government believes that the bill as it is covers tenancy databases. Organisations that avail themselves of the use of tenancy databases rely on a flow of personal information to and from organisations that maintain these databases. Where this flow of personal information occurs between organisations for a benefit, service or advantage, such organisations would not be able to take advantage of the small business exemption in any event.

The government does not believe there is sufficient justification for singling out those databases from the small business exemption. The current set-up of the bill is that all businesses are covered unless they are specifically exempted from the bill. To expressly refer to a particular industry that is already covered by the bill would be contrary to the manner in which the bill is set up and it is unnecessary. If tenancy databases prove to be a problem, the bill allows for regulations to be made prescribing small business operators or the acts or practices of small business operators that will have the effect of bringing those prescribed small business operators or the prescribed acts and practices of small business operators within the scope of the regime.

The government has accepted the House of Representatives committee recommendation to include a mechanism in the bill to allow a small business to voluntarily opt in to coverage by the legislation. Such a mechanism is included in the amendments moved by the government. Under these amendments, a small business that wishes to voluntarily opt in to the legislative scheme, for commercial reasons or otherwise, would be able to ask the Privacy Commissioner to include the business in a public register set up for this purpose by the commissioner. Where market forces dictate that a small business operator ought to be covered, it is likely that this mechanism would be used by that small business operator. For example, a small business may take up this opportunity if it has a business relationship with larger businesses that are subject to the legislation and those larger businesses insist on their trading partners being subject to the same privacy rules.

The bill provides that an act done, or a practice engaged in, by an employer is exempt from the operation of the bill if the act or practice is directly related to a current or former relationship between the employer and the individual or an employee record held by the employer relating to the individual. Clearly, this does not give employers the ability to do whatever they like with employee records. The employer must be dealing with the employee records in the context of a current or former employment relationship for the exemption to apply. This means that there is no scope for an employer to sell or otherwise take commercial advantage of the personal information contained in the employee records it holds. The regulation of the employee records is an area that intersects with a number of state and territory laws on workplace relations, minimum employment conditions, workers compensation and occupational health and safety. To attempt to deal with employee records comprehensively in the bill would result in an unacceptable level of interference with those state and territory laws and create a confusing mosaic of obligations. This is an area that is better dealt with in the context of workplace relations reform than privacy regulation.

The government recognises that the Australian public consider their health records to be particularly sensitive. The bill takes these sensitivities into account. In developing the legislation, the government has carefully considered the views of the health sector, health consumers, insurers and other organisations that hold health information. The bill's health provisions are sensible and workable. Appropriate and adequate safeguards have been included to protect the privacy of health information of Australians. The bill provides additional protections in relation to the use and disclosure of health information, as such information is clearly considered by the community to be particularly sensitive. For example, national privacy principle 10 limits the ways that sensitive information, including health information, may be collected. As a further example, national privacy principle 2 prohibits the use of sensitive information, such as health information, for direct marketing purposes. Significantly, for the first time, Australians will have the right to seek access to and to correct health records held about them by private sector organisations. Subject to certain exceptions, such as where providing access would pose a serious threat to the life or health of any individual, organisations must provide individuals with access to information held about them. The government plans to work closely with the office of the federal Privacy Commissioner and key stakeholders to develop the implementation guidelines to ensure the appropriate handling of what we would all agree is highly sensitive information.

The members for Barton, Gellibrand, Maribyrnong and Chisholm have raised the issue of the application of this bill to existing databases, particularly those national privacy principles concerning the use and disclosure and access and correction rights which the government has decided should apply only to information collected after the legislation commences. There are good reasons why the government has not applied these privacy principles to information already collected and in the possession of a private sector organisation at the date this legislation comes into operation. These are largely concerned with the fact that, until such time as the legislation is in effect, the organisation does not have to comply with the collection principles. It may not be possible to retrospectively discern in relation to existing information what were the primary and secondary purposes for collection. Organisations were not required to inform people at the time the information was collected about the intended uses of their information and to whom it would be disclosed. For the government to require organisations to provide access to personal information already in their possession at the date this legislation commences operation would impose an unreasonable burden on the private sector. Of course, the government is not saying that an organisation cannot provide access; it is just saying that it will not require organisations to provide access. An organisation can always provide it if it chooses to do so. An organisation will, in relation to personal information collected before the date on which the bill comes into effect, be required to take reasonable steps to make sure that the personal information it uses or discloses is accurate, complete and up to date. Such organisations will also be required to be open about what sorts of personal information they hold and what purposes information is used for, including having clearly expressed policies on their management of personal information. They will have to take reasonable steps to protect all personal information in their possession from misuse and loss and from unauthorised access, modification or disclosure. They will also have to take reasonable steps to destroy or permanently remove identifying information if it is no longer needed for any purpose.

Finally, if transferring personal information about an individual to someone who is in a foreign country, such organisations will have to comply with the principles regarding transborder dataflows. After the bill takes effect, organisations that hold existing databases of personal information will need to comply with all aspects of the legislation when they update that information, including those aspects relating to collection, access, use and disclosure. In the information industry, the currency of personal information is crucial. This means that, over time, the complete set of principles will come to apply to that updated information.

The bill allows a person to make a complaint if they think a private sector organisation has handled their personal information inappropriately. The complaint handling process is designed for people to have their complaints dealt with simply, quickly, at low cost and without red tape. It is designed to ensure that most complaints can be resolved through conciliation and mediation rather than through an adversarial court process.

The process for investigating complaints is based on that which is applied and has worked well in the Commonwealth public sector since 1989. In the first instance, complaints are to be directed to the organisation concerned. If the person and the organisation are unable to resolve the matter between themselves, the person can request that an independent person investigate the complaint. Where the organisation concerned is subject to an approved privacy code that includes a mechanism for handling complaints, the independent investigator will be an adjudicator nominated under the code. Where the organisation is not subject to an approved code, the federal Privacy Commissioner will handle the complaint. Where the independent investigator finds that the organisation has interfered with the person's privacy, the investigator has a number of options, including making an order that the organisation redress any loss or damage or pay compensation to the person. If the order is not complied with, the individual may commence proceedings in the Federal Magistrates Service or the Federal Court for an order to enforce the determination.

Where the Privacy Commissioner determines that an organisation has interfered with the privacy of a person, the commissioner has a number of options available to address the issue. The bill provides that an adjudicator under an approved privacy code must have the same options to make declarations in relation to privacy breaches as the Privacy Commissioner. The options available to the Privacy Commissioner and, when the private sector provisions commence, to a code adjudicator, include making a declaration that the organisation should not repeat or continue the offending conduct, should perform any reasonable act or course of conduct to redress the loss or damage suffered by the person concerned, and/or should pay a specified amount by way of compensation for any loss or damage suffered by the person concerned. Loss or damage can include injury to the person's feelings or humiliation suffered by that individual. The penalties for privacy infringements by a private sector organisation are the same as those that currently apply in respect of the Commonwealth public sector. These penalties have been applied by the Privacy Commissioner since the Privacy Act came into force over 11 years ago, and they have worked effectively.

A key feature of the bill is the ability of organisations to develop their own codes regulating the collection, storage, use and disclosure of personal information. The national privacy principles will also provide minimum benchmarks for the development of privacy codes under the bill. However, private sector organisations are free to adopt higher standards if considered appropriate. The national privacy principles set out in the bill will operate where a business or other organisation chooses not to adopt its own privacy code.

Freedom of political communication is vitally important to Australia's democracy. It is important to preserve the operation of the electoral and political process in Australia. The exemption in the bill for political parties registered under electoral laws, and for acts and practices concerning the political process, is designed to encourage that freedom. I note that the European Union directive on the protection of personal data recognises the need for political parties operating in a democratic system to be free to compile data on people's political opinion. The exemption will not derogate from the objectives of the bill.

The government acknowledges that there is a clear public interest in the free flow of information to the Australian public and that the media has an important role in facilitating that flow. Quite clearly, however, there is also a public interest in ensuring that media organisations handle personal information about individual Australians in a responsible and appropriate way. The government's amendments to the media exemption seek to ensure that an appropriate balance is found between these important public interests. These amendments also aim to address recommendation 9 of the House of Representatives committee report on the privacy bill. The effect of the amendments is to require a media organisation to meet an additional condition before its acts and practices in the course of journalism are exempt under the privacy bill. The additional condition is that a media organisation publicly commit to observing published standards that deal with privacy at the time it engages in an act or practice in the course of journalism.

Many media organisations already subscribe to published codes of practice that deal with privacy developed by industry bodies that represent them. The additional condition will not require a media organisation to subscribe to a privacy code approved by the Privacy Commissioner in order to benefit from the exemption. These amendments are therefore consistent with the government's commitment to promoting effective self-regulation and coregulation of the information and communications industry while at the same time encouraging the responsible handling of personal information by that industry.

I would like to go back to the national privacy principles, which are the core of this bill. When the decision was made to legislate, the government considered that the National Principles for the Fair Handling of Personal Information developed by the former Privacy Commissioner were an appropriate basis for the legislation. The national privacy principles regulate how and when an organisation can collect personal information. The principles also restrict what organisations can do with personal information after it has been collected. The general rule is that personal information should only be used or disclosed in a way that is consistent with people's expectations or where it is in the public interest to use it or disclose it in that way.

The national privacy principles also provide strict guidelines for the collection of information that the community considers to be particularly sensitive, such as health information, criminal records, political opinions or religious beliefs. Significantly, the principles will give Australians the right to access records containing personal information about them and to seek to have those records corrected if they are wrong. To cover the costs associated with providing such access, businesses are permitted to impose a charge for access, so long as it is not excessive. The national privacy principles in the bill are intended to provide a basis for business to develop practices to ensure that the privacy of Australians' personal information is protected. They are minimum standards but are workable, flexible and comprehensive. They have been accepted by business and industry, and they provide a sound basis for legislation.

There comes a point at which the talking has to cease, decisions have to be made and action has to be taken. There is no denying that this bill involves competing public and private interests. Tough decisions have been made to strike an appropriate balance between all of these interests. This bill is a realistic reflection of the various competing interests. It will provide comprehensive privacy benchmarks for the handling of personal information by the private sector and will ensure that Australia is well placed to take full advantage of the opportunities presented by electronic commerce. It is now time to stop talking and to act to ensure that privacy standards for the handling of personal information by private sector organisations in Australia are enshrined in legislation. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —It may assist the House if I indicate that I propose to move some 25 opposition amendments to the bill. To facilitate consideration of the bill, I therefore seek leave to move a number of opposition amendments together. The course of action I propose is to move opposition amendments 3, 4, 11 and 12 together; opposition amendments 8 and 9 together; opposition amendments 17, 18, 19 and 25 together; and opposition amendments 20, 21, 22 and 23 together. I propose to move the remainder of the opposition amendments separately. I also have a number of amendments to proposed government amendments, but I will deal with those later in the debate. I now move:

quote.para: (1) Clause 2, page 1 (lines 8 to 13), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) Subject to this section, this Act commences on 1 July 2001.

speech.para: This is a simple amendment. It would amend proposed section 2 of the bill, which currently provides that the date of commencement of the act will be the first day after the end of the period of 12 months, beginning on the day on which the act receives royal assent, or otherwise 1 July 2001. Clearly we have gone beyond 1 July 2000. If this bill is enacted, it would not commence until at least 12 months hence. So, assuming the bill is passed through the Senate, which we sincerely hope it will be by the end of the year, it would not commence until the end of next year. To put that in its context, the act probably would not commence until after the next election. Labor say that that is unacceptable. It is our view that effective privacy protection is needed now.

There has been a history of delay on the part of the government in bringing forward effective private sector privacy regulation. In particular, in March 1997 the government withdrew from the field entirely in terms of a legislative response in this very important area. These national privacy principles have been in place since 1998, although it must be said that it has been on a voluntary basis. Nonetheless, the key principles underlining this bill, which give the national privacy principles limited legislative backing, have been in the public domain since at least December of last year. Labor's amendment will ensure that privacy protection is put in place with effect from 1 July 2001, which will give a good six months lead-in time. We say that that is the earliest date contemplated by the bill and should appropriately become the date of commencement of the act if the bill is passed.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment. As the member for Barton said, I accept that there are some organisations that have been conscious of privacy concerns for some time. There are some enterprises—and even sectoral organisations—that have put in place codes of conduct, some of which are based on the national privacy principles, but it is not true of all business. An example of that was the sudden discovery by the media at the end of last year that media organisations would be subject to the privacy bill, which resulted in a clamour in the media to slow down the headlong rush to put the bill into legislation after three years of preparation.

speech.para: The 12-month lead-time is essential for business to get ready for the legislation. Organisations will need to reassess their practices and procedures and to develop new ones that comply with the legislation. Organisations may also want to develop their own privacy codes for submission to and approval by the Privacy Commissioner. The Privacy Commission will also need this 12-month period to educate business and consumers to develop guidelines and to assist business with the development of privacy codes. In seeking to cut short the time that organisations have to comply with the new legislation, the opposition displays a lack of appreciation of what good privacy practice entails. This legislation would come into force quicker if the opposition were to assist with its passage through the parliament.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: (2) Clause 3, page 2 (after line 20), at the end of paragraph (3), add:
; and
(iv) provide individuals with mechanisms by which they can obtain appropriate redress for interferences with privacy; and
(v) provide the Privacy Commissioner with the means to monitor and prevent the systematic abuse of privacy by organisations.

speech.para: This amendment is also a simple amendment. It proposes an amendment to the objects of the bill to include additional objects. The first object is to provide individuals with mechanisms by which they can obtain appropriate redress for interferences with privacy and the second object is to provide the Privacy Commissioner with the means to monitor and prevent the systematic abuse of privacy by organisations. As we have said in the course of the second reading debate, the government's bill falls short of these two important measures of effective privacy regulation from the point of view of Australian citizens. Our amendments, along with our other amendments that I will shortly be moving, seek to address this by boosting the powers of the Privacy Commissioner and giving the bill more `effect', more grunt, from the point of view of its ability to protect the interests of private citizens.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment. The objects clause in the bill currently describes the objects as being to establish a national scheme for the appropriate handling of personal information in a way that: (i) meets Australia's international privacy obligations; (ii) recognises individuals' interests in protecting their privacy; and (iii) recognises important human rights that compete with privacy. The opposition's proposed amendments are much more detailed in nature and come close to being functions rather than objects. They are unnecessary as additions to the objects clause are they are already encompassed by the broad objects statements in the current objects clause. They add nothing of substance and in fact have the further difficulty that they contemplate amendments that the government will be opposing.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

quote.para: (3) Schedule 1, item 12, page 6 (lines 8 to 26), omit the definition of employee record, substitute:

employee record, in relation to an employee, means a record of personal information relating to the employment of the employee other than an exempt employee record. Examples of personal information relating to the employment of the employee are health information about the employee and personal information about all or any of the following:
(a) the terms and conditions of employment of the employee;
(b) the employee's personal and emergency contact details;
(c) the employee's performance or conduct;
(d) the employee's salary or wages;
(e) the employee's membership of a professional or trade association;
(f) the employee's trade union membership;
(g) the employee's recreation, long service, sick, personal, maternity, paternity or other leave;
(h) the employee's taxation, banking or superannuation affairs.
(4) Schedule 1, after item 13, page 7 (after line 22), insert:
Insert:
exempt employee record, in relation to an employee, means a record of personal information relating to the employment of the employee and relating to:
(a) the engagement, training, disciplining or resignation of the employee;
(b) the termination of the employment of the employee; or
(c) the employee's performance or conduct.
(11) Schedule 1, item 42, page 23 (line 19), omit “Employee records”, substitute “Exempt employee records”.
(12) Schedule 1, item 42, page 23 (lines 25 to 26), omit paragraph (b), substitute:
(b) an exempt employee record held by the organisation and relating to the individual.

speech.para: These amendments relate to the concept of employee records. In moving these amendments we recognise that there is certainly a balance to be achieved in protecting the right of privacy of private citizens but not adding unnecessary burdens to businesses, whether they be small or big businesses. However, there is a range of material that is not relevant to the employment relationships, such as an employee's health records, family records and even the payroll deductions that they may have on a weekly basis, either to a trade union, to a particular credit facility or some other organisation. These things clearly are not contemplated within the normal understanding of employee records and indeed are not contemplated in relevant state industrial laws, albeit there may be some protections in state privacy laws.

Our amendments are intended to implement the unanimous recommendations of the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which we note the government has rejected. The House committee was a strong committee in terms of those members of this House that sit on the committee. That committee recommended that the definition of `employee record' be amended and a new definition of `exempt employee record' be inserted.
