Employee records as currently defined are entirely exempt from the national privacy principles. Labor's amendments will give employee records the protection of the NPPs but will leave exempt employee records outside the scheme of the act. That is, those exempt employee records would be records in relation to the personal information of the employee, consisting of details in respect of the engagement, training, disciplining or resigning of the employee or the termination of employment of the employee or the employee's performance or conduct. That exemption accords with the community's understanding of what we would normally be talking about when we are talking about employee information in the hands of an employer. Our exemption of this particular matter would remove the employer's obligations under the Privacy Act in respect of those sorts of things but it would give protection in respect of those things which I think fair-minded Australians would say are not commonly understood as being relevant to the employment relationship such as, as I have said, health information, family information or even payroll deduction information. The House committee recognised that it would be inappropriate to treat these records like other employee records and accordingly made the recommendation which Labor has accepted. Again, we would call on the government to reconsider their rejection of that committee recommendation.

talk.start.para: —Amendments (3), (4), (11) and (12), as the member for Barton has pointed out, relate to employee records and their exemption from the privacy regime contemplated under the bill. The bill currently defines employee records expansively. Amendment (3) amends the definition of employee record in the bill by deleting paragraphs (a) and (b) of the definition. It also appears the opposition intended to delete paragraph (e) but it seems to have been retained through a drafting error. Amendment (4) inserts a new definition to the bill, `exempt employee record'. An exempt employee record is defined as a record of personal information relating to the employment of the employee and relating to an employee's engagement, training, discipline, resignation, termination, performance and conduct. In effect, this definition consists of the elements of the definition of employee record deleted by amendment (3). Amendment (11) changes the heading of subsection 7B(3) from `Employee records' to `Exempt employee records' and then amendment (12) amends subsection 7B(3) so that the acts and practices of organisations would be exempt in relation to `exempt employee records' rather than the more expansive `employee records'. This has the effect of significantly narrowing the extent of the exemption.

speech.para: The amendments, I would suggest, are not new. Similar suggestions were made, as the member for Barton mentioned, by the House committee in its report on the bill. The reasons the government gave for not accepting those suggestions then are equally sound today. The regulation of employee records is a matter that is best dealt with in the workplace relations context. In addition, the regulation of employee records intersects with state and territory legislation and there is a real danger that if we impose excessive privacy regulation on employee records we unintentionally create a confusing and mismatched set of obligations. It is not in anybody's interests to place such a burden on employers.

The opposition does not seem to have made up its mind whether an employee's performance or conduct should be covered by the bill. This may be a drafting error, but it reflects perhaps the haste with which the opposition amendments have been put together and the lateness of the time at which they have been provided to the government—a subject that has been dealt with by a number of members of the government in the second reading debate. The employee's performance and conduct reference is listed under the definitions of both `employee record' and `exempt employee record'. If the opposition amendments were accepted, the only types of employee records that would be exempt from the bill would be those relating to an employee's engagement, training, discipline, resignation, termination, performance and conduct. There are clearly many other types of information which could be included on an employee record. That information would all be subject to the provisions of the bill if these amendments were accepted, imposing unnecessary administrative and financial burdens on Australian employers. If one contemplates what would be required in segregating from one record or one set of records those matters relating to engagement, training, discipline, resignation, termination, performance and conduct, and leaving the others out, one can see that it would just be a nightmare for employers if the government were to accept these amendments.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (5):

quote.para: (5) Schedule 1, item 18, page 8 (lines 29 to 35), omit definition of journalism, substitute:
journalism means the practice of collecting, preparing for dissemination or disseminating the following material for the purpose of making it available to the public:
(a) material having the character of news, current affairs or a documentary;
(b) material consisting of commentary or opinion on, or analysis of, news, current affairs or a documentary.

speech.para: This amendment relates to the definition of journalism. The government seeks to delete the definition of journalism from the bill, but in our view that is unsatisfactory. It is our argument that reverting to a plain English definition of journalism will create great uncertainty as to which acts are covered and which are not. Labor's preference is to retain the definition of journalism but to confine it more narrowly than the definition which appears in the current bill.

Our chief concern is that the definition as it currently stands is too broad and provides too great a scope for the journalism exemption to be abused by unscrupulous operators who should not rightfully obtain the benefit of the exemption. For instance, as referred to during the second reading debate, there is an argument about the information contained in the CrimeNet database, which is essentially information about citizens' convictions according to records researched by the CrimeNet organisation. Insofar as that organisation is providing the information over the Internet, it may well be the case that that organisation would fall within the journalism exemption if the government's proposals are allowed to remain as they are proposed. Under our amendment, on the other hand, journalism will mean:

quote.para: ... the practice of collecting, preparing for dissemination or disseminating the following material for the purpose of making it available to the public:
(a) material having the character of news, current affairs or a documentary;
(b) material consisting of commentary or opinion on, or analysis of, news, current affairs or a documentary.

speech.para: That would distinguish, for instance, the CrimeNet situation, which is simply providing information about people. By omitting reference to the very broad concept of information, Labor's amendment is narrower and more accurately reflects the common view of what journalism is. Labor will also support the amendments to be moved by the government, which confine the exemption to those organisations which publicly commit to privacy standards—provided, however, we say, that the Privacy Commissioner is given a role in considering and approving those standards.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment. As the member for Barton has indicated, the government proposes that the definition of journalism be deleted altogether, and government amendment (2) will be moved to that effect. On that basis, to amend the definition would be, in our view, inappropriate. It is appropriate, in our view, to rely on the common law definition. This will confine the exemption to commonly understood activities of journalism. The media exemption was the subject of intense negotiation with media organisations after they realised that they were going to be subject to the bill. Further changes to it would need to be subject to additional consultation. The government much prefers the term to be left undefined rather than fiddling with the edges and, as a consequence, raising further questions about its meaning.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (6):

quote.para: (6) Schedule 1, after item 22, page 9 (after line 23), insert:
Repeal the definition of personal information, substitute:

Personal information means information or an opinion (including information or an opinion forming part of database), whether true or not, and whether recorded in a material form or not, about an individual:
(a) whose identity is apparent from the information or opinion; or
(b) who can be identified, directly or indirectly, by reference to the information or opinion.

speech.para: This amendment modifies the definition of personal information contained in the parent act, the Privacy Act. Currently there is doubt as to whether that definition of personal information as contained in the act would include information on individuals which has been revealed by such things as cookies and web bugs used over the Internet. The way these things operate, as I understand it, is that they will identify when someone has entered or browsed a particular web site. That information fed back to the service provider may not necessarily in itself identify the particular person, but subsequently, if that person makes a purchase over the Internet, subscribes to a service or otherwise gives their personal records, there is a means of connecting that detail to the whole trail of where that person has browsed.

I appreciate that the intention of the government is to keep this legislation technologically neutral, and there are sound policy reasons for that, because technology develops very rapidly. Nonetheless, we think that we have come up with a form of words which more satisfactorily covers the use of these sorts of techniques, and the definition which we are proposing for personal information is:

quote.para: ... information or an opinion (including information or an opinion forming part of database), whether true or not, and whether recorded in a material form or not, about an individual:
(a) whose identity is apparent from the information or opinion; or
(b) who can be identified, directly or indirectly, by reference to the information or opinion.

speech.para: The key to our amendment is that it ensures that personal information, which includes information about an individual who can be indirectly identified by reference to information ascertained from an examination of such things as Internet cookies or web bugs, will be included. The current definition, as I have indicated, was conceived in an age when technology did not permit this kind of information to be stored and exploited, in particular by merging it with other information obtained from a variety of sources. Our new definition draws on the European definition which, while still technologically neutral, we believe is more technologically savvy.

talk.start.para: —It came as something of a surprise that the opposition seeks to amend a definition that has been in the act and has operated quite successfully for some 12 years, at least in the public sector, and the reason behind this was not at all clear until the member for Barton spoke, because there has been no consultation at all on this issue. Having listened to the member for Barton, I am not convinced that there is a difference of moment that needs to be addressed by an amendment. But, while we will oppose the amendment at this stage, we will give further consideration to what he has said.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 7:

quote.para: (7) Schedule 1, after item 33, page 11 (after line 30), insert:
Insert:
tenancy information means information or an opinion about an individual collected in connection with the provision of residential accommodation to the individual that is also personal information.

speech.para: This amendment inserts a definition of tenancy information. Tenancy information means information or an opinion about an individual which is collected in connection with the provision of residential accommodation to the individual. That tenancy information must also be personal information as defined in the primary act—whichever definition is ultimately decided upon. The House of Representatives committee to which I have referred recommended that the national privacy principles apply to tenancy databases from the date of commencement of the bill and that the government ensure that tenancy databases do not gain the benefit of the small business exemption.

We note that the government have rejected the recommendation but, we believe, without any real explanation. There is no question that tenancy databases have aroused a considerable degree of community concern. We think that it is entirely appropriate that tenancy databases be addressed specifically in the bill. We hold this view because information on those databases, if incorrect, has a capacity to seriously harm an individual's capacity to access one of the most basic human needs for themselves and, more often than not, their family—and that, of course, is housing. When an increasing number of Australians are looking for rental accommodation for their long-term housing needs, it is imperative that individuals be equipped with an enforceable right to access information held about them on tenancy databases and to ensure that the information is correct. This should be the case, regardless of when the information was collected.

talk.start.para: —The government considers this proposed amendment and amendments Nos 8 and 9 that the member for Barton will move following this amendment as unnecessary. They relate to the privacy practices of businesses that collect tenancy information and they also relate to the relationship between the small business exemption and the employee records exemption. It is the government's view that a definition of tenancy information is unnecessary and, as I have already expressed, that it is not appropriate for one particular group of businesses to be singled out in the bill. The best solution to concerns about tenancy database operators is to monitor their activities to see if any further regulation is required. The bill provides the Attorney-General with the power to prescribe small businesses or particular acts or practices of small businesses that should be brought within the ambit of the bill. This is the appropriate mechanism to be used to address the issue of tenancy databases once there is actual evidence that they pose a threat to the privacy of individuals. If there is to be any single sector or small business type to be dealt with by special provisions, no doubt there will be pressure for others and the broad principles of the bill will be lost.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 8 and 9:

quote.para: (8) Schedule 1, item 36, page 14 (line 22), omit “In this Act”, substitute “Subject to subsections (1A) and (1B), in this Act”.
(9) Schedule 1, item 36, page 15 (after line 6), after subsection (1), insert:
(1A) Notwithstanding subsection (1), a small business operator is deemed to be an organisation with respect to its actions and practices in relation to:
(a) an employee record it holds; and
(b) tenancy information it holds.
(1B) Notwithstanding subsection (1), a small business operator is deemed to be an organisation if it accepts online payment for goods or services.

speech.para: As the Attorney-General indicated, these amendments relate to our two earlier amendments and are again intended to implement the unanimous recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which have been rejected by the government. The committee recommended that a new subclause be inserted to ensure that the small business exemption does not extend to acts or practices of a small business operator in relation to personal information about an employee. Again, that is information about health, family relationships, payroll deductions and the like, which we have proposed exempting from the small business exemption. It was also recommended that the national privacy principles apply to tenancy databases, as I previously indicated, from the date of commencement of the bill and that the government ensure that the tenancy databases do not gain the benefit of the small business exemption. These amendments are included in our proposed subclause 1A.

Our amendment also proposes a new subclause 1B to address privacy concerns in relation to information collected through the use of Internet technologies. Evidence has been given to a Senate committee examining these issues that the government's small business exemption would exempt some 94 per cent of businesses that currently participate in electronic commerce in Australia. Our amendment proposes to include such businesses within the privacy regulation. There are very sound reasons, as I indicated in my second reading contribution, for that to occur. Our new subclause 1B states:

quote.para: Notwithstanding subsection (1), a small business operator is deemed to be an organisation if it accepts online payment for goods or services.

speech.para: Being deemed to be an organisation—that is, an organisation covered by the act—and receiving payment for online goods or services will necessarily mean that it will have private information from the citizen purchasing the goods, such as credit card details, and of course name and address, together with other information which a number of businesses acquire as part of incentive programs and the like. We say that this is not only a human rights issue but also an essential economic issue. For instance, it has been predicted that, worldwide, the value of Internet commerce will increase from something like $657 billion this year to as much as $6.8 trillion in the year 2004. Even if that is not achieved, clearly there will be a massive increase in the amount of Internet or electronic commerce. But, at the moment, only about five per cent of Australians who use the Internet—and I think there are about 43 per cent of Australians who do—are prepared to buy goods and services online.

All the evidence and expert opinion suggests that privacy fears are the greatest impediment to the greater uptake of Internet technology. Our proposed subclause 1B will ensure that people dealing with online operators can be confident that their privacy will be protected, regardless of the size of the web site operator. It will also, very importantly, give overseas consumers greater confidence in engaging in electronic commerce with Australian businesses. We say that this is in the category of not only a human rights issue but also an economic imperative if Australia is to get a piece of the action in what is going to be a rapidly increasing commercial activity around the world.

talk.start.para: —I have effectively foreshadowed, in opposing amendment (7), that we would oppose amendments (8) and (9) as well. It is accepted that the development of electronic commerce is vital for the future of the Australian economy and that we need to be part of the international movement towards it. We also accept—and I have mentioned this publicly on many occasions—that people dealing online frequently provide false information in order not to disclose their identity so that personal data relating to them is not misused in any way. A surprisingly high percentage of people who participate in electronic commerce engage in this provision of false information. We cannot support what the opposition seek to do. It has not been properly thought through. It has been considered only superficially and we do not believe it is good public policy.

speech.para: Amendments (8) and (9), along with amendment (7), attempt to apply the provisions of the bill to all small businesses that hold employee records and tenancy information and accept payment online for goods and services. To accept these amendments would mean that a small business could be exempt in relation to some of the information holders and subject to the bill in relation to other information. This has the potential to create uncertainty and to be an unsatisfactory situation for small businesses and the members of the community who want to deal with them. I have commented in relation to amendment (7) about tenancy databases and I will not repeat my comments.

The amendment that would deny the small business exemption to a small business operator that accepts online payment for goods or services is a totally new invention that we have not discussed with the opposition previously. Simply accepting payment online has nothing to do with what is the real privacy risk. The opposition's amendment is really nothing more than an unnecessary imposition on businesses trying to engage in the new economy. As the member for Barton has said previously, the government has sought to make the legislation technologically neutral. We believe it applies equally to online transactions between information gatherers and the public as it does to non-online or non-digital transactions.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: (10) Schedule 1, item 36, page 18 (lines 23 to 24), omit paragraph (c), substitute:
(c) discloses personal information about another individual to anyone else other than:
(i) with the consent of the other individual; or
(ii) as required or authorised by or under legislation.

speech.para: This amendment must be considered in conjunction with government amendment (6), which Labor will oppose. However, we do pick up some of the wording used in government amendment (6). Together, the effect of the changes would be to ensure that the disclosure of information by a small business, except with the consent of the individual concerned, would bring the small business within the scope of the act. Again, this implements the unanimous recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which was rejected by the government. The committee concluded that the small business exemption should remain but that the exemption should not be available where a business disclosed personal information other than with the consent of the individual. Accordingly, under our amendments it would be permissible for a small business to obtain and store the credit card details of the consumer without strict compliance with the national privacy principles relating to collection and storage. However, the decision to pass on those details to another organisation without the consent of the individual would bring that business out of the exemption. Under the current formulation proposed by the government, a small business will lose the benefit of the small business exemption only where it discloses information for benefit, service or advantage. Our amendments tighten this to ensure that any disclosure without consent or otherwise not in accordance with the law will bring the business outside the exemption.

talk.start.para: —The bill currently exempts small businesses from the scope of the bill unless they pose a particular risk to the privacy of individuals. An example of a risk to privacy is that a business engages in the disclosure of personal information about an individual for benefit, service or advantage. This amendment seeks to delete a paragraph and replace it with a new paragraph that will deny the small business exemption to businesses that disclose personal information about an individual other than with the consent of the individual or as required or authorised by or under legislation. The effect of this will be significantly to narrow the scope of the small business exemption. It will increase the number of small businesses that lose their exemption through normal business practices. The amendment effectively inserts into the exemption a consent requirement on the part of individuals.

speech.para: The small business exemption is a reflection of the government's core policy to minimise the compliance costs of regulatory regimes for small business. The exemption has been balanced to ensure that small businesses that pose a particular risk to the privacy of individuals will not be able to benefit from the exemption. For example, businesses that trade in personal information—that is, give or receive a benefit, service or advantage to collect or disclose personal information—will be denied the exemption. The opposition's amendment destroys that balance. It seeks to introduce a new consent based element to the exemption, which will mean in many cases that there will be no exemption at all. Alternatively, the small business will have the burden of determining whether consent has been given or not, which is in practical terms quite an unsatisfactory situation and which obviously will significantly increase compliance costs. The amendment demonstrates the opposition's desire, it seems, to turn the bill into an exercise in heavy-handed regulation, as distinct from light touch coregulation. The government opposes this amendment.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (13):

quote.para: (13) Schedule 1, item 42, page 26 (after line 4), at the end of section 7B, add:

(7) Nothing in this section permits a political representative, a contractor or a subcontractor to sell or disclose personal information collected or held by the political representative, contractor or subcontractor to any entity that does not have the benefit of this exemption.

speech.para: This relates to the exemption for political organisations and those who are members of political organisations. We accept, as the Attorney-General indicated in his reply in the second reading debate, that there are very important principles of freedom of political discussion, just as there are with respect to the exemption for media organisations and journalists important issues relating to the freedom of the press. However, again having regard to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommendations, we note that that committee recommended that a new provision be inserted to provide that clause 7C of the bill does not allow a political party or a political representative to sell or disclose personal information collected by the political party or political representative in the course of their duties to anyone not covered by the exemption.

Political parties, by virtue of their access to the Commonwealth electoral roll, are in a special position of trust with respect to private information of Australia's. We do recognise that the Commonwealth Electoral Act does prohibit the misuse of information contained on electoral rolls. However, we, like the committee, believe it is appropriate to amend the bill to provide a strict prohibition on the sale or inappropriate disclosure of personal information by a political party or a political representative.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment simply on the ground that it is unnecessary. There is an exemption in the bill for registered political parties. The bill regulates organisations, and a registered political party is not an organisation. There is also an exemption in the bill for acts and practices of members of parliament where what they are doing relates to an election, a referendum or participation in the political process. Contractors for political representatives, subcontractors and volunteers are also exempt to the extent that they are assisting a political representative to do things in relation to an election, referendum or other aspect of the political process. The amendment, and I presume the opposition, seeks to amend clause 7C, although the amendments refer to clause 7B, which is not relevant.
—The member for Barton has confirmed that it should be 7C.

—The amendment proposes to add a subsection that confirms that political representatives, contractors or subcontractors cannot sell or disclose personal information to any entity that is not covered by the exemption. As I said, the government regards that as unnecessary. The government's view—and this was outlined in the response to the House committee report's recommendation 13—is that the clause already operates to restrict sale and disclosure of personal information in this way. The exemption would not apply where a political representative or other body described in clause 7C sells and discloses personal information for any purpose unconnected with an election, referendum or participation in another aspect of the political process.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (14):

quote.para: (14) Schedule 1, item 52, page 30 (after line 6), after paragraph (b), insert:
provided that:
(c) such collection or disclosure would not exceed the reasonable expectations of the community; and
(d) the organisation which initially collected the information has complied with National Privacy Principle 1.

speech.para: This amendment deals with the circumstances in which an organisation may transfer information between related bodies corporate. Labor is concerned that the wide definition of organisations within which information can be freely disclosed is too broad. The effective extension of organisations to include `related entities' as defined in the Corporations Law makes the umbrella unreasonably large for effective protection of consumers' rights to opt out of information sharing. Labor's amendment will introduce an explicit test of how consumers expect that information provided by them to companies will be treated. This would confine the exchange of information between related bodies corporate to an extent more acceptable for consumers.

Importantly, it will be possible for businesses to manage these consumer expectations by disclosing up front at the collection stage how the company proposes to share the information between its various related entities. The amendment also implements the recommendation of the House of Representatives legal and constitutional committee that the bill be amended to ensure that disclosure between related bodies corporate should be permissible only where the collection of that information complied with the national privacy principle relating to collection.

talk.start.para: —The government regards this proposed amendment as being inconsistent with an aspect of the basic design of the legislation. The related body corporate provision, clause 13B, allows related bodies corporate to share personal information and use that information in accordance with the original purpose of collection. Proposed government amendment No. 10 provides that an organisation cannot collect personal information from an entity that is exempt from the operation of the bill without it first ensuring that national privacy principle 1, which regulates collection practices of organisations, is complied with.

speech.para: The opposition proposes to amend the clause so that related bodies corporate can share personal information with each other only if it `would not exceed the reasonable expectations of the community' and national privacy principle No. 1 has been complied with. The government regards this amendment as unnecessary. Government amendment No. 10 ensures that NPP 1 is complied with before related bodies corporate can share personal information. The national privacy principles are all about using and disclosing personal information in a way that is consistent not with the reasonable expectations of the community but with the reasonable expectations of the individual who is providing it. That is a fundamental aspect of the design of this regime. The requirement that sharing information be within the reasonable expectations of the community is also vague and, with respect, displays a lack of understanding of what the principles are about.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 15:

quote.para: (15) Schedule 1, item 54, page 33 (lines 16 to 18), omit subsection (3), substitute:

(3) National Privacy Principles 2, 6 and 11 apply in relation to personal information held by an organisation regardless of whether the organisation holds the personal information as a result of collection occurring before or after the commencement of this section, provided that in respect of personal information collected prior to the commencement of this section, an organisation is not required to comply with those Principles where such compliance would place an unreasonable administrative burden on the organisation or cause the organisation unreasonable expense.

speech.para: This bill does not provide adequate privacy protection for information held in databases which have already been compiled and which will continue to be compiled until the commencement of the bill 12 months after it passes into law. In particular, the bill specifically provides that privacy principle No. 2, which relates to the use and disclosure of personal information, will not apply to existing databases. As I said in the second reading debate, this effectively means that the horse has already bolted and the horse is carrying on it the personal information in some circumstances of millions of Australians. I referred, for instance, to reports of a giant Acxiom database carrying information of some 15 million Australians which has been obtained from a wide variety of services such as web sites and coupled with information as to when people have ordered tickets for theatrical events and the like. We say that is unacceptable and effectively means that Australians will have no protection in respect of information that has already been collected.

The Attorney in his reply to the second reading debate said that when the information is updated after the bill comes into force it will be caught within the parameters of the legislation. However, it will be a very simple procedure indeed for organisations, if they want to circumvent the provisions of the act, to simply quarantine that information which they already have. The fact that this bill will not come into operation for a period of 12 months is effectively saying to organisations, and there will be some unscrupulous organisations, `Look, the sun is shining for another 12 months. Go and make hay to build up these databases while the sun is shining, because that which you collect over the next 12 months will be quarantined from the provisions of the bill after it comes into operation.' We say that under the government's proposals it will remain possible, and indeed it will, for organisations to sell that information which they already have, even though Australian citizens unquestionably did not consent to their personal information being used for that purpose; that is, for the purpose of sale or lease by an organisation seeking to profit from their personal information relating to their personal affairs, and on occasions intimate details.

The bill also provides that privacy principle No. 6, which relates to access and correction of personal information, will not apply to existing databases. The CrimeNet example, which I gave before, is a good example in this area too. It will mean, for instance, that if CrimeNet is displaying inaccurate information about a citizen, then aside from perhaps defamation laws that citizen will not have the right to access and insist on correction of the information contained on databases such as that. Accordingly, under the government's proposal, any Australian citizens who suffer damage as a result of inaccurate information currently held on them will be unable to correct that information. Inaccurate information held on a database regarding somebody's financial affairs could significantly impede that person's ability to rent a property, as we have discussed, or even for business to obtain finance. The treatment of existing data under the bill is fundamentally unsatisfactory. Our amendment will prevent the inappropriate use and disclosure of existing information by applying those privacy principles Nos 2 and 6, although we do recognise that, if it would involve inappropriate or unacceptable administrative procedures and hence expense to retrieve information already held, that case can be made out by organisations. It is not our intention to cause unreasonable administrative expense in respect of existing databases, but the reality is that much of it is already held in electronic form and is readily accessible, and there is no reason why that sort of material could not be brought within the parameters of the legislation.

talk.start.para: —The member for Barton has got form on this issue. He is a recidivist offender. On 12 April, when I introduced the legislation, the member for Barton issued a news release claiming that the bill would not apply to existing databases at all. That was completely wrong. Pre-existing databases would not escape regulation. He is not quite committing the same offence today, but the views he has just expressed fail to take into account the impact of what he seeks to do. The bill currently regulates use and disclosure of personal information collected after the commencement date. NPP2 regulates use and disclosure. Similarly, the right to access your own personal information and to correct it if it is wrong, NPP6, applies only to personal information collected after the commencement date. There are very good reasons for this. The opposition's proposal is to amend clause 16C, which relates to the application of the NPPs, so that NPPs 2 and 6 apply to existing data. In addition, the opposition propose that a new NPP they have made up which relates to children's personal information apply to personal information held by organisations at the time the legislation commences.

speech.para: From what I have said, Madam Deputy Speaker, you will not be surprised when I indicate that the government opposes the amendment. NPP2, regulating use and disclosure, makes a distinction between the primary purpose of collection and the secondary purpose of collection. These concepts are linked to the procedures contained in NPP1. To require compliance with NPP2 without first having complied with NPP1 is problematic. It would create unnecessary and unjustified compliance costs for organisations. Organisations would be faced with similarly unjustified compliance costs in the case of the application of NPP6 to existing data. The government is not prepared to accept NPP11, a new principle made up out of the blue by the opposition, at this stage.

It must be remembered—and the member for Barton has foreshadowed that I would make this point—that after the bill takes effect organisations such as Acxiom that hold existing databases of personal information will need to comply with all aspects of the legislation when they update that information, including those relating to collection, access, use and disclosure. In the information industry, the currency of personal information is crucial. This means that over time the complete set of principles will come to apply to that updated information. Another practical point that the member for Barton overlooks is that not all information is contained on databases online. Much information is contained in hard copy in archives, and to impose obligations on organisations that have records going back many years is to introduce regulatory requirements that meet no real threat in relation to privacy at all.

talk.start.para: —Briefly responding to a couple of those points, I note that the Attorney-General said that I had form on this matter. If my form is referring to provisions of the bill, in particular to proposed section 16C(3), I am guilty. For the record, it says this:

quote.para: National Privacy Principles 2 and 6 apply only in relation to personal information collected after the commencement of this section.

speech.para: But my criticism of the Attorney has been that the government has actually misled Australians into thinking that information which is already obtained about them is subject to protection under this bill. It is not, other than in respect of the mode in which that material is to be held after the bill comes into operation and other than in respect of circumstances in which that material might be updated if the organisation decides not to quarantine their existing databases of the information they already hold in respect of Australians.

The Attorney's comment that I overlooked the fact that not all information will be held in electronic form is, with respect, unreasonable. I sought to make that point during my previous contribution on this amendment. In particular, the wording which we have proposed is that an organisation is not required to comply with those principles `where such compliance would place an unreasonable administrative burden on the organisation or cause the organisation unreasonable expense'. That is intended to cover the situation where the material is held in hard copy—we recognise that. There will be a lot of information held in hard copy in archive boxes stored away in storage facilities and in those circumstances it would present an unreasonable burden or expense. But, equally, if information is in that form, it is less liable to exploitation and hence on our amendments would be excluded from the provisions of the bill.

talk.start.para: —I will briefly respond to that. If the legislation comes into effect in its proposed form, it will oblige private organisations that hold existing databases of personal information to take reasonable steps to ensure that the data is accurate, complete and securely held. The organisation will be required to be open to consumers about what information it already holds and how it collects, holds and proposes to use or disclose such information. So pre-existing databases do not escape regulation, and in fact the retrospective aspects of the bill mirror the provisions that applied to the public sector at the time that the public sector provisions of the Privacy Act 1998 were introduced by Labor.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: (16) Schedule 1, item 58, page 37 (after line 31), after paragraph (l), insert:
; and

(m) the code requires the adjudicator to maintain a summary of each complaint resolved with or without a determination, finding, declaration, order or direction identifying the nature of the complaint, the code provisions applied in resolving it, the nature of the settlement, and any issues of law which were raised in the complaint; and
(n) the code requires the adjudicator to provide a copy of these summaries to the Commissioner at least annually.

speech.para: The bill will effectively allow industry bodies to contract out of the privacy protection system by developing self-regulatory codes. It must be acknowledged that the Privacy Commissioner is entrusted with the responsibility of approving those codes, and no doubt will do so in good faith. But, once that code has been approved, the industry will then be wholly responsible for applying its interpretation of the code to all complaints which fall within its scope. The Privacy Commissioner has no power to audit compliance with the code: for instance, to enter premises and inspect documents or to interview witnesses. The Privacy Commissioner has no powers to review decisions made under the code. The Privacy Commissioner has no powers to direct code adjudicators on how they should go about the task of resolving complaints made under the code.

One of the few things that the Privacy Commissioner can do is read the annual report prepared by each industry code adjudicator and, based on the very limited information which is required to be provided, make a decision whether or not to continue to approve the industry code. This amendment boosts the requirements necessary for the approval of an industry specific code to provide additional information to the Privacy Commissioner on the operation of the code. In addition to the requirements which are currently reflected in the bill, Labor's amendments will add the following: `the code requires the adjudicator to maintain a summary of each complaint resolved' with or without determination and also that `the code requires the adjudicator to provide a copy' of these summaries to the commissioner at least annually. This will provide the commissioner with valuable additional information upon which to decide whether or not an industry code is meeting the minimum requirements to maintain its approval as an alternative to the standard framework.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment and believes it would introduce quite unnecessary bureaucratic requirements that would be expensive to implement and of little point. The amendment would impose additional burdens on organisations. It is inconsistent with the government's commitment to provide a light touch coregulatory approach to privacy protection, although I have to admit that it is consistent with the heavy-handed approach that the opposition seems to be taking. It should be up to individual code adjudicators to decide how complaints will be resolved and whether a precedent or similar system is set up. Imposing these requirements in the legislation will not encourage the take-up of codes by industry bodies, which will then rely on the national privacy principles instead. Of course, that would result in everybody being subject to the Privacy Commissioner's adjudication rather than individual code adjudicators.

speech.para: The Privacy Commissioner has a power to make guidelines relating to the making and handling of complaints under approved privacy codes in the new section 18BF. Whether he recommends an annual complaints summary will be a decision for him in administering the code system, and he will be in the best position to make that judgment. He will know how many code adjudicators there are, what industry sectors of individual enterprises they cover and how well they are operating. It is a matter which should be left for the decision of the Privacy Commissioner.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments (17), (18), (19) and (25):

quote.para: (17) Schedule 1, item 58, page 40 (after line 11), after section 18BG, insert:

para.inline: 18BH Review of operation of approved privacy codes

quote.para: (1) The Commissioner may, if in his or her view the circumstances so warrant,
(a) following receipt of a report referred to in 18BB(3)(i); or
(b) following receipt of the summaries referred to in 18BB(3)(n); or
(c) on his or her own motion
conduct a review of the operation of an approved privacy code.
(2) The circumstances under subsection (1) may include:
(a) the number, nature and outcome of complaints made to an adjudicator; and
(b) the code provisions applied in resolving complaints; and
(c) information received by the Commissioner that indicates that obligations under the code may not have been met by an organisation bound by the code.
(3) In undertaking a review under this subsection, the Commissioner may:
(a) review the complaints process;
(b) inspect the records of the adjudicator;
(c) review the results of complaints;
(d) interview the adjudicator.

para.inline: 18BI Review of decisions under an approved privacy code

quote.para: A person who is aggrieved by a decision made by an adjudicator under an approved privacy code may apply to the Commissioner for a review of the decision.

para.inline: 18 BJ Powers of the Commissioner in respect of applications for review

quote.para: On an application for a review under section 18BI, the Commissioner may:
(a) make a determination setting aside a decision under the privacy code, or a part of a decision, with effect from the date of the determination;
(b) exercise all the powers conferred on the Commissioner to investigate complaints made directly to the Commissioner;
(c) make a fresh determination in accordance with section 52.
(18) Schedule 1, item 59, page 40 (after line 25), after subparagraph (ac), insert:
(ad) to review the operation of privacy codes under section 18BH;
(ae) to review decisions that an adjudicator may make under an approved privacy code under section 18BI, to set aside those decisions and to make fresh determinations.
(19) Schedule 1, item 55, page 54 (after line 12) after section 55B, insert:

para.inline: 55C Privacy Commissioner may issue Breach Notice

quote.para: (1) The Commissioner may issue a Breach Notice to an organisation which, in the opinion of the Privacy Commissioner, has not complied with a determination issued under section 52.
(2) The Commissioner must provide the organisation with an opportunity to be heard prior to the issue of the Breach Notice.
(3) The Breach Notice must specify;
(a) the nature of the breach;
(b) the steps which the organisation must take to rectify the breach; and
(c) a reasonable time (no greater than 12 months) in which the organisation must rectify the breach.
(1) An organisation which does not comply with a Breach Notice issued by the Commissioner within the time specified in the Breach Notice is guilty of an offence.
(2) A penalty under this section may be sued for and recovered by:
(a) the Privacy Commissioner; or
(b) a person that is affected by the serious privacy breach.
(3) A proceeding under this section shall be commenced not latter than 6 years after the commission of the breach.
(25) Schedule 2, items 1 and 2, page 77 (lines 4 to 11), omit the items.

speech.para: These amendments substantially boost the powers of the Privacy Commissioner. Labor believes that the key role of the Privacy Commissioner in supervising the developing private sector privacy jurisdiction has been undersold. The Privacy Commissioner should exercise a supervisory role over industry complaint bodies set up to administer the approved industry codes. If this does not occur, there is a risk that the codes will be applied differently across different industry sectors. Indeed, it is important to note that there will be many instances of overlapping codes, for instance, affecting banks which may be the subject of one industry code yet may be participating in Internet activity which is regulated by another code. So the danger of having different interpretations is very real. If that occurs, it will diminish the overall confidence that Australians have, and indeed those wishing to trade with Australia have, in the protection of privacy within our shores.

The Privacy Commissioner should also have appropriate powers of audit and inspection, as I have indicated, to properly monitor the operation of the industry codes. One of the concerns raised by industry groups was that they did not wish to see decisions of industry codes reviewable under the administrative decisions judicial review mechanism currently provided for in the bill. Industry code processes operate in an informal fashion, which the Attorney-General has indicated and with which we agree. The burden of being subject to review, which concentrates on matters of form and procedure rather than substance and merit, was identified as undesirable. For this reason, our amendments would remove the right of administrative decisions judicial review from decisions of industry code adjudicators and, instead, provide the Privacy Commissioner with a supervisory jurisdiction over the code adjudicators. Where a person is unsatisfied with a decision obtained from an industry code adjudicator under an industry code, there will be an automatic right of appeal to the Privacy Commissioner, who will be able to set aside the decision of the adjudicator and make a fresh decision. As it is the experience of the current industry adjudicators that most complaints are resolved satisfactorily, we believe it is unlikely to result in a flood of claims or appeals to the Privacy Commissioner from unsatisfied applicants. It will also address the concerns that having multiple adjudicators applying multiple codes will lead to different interpretations being placed on similar provisions.

Finally, these amendments establish the offence of serious privacy breach. We say that you have to be realistic. There will always be unscrupulous operators who will attempt to exploit personal information for profit, regardless of the applying law. The bill provides no real deterrent for those companies which break the rules again and again. Accordingly, there is a real risk that companies which ruthlessly exploit personal information for profit will go unpunished. As is the case in so many areas, it is often the actions of a few that affect the reputations of many.

Our amendments will create an offence of serious privacy breach to ensure that business takes seriously their privacy obligations. The offence will be triggered only in circumstances in which the usual civil remedy offered by the Privacy Commissioner and enforceable by the Federal Court is not sufficient to address the problem. For instance, I gave the example that disclosing the personal details of someone's subscription to a surfing magazine, or whatever it might be, may not itself give rise to much compensation, but the invasion of that publisher's records might be so intense as to justify a penalty. The penalty proceedings which we have proposed will be available only after the Privacy Commissioner has issued to the noncomplying company a breach notice which specifies the nature of the noncompliance, provides the offending company with a warning of this course of action and offers the company an opportunity to make appropriate rectification and restorative measures. So it is very much a penalty of last resort but one which we say must be there to give some force and effect that this privacy regime is fair dinkum.

talk.start.para: —The amendments moved by the opposition highlight the difference of approach between the government and the opposition. The government seeks to emphasise, as businesses recognise, that good privacy is good business. The opposition seeks to treat them as criminals. So, instead of a light touch coregulatory approach, we have a punitive and bureaucratic approach on the part of the opposition.

speech.para: Amendment (17) proposes to significantly erode the coregulatory approach in the bill by providing that the Privacy Commissioner be able to conduct a review of the operation of an approved privacy code, including a review of the complaints process and inspection of the records of the code adjudicator, to review decisions made by a code adjudicator and to make determinations replacing those of an adjudicator after reviewing his or her decision. Amendment (18) is merely a consequence of amendment (17). It adds to the list of the Privacy Commissioner's functions.

Amendment (19) moved by the opposition proposes to provide the Privacy Commissioner with an additional power to issue a breach notice where an organisation fails to comply with a determination issued by the Privacy Commissioner. If an organisation fails to comply with a breach notice within the time specified in the notice, the provision provides for a penalty of 500 penalty units.

Amendment (25) relates to the deletion of an avenue of review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Currently, the bill provides for the judicial review of decisions made by code adjudicators under an approved privacy code. It does this by amending the definition of `enactment' in that act so that a decision made by an adjudicator under an approved privacy code is one made under an enactment and is therefore reviewable under the act. The opposition proposes to delete the mechanism that allows for judicial review of decisions made by code adjudicators.

The government naturally opposes all of these amendments. As I have said, they are inconsistent with a coregulatory approach and provide a distinct disincentive to develop privacy codes. Amendment (17) adds an extra level of review in the case where a code adjudicator has made a decision under an approved privacy code. The Privacy Commissioner is not resourced to undertake audits of private sector organisations and to review decisions made by code adjudicators. Not accepting amendment (17) has the consequence that we do not accept amendment (18). The provisions in amendment (19) are vague and are possibly inconsistent with the Commonwealth's criminal law policy. It is not altogether clear whether noncompliance with a breach notice is intended to be a civil or criminal matter. The amendment sets out provisions for recovery by the Privacy Commissioner or the person affected by the privacy breach, yet the compensation for breach is expressed in terms of penalty units. In addition, there may be constitutional problems with issuing a breach notice, as the process appears to be based on the Privacy Commissioner exercising judicial power.

The Privacy Commissioner has operated very effectively under the public sector privacy scheme without using the threat of a breach notice. In the annual reports of the Privacy Commissioner going right back to 1989, I am not aware of any reference to any litigation in respect of a privacy complaint. All privacy complaints that have been dealt with seem to have been either withdrawn or satisfactorily dealt with by conciliation. The Privacy Commissioner under the legislation will have powers to make declarations, to fix compensation or even to fix damages where there has been a loss as a result of the breach of a principle, and those damages can include compensation for injury to feelings. In the context of the history of the public sector regime, there is no empirical evidence suggesting that there is a need of any sort for anything more punitive than that which is in the public sector regime. The government has followed the public sector regime in the design of this regime to apply to the private sector.

The government does not accept that the Privacy Commissioner has a role in reviewing decisions made by code adjudicators. Potentially this may involve a considerable amount of work. (Extension of time granted) The Privacy Commissioner is not resourced to undertake the function of reviewing the code adjudicators. We do not know to what extent resources would be necessary. Potentially, no resources would be required if the public sector history is repeated. But, in any event, it downgrades the role of a code adjudicator in a way that is inappropriate. Code adjudicators should do the job that they are given to do under the code, and they should not be subject to someone watching over their shoulder. It is a matter between the complainant and the organisation; and, if either is dissatisfied, there is the alternative of a judicial review. To introduce a second tier of review is to introduce unnecessary expense and to potentially delay matters; it is bureaucracy and red tape rather than a simple solution.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments (20) to (23):

quote.para: (20) Schedule 1, item 139, page 71 (line 23), after “individual,”, insert “other than health information,”.
(21) Schedule 1, item 139, page 71 (lines 26 to 30), omit paragraphs (a) and (b), substitute:
(a) providing access would pose a serious and imminent threat to the life or health of any individual; or
(22) Schedule 1, item 139, page 72 (after line 29), after subclause 6.1, insert:

6.1A If an organisation holds health information about an individual, subject to subclauses 6.1B and 6.1C, it must provide the individual with access to the information on request by the individual, except to the extent that:
(a) the provision of the information would constitute a significant risk to the life or health of
(i) the individual; or
(ii) any other person; or
(b) the provision of the information would contravene
(i) a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory;
(ii) an order of a court of competent jurisdiction; or

(c) the information consists of or includes material or information concerning an individual given in confidence to the person who was responsible for receiving or recording the information, by a person other than
(i) the individual;
(ii) a guardian of the individual; or
(iii) a health service provider in the course of, or otherwise in relation to, the provider's treatment of the individual,
and, in addition, health information may not be disclosed if

(d) the individual notifies the person responsible for the information to the effect that the individual does not wish the information to be disclosed and the person responsible for the information marks the information or record accordingly; or
(e) the individual
(i) becomes a legally incompetent person; or
(ii) dies.
6.1B Health information about an individual that contains factual matter is subject to the provisions of subclause 6.1A regardless of when the information was collected.

6.1C Health information about an individual that contains matters of opinion is subject to the provisions of subclause 6.1A if the information was collected on or after the date of commencement of this Act.
(23) Schedule 1, item 139, page 76 (lines 28 to 31), omit subclause 10.4, substitute:

10.4 If an organisation collects health information about an individual in accordance with subclause 10.3, the organisation must permanently de-identify the information before the organisation discloses it unless it is impractical to do so.

speech.para: These amendments implement the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in relation to the treatment in the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000 of health information. In moving these amendments, I draw attention to the fact that the regime for privacy in the private sector being put forward in this bill is woefully inadequate to protect the personal information files held in the electronic age. The information recorded about a person in a doctor's surgery or hospital is far more private than that gathered in a supermarket or a bank, yet the bill does little to recognise the special character of health information. Because health crosses over the public-private divide, it is clear that more work needs to be done to ensure that privacy protection is adequate.

With respect to the Attorney-General's comments, there is a fundamental difference between the bill and the operation of privacy legislation to date, which has been primarily in the context of the public sector—albeit also in the context of credit. The public sector, of course, is not driven by a profit motive. In the private sector, I think we are going to be looking at a clash when trying to develop this culture of privacy in the context of the drive of the profit motive, which is necessarily part of the private commercial world.

Having regard to that difference, particularly in the area of this very sensitive health information, the House committee clearly regretted its inability to properly address the area because of the time available. However, it did make recommendations in respect of access to medical records. The committee recommended that the bill be amended to include access standards for medical records, as set out in the ACT Health Records (Privacy and Access) Act 1997, that is, a patient should have a right of access to his or her medical records unless one of three things is involved, the first being that the provision of the information would constitute a significant risk to the life or health of any person; the second, that the provision of the information would contravene a law of the Commonwealth, or a state or territory, or an order of a court of competent jurisdiction; or, thirdly, the record is subject to an obligation of confidentiality. We say that those principles are really minimalist and should appropriately be included in the provisions of this bill.

talk.start.para: —Access to records containing personal information or health information is currently addressed by NPP6. Opposition amendment (20) seeks to amend NPP6 to facilitate amendment (22), which would separate the provisions dealing with access to health records from the general access provisions. Opposition amendment (21) is a consequential amendment arising out of the first two. Opposition amendment (22) separates the provisions dealing with access to health records from the general access provisions. It inserts new subprinciples into NPP6 dealing specifically with access to health information. The amendment limits the ability of record holders to legitimately deny access to an individual's health information. In addition, proposed NPPs 6.1B and 6.1C provide that an individual may access health information of a factual nature, regardless of when the information was collected, but may only access health information containing matters of opinion if the information was collected on or after the date of commencement of the bill. NPP10.4 currently provides that organisations that collect health information under NPP10.3 must take reasonable steps to permanently de-identify the information before it is disclosed. Opposition amendment (23) removes the qualification in NPP10.4 that an organisation must take reasonable steps to permanently de-identify certain health information before disclosing it and inserts the qualification, `Unless it is impracticable to do so.'

speech.para: The government opposes the amendments. The present treatment of access to health records in NPP6 is balanced and appropriate, and the opposition's amendments are unnecessary. I mention to the member for Barton that, in the preparation of the legislation, the ACT legislation was carefully examined. It was regarded as incompatible with the design of the government's regime and, on that basis, to the extent that it was inconsistent, it was not adopted. The opposition's amendments ignore the balance that the government has worked hard to reach in this area, following very extensive consultations with stakeholders. This includes extensive consultations by the Privacy Commissioner last year with the health sector, undertaken at the government's request. The provisions put forward by the opposition are simply not sufficient to take into account all of the complex issues that arise in relation to access to health records.

The opposition's proposed new NPPs 6.1B and 6.1C broadly follow what has been proposed in recent draft Victorian legislation. The application of the bill to information collected prior to the commencement of the bill is set uniformly in relation to all personal information. There is no reason why the bill's application should be changed just in relation to health information. The amendment to NPP10.4 does not appear to have any substance. It simply changes one set of words that qualify the obligation to permanently de-identify certain health information with another. We are not concerned with semantics in this debate. The government opposes the amendments.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —Finally, I move opposition amendment (24):

quote.para: (24) Schedule 1, after 139, page 76 (after line 35) at the end of the Schedule, add:
11.1 An organisation which:
(a) operates a commercial service which is directed at children; or
(b) operates a commercial service directed at a general audience but for which there is a reasonable expectation that personal information will be collected from children
must:
(c) provide parents with notice of the information collection practices of the organisation;
(d) obtain parental consent before collecting, using or disclosing personal information about a child, which consent may be revoked by a parent at any time;
(e) obtain new consent from parents when the information collection practices of the organisation change in a material way;
(f) allow parents to access and correct personal information collected from their children;
(g) delete information collected from children at the request of parents;
(h) not require a child to provide more information than is reasonably necessary to participate in the service offered by the organisation; and
(i) ensure that personal information collected from children is maintained with confidentiality, security and integrity.
11.2 In this clause:
child means a person aged 13 or under.

speech.para: This bill contains no special treatment for information collected from children. It must be acknowledged that information privacy principle No. 2 and information privacy principle No. 6 do touch on that area. But, in so far as consent is involved in information privacy principle 2, the concept of obtaining informed consent from a child is deficient. Also, information privacy principle 6—that is the one providing for access and correction to information—is obviously short insofar as it does not provide access and correction to information obtained from third parties; namely, a parent seeking to obtain access and correction to information obtained from one of their children.

I must say that I was particularly attracted to these provisions, which are essentially based on what has occurred in the United States, after sitting at my home computer and receiving email messages offering to sell me all kinds of pop band posters, music and memorabilia, an interest in which, clearly, my 13- and 14-year-old daughters had disclosed in terms of their interests and some other personal information. But that situation is not uncommon. Research by the US Federal Trade Commission revealed that 89 per cent of 212 commercial childrens web sites collected personal information from children, but only 24 per cent posted privacy policies and only one per cent required parental consent for the collection or disclosure of that information. So we believe that something needs to be done in Australia to put parents back in charge of their children's personal information. Families need to be given the tools to control who collects personal information from their children, to dictate how that information is used and, most importantly, to determine whether it is shared with third parties. The American approach is receiving considerable support, I might add, from reputable Internet service providers, who are helping to publicise the rules and to provide a specific link back to the Federal Trade Commission's `Kidz Privacy' page.

Australian families do not have these important safeguards, but our amendments to the core of the bill—the privacy principles—would, we believe, go some way to achieving that. Our amendments will require the operators of commercial web sites and online services directed at children to comply with special and specific principles including: providing parents with notice of their information collection practices; obtaining parental consent before collecting, using or disclosing personal information about a child, with limited exceptions; obtaining consent from parents when information practices change in a material way; allowing parents to review personal information collected from their children; allowing parents to revoke their consent; deleting information collected from their children at the parents' request; not requiring a child to provide more information than is reasonably necessary to participate in a particular activity; and maintaining the confidentiality, security and integrity of information collected from children. In this age when, increasingly, the recreational, research and entertainment activities of families are intimately involved with the Internet, and when children are increasingly using it for entertainment and research, these special provisions applying to children are necessary and appropriate.

talk.start.para: —I do not think anybody in this House would deny that children are in need of special protection when they venture out into the community, whether they do it physically, online or otherwise. But because there is a need for protection of children does not mean to say that one can respond with what seems like a good idea without proper analysis and without consultation with those affected. That is what it seems the opposition is minded to do.

speech.para: This issue has been addressed by legislation in the United States, and it is also dealt with in the e-commerce best practices guidelines recently released by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, the Hon. Joe Hockey. As an NPP, it comes completely out of the blue. The opposition did not provide the government with any indication it was considering such a principle, and in our view it is totally unrealistic to introduce such a wide-sweeping new policy like this without giving adequate time for community consultation or consideration by the government.

The bill is the result of extensive community consultation that commenced in November 1996. We had notice yesterday, I think it was, that this amendment was going to be moved. It obviously has dramatic consequences. In its terms, it is inconsistent with the design of the regime under the bill. As a proposed NPP, it is technology specific, which is inconsistent with the rest of the bill and inconsistent with the sentiment expressed by the member for Barton earlier in this debate when he expressed agreement with the government's policy in that respect. The regime we put forward is designed to be technology neutral and therefore able to stand the test of time and changing technologies. As I have said, the coverage of the national privacy principles was the result of very long and extensive consultation.

A separate principle relating to children has not been under consideration at any stage and including it now, without adequate consultation and support, is just unacceptable. We could not possibly accept an amendment in the terms put forward without a proper analysis of its consequences. We are willing to engage in discussion with the opposition as to the effect of what is proposed, but we are not prepared to accept an amendment at this point.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill. I propose to move government amendments in the following order: amendments (1) to (5) and amendment (7) together; amendments (6), (8) and (9) separately, then amendments (10) to (23) together. The government has closely considered the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and has proposed a number of amendments to the bill in response to the committee's recommendations. Changes have also been made to the bill as a result of further consultations with stakeholders. These proposed amendments were released in early September, consistently with the consultative approach that the government has adopted for this bill. The government proposes a total of 23 amendments. I seek leave to move government amendments (1) to (5) and amendment (7) together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:
