Number of days in the whole financial year----------------------------------------------- Number of days in the part

speech.para: In relation to amendment (1), acting on suggestions made by the House of Representatives committee in its report on the bill, the government has reconsidered its approach to the calculation of annual turnover. While the government concluded that it is appropriate to use a turnover threshold in defining the extent of the small business exemption, it accepts that the definition of annual turnover in the bill as introduced could have unintended consequences for businesses that are input taxed. The government is proposing to remove the definition of annual turnover in the bill and to insert a new definition. Amendment (1), combined with amendment (7), inserts this new definition. The new definition of annual turnover will simplify the task of determining whether a business is a small business for purposes of the exemption.

In relation to amendment (2), item 18 of the bill inserted a definition of journalism in subsection 6(1) of the act. Government amendment (2) proposes to omit this definition so that the ordinary meaning of the word `journalism' will apply. The ordinary meaning is relevant in determining the scope of the exemption for acts and practices done or engaged in by a media organisation in the course of journalism.

The definition of journalism the government proposes to omit would have covered activities beyond the commonly understood activities of journalism. The amendment is intended to clarify the scope of the exemption, narrowing it to activities of mainstream media organisations and thereby making it more difficult for some online organisations not involved in mainstream media activities to take advantage of the exemption. The term `journalism' is intended to apply in a technology neutral way. This is consistent with the approach in the bill as a whole. The term is also intended to cover the dissemination of material to the public.

Government amendment (3) inserts a new definition in the bill as a consequence of proposed government amendments (16), (19), (21) and (22), which concern NPP7. That principle places limits on the adoption, use and disclosure of Commonwealth government identifiers. The amendment inserts a definition of `principal executive' into subsection 6(1), which is designed to have the same meaning as it has in section 37 of the act.

Government amendment (4) proposes to omit subsections 6D(1) and 6D(2) of the bill, substituting a new meaning of the term `small business' in the bill. That new definition provides that a business is a small business during a financial year if its annual turnover for the previous financial year was $3 million or less. The amendment also provides that a business which was not carried on in a previous financial year is a small business only if its annual turnover for the current year is $3 million or less. The method by which annual turnover is calculated for a previous year or projected for a current year is dealt with in proposed government amendment (7). Any criteria for determining a threshold raises difficulties of how to deal with entities that are on the edge and which sometimes fall under and sometimes go over the threshold. There is also the difficulty of how to assess the business that is just starting up in relation to the threshold criteria. The government seeks to clarify these issues through amendments (5) and (7).

The bill outlines the circumstances in which a small business is prevented from being defined as a small business operator and therefore unable to rely on the exemption in the bill for small business operators. The practical effect of government amendment (5) is that an entity will not be a small business operator if it carries on a business that has had an annual turnover of more than $3 million in a previous financial year. The reference to a financial year that has ended means that a new small business that is required to project its annual turnover will not be denied the status of a small business operator only because its projected annual turnover exceeds $3 million. As already indicated, government amendment (5) together with amendment (7) simplify the application of the small business exemption. Government amendment (7) inserts a new clause 6DA into the bill, which defines the annual turnover of a business for a financial year as the total of the proceeds of sales of goods and/or services, commission income, repair and service income, rent, leasing and hiring income, government bounties and subsidies, interest, royalties and dividends and other operating income earned in the year in the course of business. The note to the new provision clarifies that in general a business's annual turnover will equate to the total of the instalment income the business notifies to the Commissioner for Taxation on its business activity statements over the course of the financial year. It is intended that in most cases a business will be able to use the calculations on its BAS to demonstrate its annual turnover for the purpose of the bill. (Extension of time granted) The proposed amendment also sets out a formula to project the annual turnover of a business that has been carried on for only part of a financial year.

talk.start.para: —The opposition agrees to government amendments (1) to (5) and amendment (7) inclusive.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move government amendment (6):

quote.para: (6) Schedule 1, item 36, page 19 (after line 8), at the end of section 6D, add:

para.inline: Disclosure compelled or made with consent

quote.para: (7) Paragraph (4)(c) does not prevent an individual, body corporate, partnership, unincorporated association or trust from being a small business operator only because he, she or it discloses personal information about another individual:
(a) with the consent of the other individual; or
(b) as required or authorised by or under legislation.

para.inline: Collection with consent or under legislation

quote.para: (8) Paragraph (4)(d) does not prevent an individual, body corporate, partnership, unincorporated association or trust from being a small business operator only because he, she or it:
(a) collects personal information about another individual from someone else:
(i) with the consent of the other individual; or
(ii) as required or authorised by or under legislation; and
(b) provides a benefit, service or advantage to be allowed to collect the information.
(9) Despite subsection (3), a body corporate is not a small business operator if it is related to a body corporate that carries on a business that is not a small business.

speech.para: This amendment in effect clarifies that a small business that collects or discloses personal information with the consent of the individual or is required or authorised by legislation will not be denied the status of a small business operator and therefore can retain the benefit of the exemption for small business. This amendment also clarifies that a small business is not exempt if it is related to a large business. It means that a small business that is part of a corporate group, which includes a large business, will not be able to take advantage of the small business exemption. This amendment is consistent with the general amendment to the related body corporate provision.

I understand the opposition does not oppose all the changes contained in the government's amendment, but does oppose proposed new subclause 6D7, which inserts a new subclause affecting paragraph 6D4(c) of the bill. The proposed new subclause clarifies that a small business operator will not be denied the benefit of the exemption for small business operators only because the business disclosed its personal information about an individual with the consent of the individual or as required or authorised by or under legislation. One of the major considerations reflected in privacy principles around the world, including in this bill, is that an individual should be informed about how organisations use and disclose the personal information that is provided to them. Where an organisation acts in a manner that is consistent with an individual's expectations, which would be the case where consent is obtained, then the organisation is respecting the privacy interests of the individual. The government has proposed that a small business operator who discloses personal information for a benefit, service or advantage should not be able to have the benefit of the small business exemption. However, where the small business operator does so with the consent of the individual concerned, it is acting within that individual's expectations and consistently with good privacy practice. In such a case, the small business operator ought not to lose the benefit of the exemption in the clause for small business operators.

The opposition disagrees. It considers that the fact that the individual consents to the disclosure of their information should not make a difference. The opposition would also deny a small business operator the benefit of the exemption if it is required or authorised by legislation to disclose the personal information. Let us look at how this might work in practice. The government requires the small business operator to disclose personal information about a trainee for whom the government is paying some grant monies. The government would effectively be saying, `The government's legislation requires you to hand over this personal information, but if you do so you will no longer be able to benefit from the government's exemption in the Privacy Act for small business operators.' This would be absurd result. The government, therefore, cannot support the opposition's proposed amendment. To do so would effectively penalise small business operators who are not doing anything wrong. The government proposed its amendment for a good reason. That reason still stands.

talk.start.para: —As the Attorney-General indicated, the opposition opposes proposed subsections 6D(7) of this particular amendment proposed by the government. Our opposition is in the context of the amendment No. 10 which we previously moved. That amendment incorporates some of the wording of government amendment (6). Together, the effect of these two changes would be to ensure that the disclosure of information by a small business except with the consent of the individual concerned would bring the small business within the scope of the act. Again, this implements a unanimous recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which was rejected by the government. The committee concluded that the small business exemption should remain but that the exemption should not be available where a business disclosed personal information other than with the consent of the individual. Accordingly, under our amendments it would be permissible for a small business to obtain and store the credit card details of a customer, for instance, without strict compliance with the national privacy principles relating to collection and storage. However, the decision to pass on those details to another organisation without the consent of the individual would bring that business out of the exemption. We say that is appropriate even if the purpose of transferring that private information was not for the purpose of profit or material advantage. Under the current formulation contained in the bill, a small business will only lose the benefit of the small business exemption where it does so, as I indicated, for a service or advantage. Even in circumstances other than that, it could still be offensive to an individual to have their private information relayed to a third party, so our amendments tighten this to ensure that any disclosure without consent or otherwise not in accordance with the law will bring the business outside the exemption. I move:

quote.para: (1) Government amendment (6), proposed subsection 6D(7), to be opposed.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.
Original amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: (8) Schedule 1, item 36, page 20 (after line 10), after section 6E, insert:

para.inline: Small business operators choosing to be treated as organisations

quote.para: (1) This Act (except section 16D) applies in relation to a small business operator as if the operator were an organisation while a choice by the operator to be treated as an organisation is registered under this section.
(2) A small business operator may make a choice in writing given to the Commissioner to be treated as an organisation.

speech.para: Note: A small business operator may revoke such a choice by writing given to the Commissioner. See subsection 33(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

quote.para: (3) If the Commissioner is satisfied that a small business operator has made the choice to be treated as an organisation, the Commissioner must enter in a register of operators who have made such a choice:
(a) the name or names under which the operator carries on business; and
(b) the operator's ABN, if the operator has one under the A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Act 1999.
(4) If a small business operator revokes a choice to be treated as an organisation, the Commissioner must remove from the register the material relating to the operator.
(5) The Commissioner may decide the form of the register and how it is to be kept.

(6) The Commissioner must make the register available to the public in the way that the Commissioner determines. However, the Commissioner must not make available to the public in the register information other than that described in subsection (3).

speech.para: The government accepts the recommendation of the House of Representatives committee that a mechanism ought to be included in the bill to allow otherwise exempt small businesses, if they choose to opt in to the coverage of the bill and be subject to the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner or an approved code adjudicator, to do that. This is implemented through government amendment (8), which will enable small businesses to opt in and opt out of coverage of the privacy scheme. Amendment (8) inserts a new clause 6EA, which allows a small business operator to elect to be treated as if it were an organisation and subject to the provisions of the bill. Such a choice must be made in writing and given to the Privacy Commissioner. The amendment also provides that if the Privacy Commissioner is satisfied that a small business operator has made a choice to opt into the privacy scheme in the bill, it must enter the name or name under which the operator carries on business and the operator's Australian Business Number, if it has one, in a register. The small business operator would then be treated as if it were an organisation covered by the bill from the date of registration.

The opposition, I understand, opposes two aspects of the government's proposed amendment, based on its view that once a small business operator has opted into the coverage of the legislation it ought not to be able to revoke this choice by subsequently opting out. I do not understand what the opposition's problem is. The business has voluntarily elected to be covered; the government has not required it to comply. If there were no facility to revoke a voluntary choice to opt in, there would be other avenues open to a business that was serious about revoking this choice. For example, the business could wind up and recommence the next day in another guise or under another name. The government considers that the better approach is to respect that the small business operator has voluntarily chosen to bring itself within the legislation and can, if it so chooses, change its mind and revoke that choice. The government acknowledges that providing this option creates some issues regarding the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner and has proposed an amendment to preserve the jurisdiction of the commissioner as appropriate. The government also acknowledges that the opt out facility is open to abuse. Were such abuse to come to the government's attention, the option is always open to the government to use its prescribing power to bring a particular small business operator within the coverage of the legislation. On that basis, the opposition's amendments to the government's amendments are opposed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

quote.para: (2) Government amendment (8), proposed subsection 6EA(2), omit the Note.
(3) Government amendment (8), omit proposed subsection 6EA(4), substitute:
(4) A small business operator may not revoke a choice to be treated as an organisation.

speech.para: Again, Labor supports the recommendation contained in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report that an opt-in mechanism for small business be included in the bill. We note that the government has picked that up. This will allow those small businesses which choose to opt in to market themselves as complying with national privacy principles, and we would certainly recommend to businesses that they do that because of the benefit they can obtain, particularly if they are going to engage in electronic commerce. These amendments implement an opt-in mechanism and also provide for an opt-out mechanism for those who would later choose to reassert their exempt status. This is unsatisfactory, in our view, because it also allows for businesses to opt out of coverage of the act when it no longer suits them to continue to protect the privacy information which has been collected by those businesses. It would allow small businesses to opt into the act to collect personal information from individuals who believe that the information is subject to the full protection in the act and then opt out of the act and presumably make use of, including sell, that information when they elect to opt out of the act.

In our view, this is inappropriate and not in the spirit of the recommendations of the House of Representatives committee. Our amendments will ensure that, once small businesses have elected to be bound by the act, that choice will be irrevocable and will be something they will have to consider before they make the election. This will prevent the possible improper use of personal information. However, it will require small businesses to have in place the appropriate privacy protection systems for administering information prior to making the decision to opt into coverage under the act, which is prudent privacy practice. The amendment omits the note which states that businesses which have opted in can opt out. Our amendment No. 3 proposes to substitute in place of proposed section 6EA(4) a new subsection (4) that a small business operator may not revoke a choice to be treated as an organisation. The reasoning for amendment (3) is the same as I have just discussed. The amendment goes hand in hand with that amendment. It states:

quote.para: A small business operator may not revoke a choice to be treated as an organisation.

speech.para: This is necessary to ensure clarity and to prevent a situation in which a small business could opt into the act, collect personal information, as I have indicated, from individuals who believe that the information is protected, and then opt out of the act and make use of that information. There has been, during this exchange over the amendments, debate regarding the ability of small businesses to opt in and opt out—and, indeed, the philosophy of whether the act should or should not apply to small businesses.

The government needs to be alive to the fact that the extent of the exemptions as currently proposed by the government probably will not be satisfactory to the European Union. People may say, `Who are they to tell us what to do?' I accept the reasoning there. However, while they are not entitled to tell us what to do, they are certainly entitled to elect whether or not they trade with Australia. I believe that, when their position is made clear to the government, the government itself will find that there will be an imperative to tighten up some of these exemptions if we are to benefit from the truly international opportunities that present themselves in this electronic trading environment.

talk.start.para: —I will just respond first in respect of the mention of the European Union directive. The European Union directive has gloriously proclaimed that it requires adequate protection of the personal information of residents of European Union countries. Except through discussions with Australian officials, of which there have been a number, there is no clarification of what is meant by that. What this regime seeks to do is to ensure that personal information, privacy, is protected where there is a risk. The small business exemption has sought to identify those businesses that do not present a risk. Insofar as they are identified as not presenting a risk but they do, there is a capacity for them to be prescribed. I do not think anything in this debate should be influenced by what the European Union directive does or does not mean or how it might be interpreted in the future. That is a matter for discussion with the European Union. We believe that the regime we are putting forward provides appropriate protection for the personal information of individuals dealing with organisations within Australia and that there are adequate provisions to protect that information being transferred overseas.

speech.para: Amendments negatived.
Original amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move government amendment (9):

quote.para: (9) Schedule 1, item 42, page 23 (lines 27 to 31), omit subsection (4), substitute:
(4) An act done, or practice engaged in, by a media organisation is exempt for the purposes of paragraph 7(1)(ee) if the act is done, or the practice is engaged in:
(a) by the organisation in the course of journalism; and
(b) at a time when the organisation is publicly committed to observe standards that:
(i) deal with privacy in the context of the activities of a media organisation (whether or not the standards also deal with other matters); and
(ii) have been published in writing by the organisation or a person or body representing a class of media organisations.

speech.para: This amendment concerns the media acts and practices exemption in the bill. It partly implements one of the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It inserts a new subclause that requires media organisations to meet an additional condition before the act or practice done or engaged in by the organisation in the course of journalism is exempt. The additional condition seeks to ensure an appropriate balance is found between the public interest in allowing the free flow of information to the public through the media and the public interest in providing adequate safeguards for the handling of personal information.

This additional condition requires a media organisation to have publicly committed itself to observing public standards that deal with privacy before it can rely on the exemption for the media. One way a media organisation might demonstrate its public commitment to standards dealing with privacy is to show that it is a member of a media industry body and that membership of that body requires it to subscribe to a code developed and published by the industry body. Many media organisations already subscribe to published codes of practice that have been developed by media industry bodies. It is not intended that a media organisation need subscribe to a privacy code approved by the Privacy Commissioner in order to benefit from the exemption.

The opposition apparently does not think that the government's initial condition goes far enough. The opposition, it seems, would require that the Privacy Commissioner approve in writing the standards that deal with privacy in the context of those media activities. And the opposition does not stop there. It would require that, before he approved the standards, the commissioner give everyone the commissioner considers has a real and substantive interest in the matters covered by the proposed standards an opportunity to comment on them. I wonder whether the opposition sought the views of the Privacy Commissioner before imposing such onerous tasks upon him. I wonder also whether it sought the views of media interests. I doubt it, because the government has already considered these options and, following extensive consultations, has rejected them. We consider the opposition's amendments in this respect to be ill conceived, and they are opposed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amend-ments (4) and (5) to government amendment (9):

quote.para: (4) Government amendment (9), at the end of paragraph (b), add:
(iii) has been approved in writing by the Privacy Commissioner.
(5) Government amendment (9), after proposed subsection 7B(4), insert:

(4A) Before approving standards for the purposes of paragraph (4), the Commissioner must give everyone the Commissioner considers has a real and substantive interest in the matters covered by the proposed standards an opportunity to comment on them.

speech.para: Again, while it is appropriate that the role of the media is properly recognised and the concept of freedom of the press is appreciated as being vital to the proper functioning of our democracy, we believe that the exemption from the provisions of the act is too broad. We acknowledge that an appropriately worded exemption is necessary, but we are concerned with the extent of the proposed exemption. The government amendment will require media organisations to publicly commit to privacy standards in order to obtain the benefit of the exemption, and we agree that is appropriate. Indeed we welcome that change. However, we are concerned that the proposed amendment overlooks the important role of the Privacy Commissioner in ensuring that those standards are in fact acceptable and appropriate. That is the role of the Privacy Commissioner with respect to other private sector codes.

Our amendment will ensure that, in order for a media organisation to be exempted from the provisions of the bill, the Privacy Commissioner must approve the privacy standards adopted by the media organisation. It must be realised, of course, that these media organisations are not exclusively and solely involved in the dissemination of journalistic opinion. They are involved in a wide range of activities, including linking to other networks and marketing of products and magazines and the like. So they will, as part of that trade, obtain a lot of information that is in the nature of consumer information, quite separately from their journalistic activities of relaying journalistic opinions regarding matters of public interest and current events.

In terms of opposition amendment (5), we propose to insert after proposed section 7B(4) a new subsection 4A to provide that, before approving standards for the purposes of paragraph 4, the commissioner—that is the Privacy Commissioner—must give everyone the commissioner considers has a real and substantive interest in the matters covered by the proposed standards an opportunity to comment on them. I draw the attention of the House to the subjective opinion of the Privacy Commissioner; it is not an objective opinion, so that burden is not too onerous at all. He has to form in his mind, albeit in good faith, who has a real and substantive interest. We say that, if a public official is doing their job properly, they should engage in such consultation with those bodies that have a real and substantive opinion. As I say, the opinion is one that he—or she if the Privacy Commissioner becomes a she—subjectively holds, not one according to an objective standard. The amendment we are proposing adds to our previous amendment which requires the Privacy Commissioner to approve media privacy standards. The Privacy Commissioner should approve those standards only after conducting what we have said is appropriate consultation with the persons who are affected, as sound public administration. We believe this is in keeping with the spirit of government amendment (14) which will require the commissioner to undertake a similar process of consultation before issuing the guidelines. For any privacy regime to be effective, the public must have confidence in it, and public consultation, we believe, is an important mechanism in the development of that confidence.

talk.start.para: —I just want to make two points. In case it is not altogether clear—and I may have misunderstood the member for Barton—the exemption for media organisations applies only in relation to their acts and practices when they are engaged in journalism. To the extent that they engage in any other sort of business, they are subject to the privacy regime under the bill. The second point I would make is to draw an analogy as a means of resisting the argument that the Privacy Commissioner ought to have a role in relation to media codes. This parliament has practices and procedures that are developed by it, and it exercises privileges that are allowed to be exercised under the Constitution. The courts have no role in the procedures of the parliament. They are simply nonjusticiable, and there is very good reason for that: the parliamentary and political processes are designed to ensure that any breach of procedures or requirements is capable of being dealt with within the confines of the parliament.

speech.para: When you come to the media, they sit in a somewhat similar position. They exercise a quasi-constitutional role in relation to exercising, under the Constitution, the implied right of communication in relation to matters of public affairs. To impose a judge on the media would be to do something similar to allowing the courts to interfere in the parliamentary processes. The Privacy Commissioner does not have a proper role in relation to what the media does in this area. It is a matter that should be controlled by the media in the same way that parliament should control itself. It is notionally nonjusticiable. That is the government view, and I commend it to the opposition.
Amendments negatived.
Original amendment agreed to.

Omit “For the purposes of this Part, the”, substitute “The”.

(18) Schedule 1, item 114, page 57 (after line 23), after section 70A, insert:

para.inline: Application of this Part to former organisations

quote.para: If an individual, body corporate, partnership, unincorporated association or trust ceases to be an organisation but continues to exist, this Part operates in relation to:
(a) an act or practice of the organisation (while it was an organisation); and

Example 1: If an individual carrying on a business was not a small business operator, but later became one and remained alive:

speech.para: Amendment (10) amends the provision in the bill that allows related bodies corporate to share personal information. The new clause will clarify how the related bodies corporate provision interacts with the exemptions in the bill. It will ensure that, where an entity that was not required to comply with the national privacy principles shares that personal information with a related body corporate, that related body corporate must comply with the national privacy principles or code equivalent when accepting that information.

Amendment (11) also concerns the small business exemption and, together with amendment (12), it clarifies which entities can take advantage of the delayed application period for small business. The amendment to clause 16D combined with amendment (12) means that the length of the delayed application period may vary. The period of delay may be a maximum of 12 months after the commencement of clause 16D or may, as a result of amendment (12), be a shorter period. Amendment (12) introduces a new definition of delayed application period. It retains the 12-month delay for most small businesses but introduces new provisions to deal with new organisations and organisations that carry on a business that is not a small business or that provide a health service. Amendment (12) removes the additional 12-month delayed application of the legislation to small businesses that provide a health service.

Amendment (13) together with amendment (17) clarify that a co-adjudicator in exercising functions under an approved code in the Federal Court or Federal Magistrates Court in exercising any judicial review powers should have regard to the same matters that the Privacy Commissioner must consider under section 29A of the Privacy Act when exercising his functions. Section 29A provides that the commissioner shall have due regard for the protection of important human rights and social interests that compete with privacy.

Amendment (14) requires the Privacy Commissioner to consult affected stake-holders before making guidelines relating to making and dealing with complaints under approved privacy codes. Subclause 18BF(2) provides that the Privacy Commissioner may publish guidelines in any way he or she considers appropriate. Amendment (15) clarifies that that subclause refers to all guidelines listed in subclause 18BF(1). Amendment (16) deletes the reference to part V so that the definition is capable of extending to NPP7. Amendment (17) makes it clear that a court must have due regard to the same matters as the Privacy Commissioner by expressly referring to paragraph 29(a) of the act. Amendment (18) preserves the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner for those periods during which the organisation had voluntarily opted into coverage, or subject to the legislation for a period, under other grounds.

Amendment (19) relates to the regulations that may be made in relation to NPP7 as proposed under amendment (21). Before the Governor-General may make regulations for the purposes of NPP7, the minister must be satisfied of certain things. These are that the agency must have agreed to the adoption, use or disclosure by the organisation of the identifier. In the circumstances it is appropriate that the agency must have consulted the Privacy Commissioner about the proposal and that the adoption, use or disclosure can only be for the benefit of the individual concerned. Amendment (20) provides that every time personal information is used for the secondary purpose of direct marketing, the organisation must provide the individual the opportunity to opt out of receiving further direct marketing communications from the organisation.

Amendments (21) and (22) provide some flexibility in terms of the adoption, use and disclosure of government identifiers. The amendments are not, however, intended to open up the principle to allow for widespread adoption, use or disclosure of such identifiers. Amendment (21) will make it clear that adoption, use and disclosure of an identifier is permissible under NPP7 if prescribed. Prescription can only occur where the circumstances set out in amendment (19) are satisfied—that is, the agency agrees the commissioner has been consulted and only where adoption, use or disclosure is for the benefit of the individual concerned. Amendment (23) will ensure that the Australian business number—ABN—which is intended by the government to be adopted, used and disclosed as an identifier of an organisation, is not subject to the limitations in NPP7. I commend the amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —The opposition agrees to amendments Nos 10 to 23 as proposed.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Williams)—by leave—read a third time.
Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —While the opposition supports the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2000, there are some points we would like to place on the record regarding the establishment of the Federal Magistrates Service. The intention of the bill is to rectify some potential invalidities or irregularities that could occur in respect of the transfer of proceedings between the Federal Magistrates Service and the Federal Court or the Family Court and, in reverse, from the Family Court or Federal Court to the Federal Magistrates Service. We understand that the Attorney-General has received advice that there is some doubt as to whether the transfers between those respective courts can occur under the feeder legislation—for want of a better description—to these courts: the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the Family Law Act and the Trade Practices Amendment Act.

speech.para: We agree that there needs to be clarification of those matters and we also agree with the need for schedule 2—that is, the safety net provisions contained in the bill—to validate any decisions or orders that may have offended the requirements of the current legislation. We might add, however, that we believe there may be a constitutional issue that does arise as to the extent to which the parliament can validate orders that have already been made, particularly with respect to orders for the dissolution of a marriage. We have questions as to whether that is effectively an administrative action rather than a judicial decision dissolving those marriages, but no doubt that is something the Attorney-General's Department has considered or will consider. I do not want to make a point about an embarrassing oversight. These sorts of things can happen no matter which political party is in power. I think the important thing is to rectify these matters so that litigants before the courts do not waste money in litigating issues that ultimately result in the outcome of the proceedings being set aside or found to be a nullity.

The point I want to make in my contribution concerns not so much the technical issues relating to the establishment of the Federal Magistrates Service but, rather, the practical issues. Fundamentally, those practical problems have been the result of the creation of an artificial seam where one is unnecessary; that is, the creation of a Federal Magistrates Service as a separate and distinct court from the Federal Court and the Family Court has created problems in respect of the use of the premises, the use of libraries, for instance, the interactive use of staff and the storage and transfer of files. No doubt, as the service continues to function, many other areas of administration will become involved. Albeit this was in the middle of the year, and hopefully some teething problems have been struggled through, I would point out that there was a Financial Review reference—reported on 23 June 2000—to an interview with the Chief Federal Magistrate, Ms Diana Bryant QC. Justice Bryant is reported as saying:

quote.para: “We are all in a `federal judiciary family' but like all families there's a power struggle,” she said.

Ms Bryant said that while in Adelaide trying to set up the magistracy she “foolishly” mentioned sharing the existing library, and she admitted the rules and procedures of the court, along with the filing fees, had not been finalised.

speech.para: I understand the rules and procedures and filing fees are being resolved; but clearly there is a reference there, if you like, to the respective empires being protective of their own turf. That is regrettable when what we are about is trying to ensure that Australian citizens have access to cheap and efficient justice irrespective of the source of that justice. Again, creating this artificial division, we believe, is unnecessary and has more to do with the desire of the government to avoid public headlines regarding decisions of the Family Court. That is not the way to create these institutions that are so vitally important to Australians receiving justice.

The clashes which have occurred—and which we believe will inevitably occur—between the competing jurisdictions are particularly important in the context of a reduction in the Family Court's budget. The Family Court's budget has been cut, as a result of the establishment of the Federal Magistrates Service, by some $15.4 million over four years. That has resulted in the loss of some 80 jobs. If you leave aside the entrenched costs of the Family Court, as was indicated in a memorandum of the chief executive of the Family Court of 10 May 2000, this cut of some $15.4 million is effectively a 10 per cent reduction in the operating budget of the Family Court. As the chief executive officer indicated, it would have significant repercussions for the staffing and delivery of services of the Family Court. That has proven to be the case.

For instance, I was recently in the federal electorate of Capricornia, in the city of Rockhampton. It appears that the cuts to the Family Court's budget have resulted in a reduction in registry hours from a full-time operating registry to two days per week during non-circuit weeks, although it will operate on a full-time basis during circuit weeks, which I understand is approximately half the year. The person who staffed the registry has said: `What sort of a job is that for me? I have a full-time job half the year and half a job for the remainder of the year. Where does that leave me?' It appears that she has very quickly been snapped up by a legal firm up there because of her reputation for competence and assistance to members of the public. It is regrettable that the Australian public has lost a very loyal public servant who has been of great benefit to the local community in that area. I should say that `local community' is a very broad term when you are looking at the electorate of Capricornia and the surrounding areas. People came from hundreds of miles away to obtain services from the Family Court registry located in Rockhampton.

There are going to be real problems for the community up there because of the loss of that staff member. How will a person travelling from 100 miles away know whether the registry is going to be closed or open before they leave? This registry had really made a contribution in assisting people to complete documentation—for example, to direct them to other support services that were available to reduce the extent of trauma associated with marital breakdown and generally to provide a very valuable and valued public service up there.

There are also going to be problems as to what is going to happen now with documents that have been filed in Townsville because the Rockhampton registry is not open. If these documents are filed at a time which is close to when the circuit is going to be in the city, there is a real prospect of disruption to proceedings as a result of documents going astray. So, despite the government's protestations and the Prime Minister's Nyngan declaration that there would be no further depletion of services to regional and rural Australia, the establishment of this Federal Magistrates Service has indirectly resulted in that occurring because of the reduction in resources to the Family Court of Australia.

Although obviously the loss of that registry resource is important, of more crucial importance is the issue of counselling. That was flagged, perhaps, by the Chief Federal Magistrate, Justice Bryant, in the interview which is reported on 23 June. She is reported as saying that she was still dealing with the vexed problem of alternative dispute resolution and how to offer it effectively within the budget—that is, the budget of the new Federal Magistrates Service. I understand that, while it was initially intended that the Federal Magistrates Service would have access to the counselling facilities of the Federal Court, and perhaps to the counselling facilities offered by non-government organisations, there is, as she points out, a question of resourcing the Federal Magistrates Service to provide that counselling service. If they do not have the money, they clearly cannot pay for that service. Again, because of the difference in the courts, presumably if the Federal Court counsellors were going to be involved there would be some payment required from the Federal Magistrates Service to the Federal Court for those hours. Or if non-government organisations were going to be used by the Federal Magistrates Service, presumably there would be some payment required from the Federal Magistrates Service.

To date, it looks as though that has not been sorted out. It has been reported to me that the Federal Magistrates Service simply is not offering that counselling—those important alternative dispute resolution facilities—to people who file documents before the Federal Magistrates Service. That is significant because of the effect that the establishment of the Federal Magistrates Service has had on the Family Court—namely, a reduction of $15.4 million in the Family Court's operating budget. As was indicated by the chief executive officer of the Family Court, as a result of that 10 per cent reduction—and I quote from his 10 May memorandum:

quote.para: It is likely that we will need to reduce the amount of voluntary counselling that we provide, with the result that some counselling positions will go.

speech.para: In Rockhampton, for instance, that has been the outcome. The counselling services will be entirely contracted out to private service providers—to non-government organisations. I met with a number of those non-government organisations when I was in Rockhampton. They are staffed by extremely decent, competent people. The organisations do a tremendous job. But there is a real issue as to whether they are going to be able to perform Family Court counselling properly, and certainly as to whether they will be able to provide the service that is needed as part of the Family Court proceedings. There is a real resourcing issue: what will they be paid to undertake this counselling activity? What is the extent of training that is being undertaken by their counsellors? The Family Court counsellors have been selected after a rigorous selection process and then have an extensive in-house training program. We are entitled to ask: will that sort of training and selection process be applied in respect of the non-government organisations?

Also, in resolving family law disputes, it is naïve to assume that some knowledge of family law is not required and, indeed, some knowledge of the likely outcome of proceedings. How can you attempt to resolve a residence or an access matter between a couple when you are not familiar with the likely outcome of that matter, should the people involved go to court? More often than not, these matters are resolved when someone who is properly informed and has the respect of the litigants is able to say, `You have to be sensible here. No-one likes the outcome of the Family Court process because, by definition, you walk away with less than the combined assets you had as a husband and wife; indeed, you walk away, more distressingly than that, with less time with your children because of the different orders made about residence and access to your children.' By its very definition, the Family Court process ends up with people who are dissatisfied because they have less than they started off with, having regard to the nature of the breakdown in the relationship.

What has been vitally important has been the ability of counsellors to say, `I know you're not happy about this and you don't want to see that happen, but if you go on to litigation, this is going to be a likely outcome.' The counsellors with these non-government organisations who have not had that sort of experience are going to be at an extreme disadvantage—or, more specifically, people using that counselling service are going to be at an extreme disadvantage in terms of receiving any meaningful guidance from the counsellor. There are also issues as to who will be available to assist the non-government organisations to reduce any agreement to a written form should they be able to succeed in bringing the parties to an agreement. There are also issues relating to a support network for these counsellors in the non-government organisations.

The Family Court counsellors, as you would expect, have developed an extensive support network in respect of the quite intense and personal problems that they confront. They are able to consult with their colleagues as to ideas that have been tried and proven to be successful in the experience of these other counsellors. But this is going to be an entirely new territory for these non-government organisations, which will not be able to tap into such a network of support.

One of the vital roles played by Family Court counsellors is the provision of family reports to judges. Judges rely extremely heavily on those family reports because they are getting input presumably from someone they respect who has had the time to spend with the respective parties to the marriage break-up and, more importantly, with their children. Do we lose that important area of input into the Family Court process because of the contracting out of these counselling services? It is very much penny-wise and pound-foolish to look at saving money in the area of counselling. The Attorney himself recognised, when he commented on the Family Court of Australia's annual report for 1999-2000 as recently as 27 October 2000, that:

quote.para: The use of primary dispute resolution processes resulted in only 6.5 per cent of all matters filed with the court being finalised by judgment during 1999-2000.

speech.para: That is an outstanding result from these primary dispute resolution processes. Only 93.5 per cent of cases went to trial because of the success of these settlement processes. The proof of the pie is in the eating. These counselling services have had dramatic success in resolving matters without going to litigation. So to diminish the resources available to them and their opportunity to assist parties to come to a resolution outside the judicial process is, as I say, penny-wise and pound-foolish simply because it is more than likely that you will end up with more court hours and paying for the cost of judicial time, an associate, a court reporter, a court officer and even the rental space of those courts. So it is just foolish.

In addition, there will inevitably be additional expenses to the community. The longer that family disputes go on unresolved, the greater the need will be, for instance, for a whole range of additional social services to cope with children who, more often than not, are the ones who suffer trauma in situations of marriage break-up where there is hostility. Indeed, in worst case scenarios, there will also be the need for the intervention of police services if there is a build-up in aggression to the point where domestic violence ensues. Again, we are all familiar with such situations. It is fair to say that those comments are not sensationalist because we are well and truly aware of the need for police to come out in domestic violence situations. The police themselves regard that as one of the most dangerous activities that they confront. But all the time that matters are not resolved, the victims are very much the children. So this disjunction that is creating this artificial division between the Federal Magistrates Service and the Family Court, with the accompanying diminution of resources to the Family Court, has already had significant effects, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

I was particularly encouraged by my discussion with the Rockhampton practitioners, all of whom appreciated the value of these counselling services, despite the fact that the lawyers did not play a part in attending those counselling proceedings and were cut out of the action from a financial point of view. They all recognised that it was in the interests of their client to achieve a conciliated outcome through an effective counselling process, rather than for the matter to be resolved by litigation.

It was put to me—and I have to say that I agree with it—that the mere fact a litigation is commenced invariably results in the inability for that matter to settle. As soon as you are required to put down in affidavit form the various accusations and imputations against the other party, particularly in the context of residence and access to children, you automatically inflame the situation so that it takes months to resolve. They put to me the vital importance of counselling at an early date—a suggestion that we will take on board in our policy development, and one that the government may take on board. It was put to me that, other than in matters of urgency of domestic violence or perhaps an abduction, it may well be of benefit to require parties, before they commence proceedings in the Family Court, to file a certificate of attempted resolution through an alternative dispute resolution mechanism, where it is not necessary to up the ante by setting out in writing the various accusations, airing the dirty laundry and aggravating both parties. That is certainly something to bear in mind. I make those points not as an aside but to say how directly important counselling services are in this area.

We are having a situation where, because of the depletion of the resources of the Family Court, those counselling services are being contracted out in circumstances where I do not believe that contracting out is going to deliver services effectively. At the same time—and this is a vitally important point—it does not appear that the Federal Magistrates Service has the resources to tap into these counselling services. I might add that the ridiculous situation is now occurring in Rockhampton where, after losing their staff member of the registry because of the reduction of registry hours, there are apparently negotiations occurring as to whether the Federal Magistrates Service will place some additional demand on the registry such that it could be at least partially reopened during those non-sitting periods.

You have had a reduction or sucking out of assets result in reduced services for the community. Perhaps commonsense is prevailing so the wave is starting to come in a bit in terms of people resolving these practical differences that exist between the way in which the Federal Magistrates Service and the Family Court conduct themselves.

That is very relevant in terms of the way circuits are conducted. If you lose 10 per cent of your operating budget the inevitable consequence for the Family Court is that they are going to have to reduce the amount of circuit time they undertake—and circuits are vitally important to the delivery of justice to rural and regional Australia. To what extent will the Federal Magistrates Service be able to fill that void? They already have intense demands in the capital cities for their services. The Chief Federal Magistrate has indicated that she herself has some resourcing questions if their workload increases, as one would expect it will. That has to put into question the extent to which the Federal Magistrates Service will be able to undertake circuit work. What is going to be the mechanism for coordinating circuits undertaken by the Federal Magistrates Service as opposed to the circuit work undertaken by the Family Court? They are vitally important questions because, for a start, when is the Rockhampton registry going to be open? Is it only going to be open during the circuit weeks of the Family Court or will it be open separately or in addition during the circuit weeks of the Federal Magistrates Service? This is a vitally important question not only for the registry staff but also for people wishing to use the registry.

Put yourself in the position, as it was explained to me, of these practitioners. What body, what court, do they commence the proceedings in? Do they commence the proceedings in the Family Court, where they know there is going to be at least some access to counselling, albeit, it now appears, through the contracting out arrangement? Or do they commence it with the Federal Magistrates Service, where it was conceded that, because of the fewer matters in that service, they will get a more expedited hearing date, but they will not have the opportunity for the counselling services that are available? Again, what court they commence it in will depend very much on the extent to which circuits will be undertaken by the Federal Magistrates Service. These sorts of things just have not been worked through. It is already having an effect on rural and regional Australia. It is certainly having an effect on the administration of justice.

This is frustrating because there were alternatives. We argued, and it indeed is still our position, that it would have been preferable to include what we acknowledge as a required magistrates level of justice within the existing Family Court and Federal Court structures. A good example is how the Western Australian Family Court operates, where, yes, there is a magistrates service incorporated within that court but it very much operates as the one unit, where magistrates and judges alike work off the one docket system so matters flow freely between them, depending on the level of complexity, urgency and the like. Incorporation of the Magistrates Service within the existing family and federal courts would have avoided these unnecessary, practical problems that I have referred to—problems because of the artificial and unnecessary division between the jurisdictions, particularly in the Family Court area.

Another alternative, or an additional avenue that would have been available, was proposed by three state Attorneys-General. Jan Wade in Victoria, Matt Foley in Queensland and Jeff Shaw in New South Wales all said, `Why are you creating this additional service? We have magistrates all through our states in regional and rural areas. Why don't we look at sitting down with an agreement for dual commissions to appropriately trained magistrates'—they concede that not all magistrates would have the training—`so that we could literally get these sorts of services out into the bush?' That was totally ignored by the government. Again, one has to question the merits of this ridiculous step of spending some $27 million to establish an entirely separate court, which has caused fractures and unnecessary divisions in the delivery of justice. As a New South Wales Law Society Journal concluded:

quote.para: From the Federal government's perspective, however, the best use of the $27 million will be the disappearance of the Family Court from television current affairs programs and the front pages of the press.

speech.para: One suspects that that is the motive of the government, but it is not sufficient for the administration of justice. (Time expired).
Debate (on motion by Ms Worth) adjourned.

debate.para: Motion (by Ms Worth)by leave agreed to:

motion.para: That the following bill be referred to the Main Committee for consideration:

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT (IMPROVED MONITORING OF ENTITLEMENTS TO PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 6 September, on motion by Dr Wooldridge:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, before I begin my remarks on the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000, I am sure you would not mind, and nor would the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, who is at the table, if I made a few remarks about White Wreath Day. A large number of us have been out on the lawns of Parliament House, where a very powerful statement has been made by the wreaths laid out on the lawns commemorating all the people who have died from suicide this year. I would like to say, on behalf of the whole parliament, how much we owe Fanita Clark, the woman who has organised White Wreath Day, for bringing this very powerful statement to the parliament.

speech.para: One of the most important things, as she said in her remarks out on the lawns, is, of course, to bring mental illness and suicide out into the open so that it is talked about in our community and not hidden or treated as something that cannot be addressed. I wanted to take a moment before beginning my remarks on this bill to pay tribute to her work. She suffered the tragedy of losing her own son to suicide. All of us have a little more understanding of the pain that she has gone through, given our terrible loss here in the parliament with Greg Wilton's suicide. I recommend to all members that they go out and spend a bit of time looking at the stories that are displayed out on the lawns. Hopefully, as a result, we will all take much more action to talk about the issues and also to improve our policies with respect to mental illness.

The aim of this bill is to tighten the process for determining eligibility for the $3.8 billion Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. As all of us know, the PBS, as we call it, is a very successful Commonwealth program that provides the community with reliable and affordable access to necessary and cost-effective medicines. Under the scheme the Commonwealth pays about 82 per cent of the cost of PBS listed drugs. Pensioners, of course, are required to pay only $3.30 for each prescription, which makes sure that they have access to the medicines that they need at an affordable price.

It is a very significant program. As at 1 February last year, the scheme covered an enormous amount of medicines—559 different medicines—while 140 million prescriptions are supplied each year under the PBS. It is very important that the entitlement arrangements are properly administered so that we can ensure that only eligible people are receiving benefits. Eligibility for the scheme is restricted to Australian residents and to visitors from countries with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement. These countries are the UK, Ireland, New Zealand, Malta, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands and Finland.

Under the bill, the government wants to make it harder for ineligible people, such as tourists, overseas visitors and people with non-resident status, to obtain subsidised drugs. The amendments also attempt to reduce the incidence of doctor shopping. Doctor shopping, as I am sure most people are aware, involves consumers obtaining large quantities of subsidised drugs for recreational drug use, sale for profit or to send to friends overseas by presenting prescriptions from different doctors to different pharmacists for the same drug.

The opposition, of course, supports both of these goals. We want to make sure that the PBS works effectively and cuts down on fraud. However, we want to make sure that, in meeting that objective, we do not do so at the expense of privacy. We have just had a very long debate in the parliament between the Attorney-General and the shadow Attorney-General in trying to improve the government's privacy legislation. One of the critical areas in that regard is in the area of privacy over an individual's health information. We certainly have some concerns, not so much about what this bill is trying to do but about where the government is heading with unique patient identifiers and the lack of privacy protection for people's individual health information.

The other area that needs a very high priority when it comes to pharmaceuticals is making sure that safety and quality are at the top of the agenda. At the moment the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme works in such a way that people do not have to prove their eligibility. Concessional patients such as pensioners must produce a health card, but no proof of eligibility is currently required for the general benefit which all of us are entitled to. It therefore has been difficult for pharmacists to determine the entitlement status of the customer or to recognise `doctor shoppers'. The desirability of tightening the legislative requirements to make sure that pharmacists can check a customer's eligibility is therefore recognised, but it must be ensured that we are doing it in a cost-effective way. I am not sure that this bill really achieves that.

The bill will require doctors and other prescribers to put the patient's Medicare number on each prescription. It will allow pharmacists to check who is eligible for the PBS and will assist the Health Insurance Commission and pharmacists to identify doctor shoppers. When fully implemented, the government will not pay pharmacists unless they have checked the person's Medicare number and the expiry date before dispensing medicines. In addition, if the number is incorrect when compared with the Health Insurance Commission data, pharmacists will be required to actually track down the customer in order to correct their Medicare number or to obtain the balance of the payment for the pharmaceuticals. The bill permits pharmacists and doctors to keep the Medicare numbers for future use for the same patients but requires them to maintain the privacy of this information. The bill creates various offences for disclosing or misusing Medicare numbers. To that degree, privacy of the Medicare number certainly is protected.

There are various aspects of the scheme, though, that we have had representations about and that do need more careful thought and design. A key concern has been the speed with which the government proposes to implement the arrangements. There are three stages, leading to July 2001, through which implementation is going to proceed. Initially, pharmacists are going to get a discretionary power to request a Medicare number from a person presenting a prescription and, with that person's consent, will be allowed to store that number. This phase will only operate for a few weeks because, unfortunately, it has taken the government a very long time to get this legislation into the parliament for debate.

From 1 January next year—not very long away—the pharmacist must ask for the Medicare number. If the number is not provided, the person will not be eligible to receive the pharmaceutical benefit and will have to pay the full price. Some people who do not carry around their Medicare card might get a rude shock, particularly if they are down at the beach during the summer holidays and need to fill a prescription. The third phase starts on 3 July next year, when the provision of a Medicare number will become mandatory both for the doctor and for the pharmacist. There are provisions allowing the correction of Medicare numbers during the phase-in, but after that the rules become quite strict.

The larger concern, though, has been that this bill is simply the beginning, the thin edge of the wedge, of what has been foreshadowed by the government in the Better Medication Management Scheme, which the government has indicated it will introduce legislation for shortly. The opposition believes that the public really needs to see the full picture and that there needs to be greater consultation with consumers and health professionals, who will be affected by what is coming next. While the opposition certainly supports amending laws to try and stamp out fraud, we do not want this to be done at the expense of access to medicines in emergency situations—people being caught without their Medicare card because they did not know that having it with them was necessary—or by the new system compromising a patient's privacy.

There are a number of people who may not have Medicare cards but who are nevertheless eligible for pharmaceutical benefits—people with disabilities, for example, in the care of a guardian; people who are itinerant; Aboriginal people who do not necessarily carry their Medicare cards all the time; visitors from overseas countries with which Australia has a bilateral agreement; people in emergency situations; and people who just lose their cards. So we need to make sure that, in the implementation of the bill, access to subsidised medicines is not denied to those eligible people. The scheme will need to include a number of these exemptions. I think it would be helpful if these exemptions were made clear before the bill goes through the parliament.

One of our primary concerns is with privacy and whether the mechanisms used in this bill—that is, for the first time the public exchange of our Medicare numbers—are foreshadowing the government's overall approach to medical records and the development of a unique patient identifier by the Health Insurance Commission. As I indicated last night in my remarks on the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000, I am a strong supporter of the need for a unique patient identifier and for electronic health records, but not without national health privacy legislation.

We all know—and I am sure this is true for the government as well—that health information cannot be moved online until there is a unique patient identifier developed that can be used to access all the health information held about a particular person, regardless of where that information is held, whether it is in records held by a hospital, medical records held by a doctor or pharmaceutical records held by a pharmacist. I say again that such an identifier represents a very significant threat to a patient's privacy unless strong health privacy legislation is first put in place. Certainly the legislation that has just gone through the House of Representatives is not sufficient in that regard. It will not protect people's health privacy, and I indicate again the opposition's serious concerns with that privacy legislation as far as health is concerned.

So long as that health privacy legislation does not exist, in our view it is certainly premature to be introducing a unique patient identifier. As I said, there is every sign that the Medicare number on people's cards is going to be used in this way with this bill. There are ways to overcome this problem, to make sure that people can have a unique patient identifier that is confidential and that does not appear on the card itself. The last thing we want is someone else picking up our Medicare cards and being able to read the number. At the moment these cards float around but, because we know there is nothing confidential that can be got from them, nobody worries about it too much. Nobody wants that number to be the unique patient identifier. We need to make sure that the identifier is confidential so that nobody can either accidentally or otherwise hack in and read our medical records.

The second privacy concern is how the government will use this information, this information that is going to be collected by pharmacists using the Medicare number, once it is collected. The bill is not clear on this issue. It is certainly the case that there are currently specific Privacy Commissioner guidelines about the use of pharmaceutical data and restrictions on matching that with medical benefits data. That is true. During briefings that we have had with departmental officers they have indicated to us that the data collected, based on our Medicare numbers, will not be matched against existing medical benefits or pharmaceutical benefits data. But there is nothing in the legislation to stop this. If the government could indicate how that is going to be protected, we would appreciate it. We are concerned about the ambiguities that this might create, because it sounds like there are now going to be three data sets collected by the Health Insurance Commission, and it is just not clear what the protections between them will be.

The same concern arises with what we understand is being worked out for the better medication management scheme. What privacy rules will be put in place to protect information that is collected through that scheme, and what data matching arrangements will be allowed? What controls have been put in place to protect an individual's privacy, and what action will the Health Insurance Commission be able to take against any person on the basis of this information alone? There are a number of these issues, particularly relating to privacy, that we certainly think still require some answers.

If the uncertainty about the operation of the unique patient identifier is allowed to continue, I am concerned that it will harm public confidence in the whole issue of the development of electronic health records. That would be very unfortunate. It would be a major setback, as national standards for electronic health records and decision support systems are essential if we are going to improve the safety and quality of our health services. We are going to need national agreement on what should be included in those electronic records, who should have access to them and what constitutes acceptable security. To reiterate, a separate health privacy regime is urgently needed, not one that is based on voluntary codes, which is all we are going to get from the government's current privacy legislation. I ask the government to clear up a number of these issues. Members of the public that I have talked to about these issues are very concerned because the detailed plans about how electronic health records and unique patient identifiers are going to go forward and what the protections will be are just not clear.

The effectiveness of the measures contained in this bill is also questionable. Under the new scheme, it will not be necessary to have your Medicare card to have a prescription filled. You only have to be able to quote your family's Medicare number and the expiry date of the card, so agents will still be able to go into the chemist shop and collect your prescription if they can quote your Medicare card number. This will leave open most of what we understand to be the currently used methods for ineligible people to obtain a prescription: borrowing a card, using a stolen card or impersonating a friend. We cannot see how this is going to impact on any of the measures that currently exist. It would appear not to be effective even against a person with a stolen prescription impersonating the person to whom the prescription was originally given, because they can simply write down the Medicare number as it appears on the prescription themselves. We are also worried that it will not be effective against doctor shopping if there is no data matching. That really goes back to the question I asked before: what data matching will take place to ensure that doctor shopping is reduced?

So we are concerned that the bill might not make much impact either way—by controlling the use of the PBS by ineligible people or by stopping abuse by doctor shoppers. Whether the Commonwealth will be able to save the amount they anticipate saving is, I have to say, more than a bit doubtful. The saving also looks like it might be offset by the increased costs incurred by implementing these requirements. Already, the Pharmacy Guild has put in a claim for increased payments because of the work involved in checking each prescription. I gather that this was not included in the recently finalised pharmacy agreement. So if, for example, the government pays more than 15c for each transaction for the additional work of checking the Medicare numbers, then the entire savings, even on the government's numbers, could be wiped out. It certainly does not look like a very efficient measure to control fraud and, also because of the cost of all the necessary checks, it looks like the cost might outweigh the savings, if they exist at all.

Pharmacists are also going to have to carry the penalty for any incorrect information being supplied to the Health Insurance Commission, and everyone would understand that they certainly have concerns about that. The government has recently signalled to us that they intend to introduce a whole lot of amendments to this bill. There are six pages of amendments to deal with oversights in the original drafting. I gather it is now common for pharmacists to swipe Medicare cards—although I have never seen my Medicare card swiped—to make an electronic claim on the PBS using the Health Insurance Commission's claims transmission system, and that is provided for under the National Health Act.

These extensive amendments are necessary because the bill unfortunately seems to have been prepared in haste. However, the fact that the government is prepared to listen to representations they have received is a good sign, and we will look at the amendments carefully. Hopefully, they will address some of the concerns that we have raised. It is appropriate that the bill should incorporate provision for electronic transmission of claims. We are not opposed to that because, of course, the underlying objective is to make the system more efficient and accurate without reducing the protection of private information.

I am disappointed that the government has introduced this legislation separately from the Better Medication Management Scheme, because that scheme promises to develop an electronic system for patient medication records that can be accessed by doctors, pharmacists and patients. That scheme will identify and prevent medication errors at a pharmacy level and it should be introduced in a complementary way to the scheme that we are debating in this bill, which is aiming to reduce inappropriate prescribing as well.

The whole question of inappropriate prescribing has a major impact on the health of Australians, particularly the elderly and those people on multiple medications. And that flows through not only to people who are being cared for in the community but also to people who get a lot of their medications via hospitals. It has been estimated that a substantial number of admissions of the elderly to hospital are the result of problems with medication. A lot more effort needs to be channelled into improving the decision making of prescribers of medications and minimising the extent to which unnecessary or unwise therapies are prescribed in the first place.

Not so long ago I saw an excellent example of this taking place with the South Australian Division of General Practice, who have developed an innovative program to better manage the prescribing of benzodiazepine in the southern region of Adelaide. Unfortunately, that has not been replicated elsewhere. We need to do a whole lot more to improve the quality use of medicines so that adverse results from using medications are reduced.

I have been visiting a lot of hospitals and have met people who are very involved in developing new ways to improve quality and safety in our health system. It is interesting that this issue was the subject of the editorial in today's Australian. The point that is made very powerfully in the editorial in the newspaper today is how slow we have been to address these issues. The editorial says that back in 1995 the federal government was presented with evidence showing that about 18,000 Australians die each year because of medical errors. This is a huge number of people who die because of medical errors that do not need to take place. The editorial correctly says that we have been slow to come up with answers and implement changes.

The government only just last year established the Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care. As the editorial says, it took four years for the government to establish this council—even though the alarm bells about medical mistakes were ringing some time ago.
