It really is a very tentative step by this government, particularly when you compare it with what is happening in the United States and the United Kingdom where much more dramatic action is being taken to reduce medical errors. The roll-out of information technology throughout our health care system is about making sure that these medical errors are reduced and that we support those at the front line in our health system with evidence so that they can improve the services that are delivered.

I am pleased to see that the Minister for Health and Aged Care has finally announced the National Institute of Clinical Studies. Unfortunately, the institute's establishment is long overdue. It was first announced in May 1999, and the membership of the board of that institute was only announced last Friday. It has taken the government an inordinate amount of time to get this organisation under way. It is a very important organisation, because it is in that place that we can see the very useful collection of meaningful data that can then be provided to those doctors and other health providers out in the community to improve their practice. Unfortunately, this government has been extremely slow at getting around to doing the things that are necessary to improve the quality of health care—whether in hospitals, general practice or any other part of our health system. It is extremely slow, unfortunately, in only recently establishing a committee and now the Institute of Clinical Studies.

It can only be hoped that we will get some much faster action and some more serious attention to what is an enormously serious problem. Eighteen thousand Australians die each year because of medical errors, and yet it is barely talked about and has been given very little attention to date by this government. I hope that during the debate on this bill we can take it a little bit further, strengthen it and make it more effective to guarantee that, certainly, the subsidised use of pharmaceuticals is only available for those who are eligible and that we are able to significantly limit doctor shopping. Unfortunately, certainly with the way the bill is written at the moment, I do not think it will have much impact.

talk.start.para: —The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 I am supporting today ensures that only those eligible to obtain prescription medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme do so. The bill will achieve this important aim by gradually introducing a system where a patient's Medicare card will have to be presented when picking up a prescription from the chemist. This will prevent people from using the PBS who are not entitled to, such as people travelling in Australia from overseas. This is another step by the coalition government to help maintain the success and viability of the PBS and to ensure that all Australians continue to have access to subsidised medicines. Importantly, this will be phased in over a period of time, enabling people to get used to the change before its full implementation on 1 July 2001. Patients already know that they have to take their Medicare card when visiting a doctor, and concessional patients already have to produce their health care card when obtaining a prescription from the pharmacy, and so I do not believe that providing their Medicare card will be much more of an impost. Australia has reciprocal arrangements with several countries, including New Zealand and the United Kingdom, and their people will still have access to the PBS—but they must show their passport so that the pharmacist can determine if they are from one of these eligible countries. This will also stop people from overseas obtaining subsidised pharmaceuticals with the intent of taking them home for themselves or other people in their own country.

speech.para: The savings to the taxpayer as a result of this legislation will amount to more than $40 million over the next four years. The spiralling cost of the PBS is often mentioned in this House, as it is quite significant. This financial year it is expected to reach approximately $3.8 billion. On a global scale, however, we fare quite well, with the cost of the PBS representing just under 12 per cent of the total health budget. This is compared to the 16 per cent in France and nearly 18 per cent in the United Kingdom. The United States only spend 7.8 per cent of their health budget on pharmaceuticals.

The huge cost of the PBS can be attributed to a number of factors. Some of these, such as the advances of modern medicine, cannot be avoided. It is also worth noting that often the cost of subsidising a particular drug can provide cost savings to the community in the long term due to the marked improvement in health of the patient. Take the drug Celebrex, which has just recently been included on the PBS. The cost to patients has been reduced from an average of about $50 to $60 a month to a maximum of $3.30 for health cardholders and $20.60 for general patients. This drug is a major breakthrough in the treatment of arthritis. It is as effective as other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs but it produces significantly fewer adverse side effects. People taking Celebrex will have considerably less gastric irritation and fewer hospital visits due to gastric bleeding and they will use fewer analgesics.

I am concerned, however, that many Australians, in particular seniors, are being overmedicated. Not only is this a strain on the PBS but it also has the potential to be life threatening to the patient. Often people take so many drugs that they would not be able to list them when sitting in front of a doctor. It is difficult to obtain statistics on this but I know from experience how drugs can react dangerously in a person's system if they are already taking another drug that is incompatible. People also hoard medicines. This is costly for both the patient and the PBS, as well as dangerous to the patient and their family, particularly children who risk poisoning themselves. Unfortunately, there are also some people who doctor shop for scripts that they can sell to substance abusers. The drug of choice used to be the self-injecting pethidine, scripts for which people would obtain and then sell. These days people obtain scripts for benzodiazepines, like Serapax and Valium, opiates and the amphetamine based drugs like dexamphetamine and Ritalin. This is one of the important issues that will be addressed when we introduce the better medication management scheme or HealthConnect. That is a separate initiative from the one I am speaking on today but they both relate to the accountability of the distribution of pharmaceuticals in this country.

I know there are some groups concerned about the privacy issues that are inevitably raised when discussing use of data monitoring and electronic databases. It is not that the information on patients is not already there now. It can be found if someone wants to find it but it is not easy to do so. Part of the push behind HealthConnect is to utilise the technology that is now available to us and enter into electronic medicine. This will allow information on a patient to be easily available to the two most important parties—the patient and the GP. This will also greatly assist hospitals, which will be able to access a patient's history if they come into the hospital unconscious or unable to communicate to the medical staff. Of course, the introduction of a system like HealthConnect needs safeguards to ensure the community will readily accept the new system without privacy concerns. I believe patients' privacy will be enhanced compared to the current paper based system. Access can be restricted to authorised users and patients will be able to find out who has accessed their records.

The issue of a central register or database was raised at a recent hearing of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs inquiry into substance abuse, which I attended. Users know which doctors to go to around the metropolitan area to obtain scripts for addictive drugs, such as Rohypnol, or `rohies' as they are known on the street. This is another area where we need to crack down on doctor shopping. People desperate for a script can be quite good actors and there is no way for a GP to know what their history is, how many scripts they have obtained that week, or whether they are taking part in a treatment program such as the methadone or naltrexone programs. It would become much more difficult for substance abusers to obtain these prescription drugs if there was some kind of limit—which I would support—that would set off alarm bells if the limit was reached.

People's lives are at stake here and it is important to have the courage to put in place this kind of initiative. We owe it to the parents of the kids who have become mixed up with drugs. They come to these inquiries expressing their anger and amazement at how easy it is to obtain these drugs quite legally through our health system. If we do not accept that we need to accurately record and police doctor shopping, we are, in a sense, accepting a legally sanctioned drug trade.

Another issue worth noting in the debate on the PBS is the concern that many of the drugs that feature on the top 10 prescribed items in Australia are for ailments that could also be treated by a healthier lifestyle. In 1998, doctors wrote 4.2 million prescriptions for simvastatin, a drug that helps to lower cholesterol. This cost the government $191 million in one year alone, as it was the number one drug on the PBS in terms of expenditure. Australians are fast catching up with people in the United States in adopting a more sedentary lifestyle. Combine that with a high consumption of saturated fats and refined carbohydrates and it does not take a doctor to work out which direction our cholesterol levels are heading in this country—and it is certainly not south. I know there are some people who are genetically predisposed to having high cholesterol levels because their livers produce too much, but many cases are lifestyle induced.

Another drug in the top 10 prescribed medicines is temazepam, which treats short-term insomnia in adults. Doctors wrote out 3.3 million of these prescriptions in 1998. This is a reflection of the increasingly stressful lifestyles many of us have, and it is of great concern to me that patients will continue to rely on sleeping pills to alleviate a symptom rather than treat the cause. Temazepam is also a favourite drug of choice for substance abusers.

It is important to ensure money is spent on education campaigns that focus on lifestyle and preventative medicine if we want to maintain a viable PBS. It is also important for the health and wellbeing of our community. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 that is before us today has one major aim: to prevent the fraudulent use of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, particularly by tourists, overseas visitors, those with nonresident status and Australian doctor shoppers. The introduction of measures preventing the misuse of Australian taxpayers' money is something that Labor supports unreservedly. Therefore, it is not surprising that we are supporting this bill.

speech.para: While the extent and cost of this type of PBS abuse is unknown, the government estimates that the measures it will put in place will save about $16 million per year over the next five years, or 0.55 per cent of last year's total PBS expenditure. In order to achieve these savings, doctors will have to ensure that they record a patient's Medicare number on each PBS prescription. The patient will have to ensure that they are able to present their Medicare number with their prescription to the pharmacist for verification. The pharmacist will have to check the Medicare number against the number on the prescription and record it on their computer database. Finally, the HIC check the number recorded against their own database to make sure they match.

In order that these savings can be realised, the cost of operating the system will have to be less than 15c per prescription. If it costs that or more, the savings generated by the system will be eaten up by administration costs. So the government has to rely on the goodwill of general practitioners and pharmacists in the hope that they will not ask for additional payment for the additional work and time that it will take to operate this system. I would imagine that, for pharmacists, the free provision of this additional service will be doubly inconvenient.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the King's School in Parramatta is planning to spend $16 million to upgrade the school's already impressive facilities? Is the Prime Minister also aware that King's has just announced in this magnificent brochure that it plans to spend $3.5 million to build a learning and leadership centre which will contain a library, information technology centre, leadership centre and museum? Prime Minister, with its fantastic existing facilities and its $16 million building plans, why you do believe that the King's School needs an extra $1.4 million a year in federal funding when needy government and non-government school parents have to hold fetes, quiz nights and barbecues just to repair buildings and buy basic sporting equipment?

—The answer to the first part of the question is no, I do not examine the brochures put out by every school around Australia. I do, however, examine the outcomes of the application of the new policy introduced by the government. That examination demonstrates to me the essential fairness of the new SES system. That new system means that schools like the King's School will end up receiving vastly less resources from the government than the more needy independent schools. Instead of playing this rather old-fashioned, very foolish class game that the Australian Labor Party is playing which we have seen introduced into this debate—I might say promoted this morning by an article in the Sydney Morning Herald that purports to list the schools attended by different members of the frontbench of both the government and the opposition—I would have thought that what is relevant is not what school you went to or what school your children went to but the quality of your policy. I decry absolutely the way in which the Labor Party and others have sought to smear people by some reference to the school they went to. I simply say to you, Mr Speaker, that the Labor Party is trying to introduce the politics of class and envy into this debate.

answer.para: The real evidence of that is to actually analyse what the leaders of the Catholic system and the leaders of all the other independent school groupings in Australia have said. Without exception, the leaders of the Catholic education system, the leaders of the independent schools, the leaders of the Christian schools and the leaders of all the other non-government schools have applauded the government system on the grounds of fairness. Even more importantly, and it must be ringing in the ears of the Leader of the Opposition, every single Labor Premier who came to the meeting last Friday endorsed without qualification the government's new funding formula—every last one of them. During the discussion they were given the opportunity, and they all said, `We don't want a cent taken away from independent schools.' That is what Peter Beattie said. He did not wave brochures around at me. He did not play the politics of class. He did not play the class card, as the Leader of the Opposition is doing. It is a tawdry attempt by the Leader of the Opposition to play the class card—a very tawdry attempt. The reality is that the new funding formula will result in the neediest non-government schools getting the most help and the less needy getting the least help. That is eminently fair on any measure.

talk.start.para: —The difference between them has changed dramatically, and you know it.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has asked his question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of Australia's aims for the forthcoming climate change negotiations to be held in The Hague on 13 November? Is the minister aware of any alternate policies?

—First, I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for her question and recognise the stalwart support she gives to her constituents as the government addresses this difficult issue. This government has said all along that Australia is prepared to make a fair contribution to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and that has been a consistent position of this government. But what we have also said is that we are not prepared to carry an unfair share of the burden. When the government, represented by Senator Hill and officials from a number of departments, goes to the sixth Conference of the Parties in The Hague, we will attempt to achieve an outcome which minimises the cost to Australia of implementing the Kyoto protocol. The two most important issues for us in that respect will be securing workable and efficient rules for sinks and for international emissions trading and the other flexibility mechanisms in the protocol. Successful outcomes on these issues would not only reduce the impact on our economy but also increase the likelihood of countries with greenhouse targets under the Kyoto protocol actually being able to meet those targets. Such a sensible outcome in The Hague will maximise the likelihood of achieving the protocol's environment objectives.

answer.para: This country has already taken a lead with domestic greenhouse programs totalling nearly $1 billion over five years. But climate change is a global issue and it requires global solutions, especially with emissions from developing countries set to exceed those of developed countries within the next decade. Commitments by large developing country emitters will be necessary, otherwise jobs in energy intensive industries could move from Australia to developing countries without any environmental benefit whatsoever. So the government wants to avoid a situation where Australian exporters are burdened by strict greenhouse constraints and yet some of our competitors have no constraints at all. This is an important conference, the meeting in The Hague, but I think the Australian public can rest assured that this is a government which not only takes its environmental responsibilities seriously but is prepared to stand up very strongly for Australia's interests in The Hague.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is also addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that this glossy brochure also outlines magnificent plans by King's School to build colonnades to give the school a `green heart', quadrangles `to give a beautiful ambience to the academic precinct' and an `attractive arrival point to the School [because] first impressions are important and this area will need to announce The King's School as a quality place of learning'? Prime Minister, do you think it is better to spend $1.4 million of taxpayers' money on colonnades, quadrangles and ambience for the King's School or on doubling special education funding for 3,000 students? Prime Minister, how much more ambience does King's need?
—I think it is—
—The member for Batman!
—It think it is better to have a funding policy for independent schools which results in the more needy independent schools getting a lot more, and that is exactly our policy.
—The Prime Minister has the call and I will deal very sternly with anyone who interrupts him.
—I also think it is better—
—The member for Melbourne!

—I think it is better education policy to have state governments matching rates of federal government increased support for government schools instead of lagging behind them. For example, it is my advice that in the current financial year federal government funding for government schools to the state of Queensland has risen by 4.4 per cent, whereas state government funding for government schools in Queensland has risen by only 0.8 per cent. It is my advice that federal government funding for government schools in New South Wales has risen by four per cent, yet state government funding for government schools in New South Wales has risen by only 1.9 per cent.
—So, instead of—
—The Leader of the Opposition might bear in mind my earlier comments.
—The Leader of the Opposition is warned.
—So, instead of the Labor Party desperately carrying on in this class driven fashion—

—It is a class driven fashion. They do not have any argument based on policy; they have an argument based on class and envy, and the Australian people have rejected that in the past and they will reject it again.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. Is the minister aware of any new information in relation to alternative price monitoring for Australian consumers that deals with the introduction of the new tax system? Minister, are you aware of any alternative policies and what these policies would mean for Australian consumers?

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank the member for Forde for her question. Over the last few weeks we have revealed some of the price watch information provided by the Australian Labor Party after the impact of the GST has been taken in on prices, and on reflection perhaps I have been a little bit tough on the member for Lilley.

answer.para: Government members—Really!

talk.start.para: —I have. I know it is hard for some on this side to believe—and some people in the Labor Party do not believe me either. I have been a little bit harsh, because I thought that the member for Lilley was the only person running a price watch program on the Labor Party side of the House. That was before some information was presented to me in relation to another Queensland member of the Labor Party. I happened to come across a copy of the Southern Star, which has the words:

quote.para: I have decided to establish a local GST pricewatch here on the south side. It is going to take a while to set it up properly. On a monthly basis we will take a standard basket of goods and analyse price changes,” ... we will on volunteers, and so on.

answer.para: The member for Griffith runs a price watch survey for February of this year, covering Coles, Franklins and Woolworths. He talks about the GST price watch in February, talks about `70 days until the GST' in April and then we come to The Rudd Report in July. I was running a bit short of information then and I decided to go to his web site, which in fact was updated on 28 July. I went to his web site today, looked for the price watch information and I came across a price survey from February—and then it stops. So what happened to the monthly analysis for April, May, June, July, August and September? What is it with the Labor Party members from Queensland and numbers?
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —What is it? Without taking the focus off the member for Lilley, I was asked about alternative policies. I went to the member for Lilley's webpage—and he has now updated it with the August figures—and it took me a little while but I found some immortal words where the member for Lilley says in a hushed tone in the House—because they have got his words in the House:

quote.para: And that is why, we have an emphatic, an absolutely emphatic commitment to roll back the GST.

answer.para: You can press play and hear it again! If the Labor Party's own price survey says that consumers are better off with the GST, then why does the Labor Party want to roll it back? We are watching individual members of the Labor Party, we are watching the commitments they made before 1 July, and we will continue to look for their words in the printed form. When it comes to roll-back, I think Australian consumers deserve to know why the Labor Party want to make a basket at the supermarket more expensive if they ever get elected into government.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the King's School latest fundraising campaign has already raised more than $2.8 million? Is it correct that these donations are likely to attract tax concessions of up to $1.4 million? Prime Minister, if the Australian taxpayers have already given the King's School a $1.4 million tax break, why do they need another $1.4 million a year under your new school funding system?

—I am not aware of the particular fundraising activities of the King's School or, indeed, of other schools, other than a residual understanding of the fundraising activities of particular schools with which my children were associated several years ago. But I can say to the Leader of the Opposition that it is my understanding that tax deductibility of the type he referred to was, of course, maintained during the whole time the Labor Party was in government. Therefore, I assume he is not attacking that principle.

—I seek leave to table the King's School Foundation Capital Appeal, which details the extent of the tax benefit that each donation is expected to attract and is why the Labor Party included these factors in the calculation of funds they gave them.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. He cannot advance an argument in seeking leave.

—My question without notice is to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer please inform the House of the results of new surveys on the implementation of the new tax system and how this compares with the results of earlier surveys?

—I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. The House has been rather well informed by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation of the exploits of the member for Lilley in relation to his price watch activities and the exploits of the member for Griffith. We also recall the exploits of the member for Melbourne, who doctored a price survey which he put out by not releasing the full details.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. On a previous ruling of yours, where a matter has been alleged and refuted on a personal explanation, it cannot be repeated.
—The Treasurer was commenting on new surveys relative to older surveys. I felt his comment was entirely relevant. If I think he is unfairly maligning the member for Melbourne, I will take action.

—Rather than go over that episode, I will table an article from the Herald Sun of 20 July 2000 headed `Labor exposed in GST cover-up: half truths leave Beazley stranded'. I have also just come across a very interesting new survey on the new tax system, which is from the Dickson report, headed, `Results of electorate wide issues survey: responses to small business questionnaire on the GST'. The Dickson report says that, of the small business questionnaire on the GST, 53 per cent said it had a negative impact, 21 per cent said it had a positive impact, 22 per cent said it had no impact and 13 per cent made no comment. I was rather intrigued by this return because, if 53 per cent said negative and 21 per cent said positive, which would make 74 per cent, 22 per cent said no impact, which would make 96 per cent, and 13 per cent had no comment, that makes it one of the most outstanding survey results I have ever come across. The member for Dickson sends out 100 questionnaires and gets 109 replies. It is like voting for the Queensland ALP. The turnout is 109 per cent of those on the electoral roll!

answer.para: I would have thought that this is a rather obvious point because, with a pie chart, if it were more than 53 per cent, it would have to be more than half the pie; yet the 53 per cent who had a negative impact is less than half the pie, quite clearly. I am not quite sure what sort of pie chart this is. I thought it could be a porky pie chart or, if one were eating it, a humble pie chart! Whichever way it goes, it falls into a grand Queensland Labor Party tradition—the member for Dickson and the member for Griffith gilding the lily, with old Swanie there with his surveys. I table the survey for the information of the House.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, and it concerns education in regional Australia. Minister, as a King's School old boy, did you receive a copy of the brochure and the list referred to by the Leader of the Opposition which show that King's School received donations of more than $1.5 million from only 11 donors? Minister, do you believe your old school really needs an extra $1.4 million of taxpayers' money when it has access to such extraordinarily generous private donations? Minister, how many schools in rural and regional Australia—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I have not heard anything in this question so far which relates to the minister's ministerial responsibility.

—The member for Boothby is quite right: there is nothing thus far that is related to the minister's responsibility. The Chief Opposition Whip had not concluded his question. I thought he may have been going to make reference to the minister's regional responsibilities, and it was for that reason that I allowed him to continue.
—Minister, how many schools in rural and regional Australia can budget for and receive old boy donations of anything like $1.5 million?

—I note that the honourable member asked me whether I would comment as an old boy of the school. I am an old boy of the school. I regret to have to inform the class warriors opposite that I cannot apologise for that. I can acknowledge that I was fortunate to attend it. I will make a few points that I think might be relevant in this debate. Yes, there are some very wealthy parents and wealthy people involved in that school community. There are also many who are not so wealthy—there really are. There are also, I think it is fair to say, many parents in parts of the country who are not in a position to find it easy to educate their children: (a) they find it hard to raise the finances and (b) they struggle against the real problems that isolation can bring when you are trying to educate your children. Indeed, in my own case—I do not know what members of the House will make of it—I actually did not go into a classroom until I was nine years old, because of isolation. A large part of the reason I went to that school is that there were no other ready options—there really were not.

answer.para: The second part of your question goes to what we have done for schools in rural and regional areas. I will make several points about that, but the first and foremost is that I have a very large number of small independent schools in my electorate. To be even-handed about this, I want to say that I am enormously impressed—

talk.start.para: —You are obviously not really interested in any sincere answer to this—obviously not. I am enormously impressed by the quality of work that some of those schools do. There is a small independent school at Wellington in my electorate, the staff of which have consciously gone out to draw children from very disadvantaged backgrounds, including the local indigenous community. Do you know what their response is? When I went to visit them recently, they told me that what we have put in place is invaluable for their school, for their community and for the future of the children in the area. Far from advocating change, they thanked me very fulsomely for what the government have done. They believe that we have done a lot to help create a better environment of opportunity for some very severely disadvantaged children in their region. We are about choice. We are about helping parents who often have to make very agonising sacrifices, let alone the decision in the first place, before they make those sacrifices, about how they are going to educate their children. I really believe that what we have done is fair and reasonable. I believe it passes what might be called the pub test. I certainly find that in my electorate.

answer.para: I do not deny at all that the school that I went to is well off. I do not deny that. I do not deny that I was privileged and fortunate to go to it. I find it more than passing strange that the sort of sense I get around this place is that somehow, because I was fortunate enough to go there, I ought to be debarred from trying to make a contribution to public life in this country. You are just pathetic, you really are. I would also point out that I believe that choice is very important. I believe that a lot of Australian children will get better opportunities in life because of what we have done to enhance choice.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker—
—Sit down. You're a freak!
—I warn the member for Kingsford-Smith!
—I need no help from the member for Lyons, and the member for Kingsford-Smith is well aware of the fact that he was interjecting.
—I seek leave to table a document received by the minister which shows that 11 parents of King's School paid $1.5 million to the King's School foundation.

—Mr Speaker, there was an assumption in the question that I have received that document. I have not sighted that document. I may or may not have received it, but you ought not to assume it, and I see no reason why it should be tabled.

answer.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I find highly offensive a comment made by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation a couple of moments ago. I would ask that you ask him to withdraw it. Members sitting to my right also found—
—The chair is on his feet!
—Minister for Aged Care!
—We don't care what you find!
—The member for Hindmarsh will excuse herself from the House under the provisions of standing order 304A.

interjection.para: The member for Hindmarsh then left the chamber.

talk.start.para: —The member for Shortland raised a matter that I could not hear. I do not even know to which minister she was referring, and I am certainly not aware of any minister having made an offensive remark that was audible to the chair. If the member for Shortland wishes to elaborate, I will allow her to do so.

—Mr Speaker, I do not think it is appropriate that I use the word in this House, and the minister for forestry was the minister in question. His remark was highly offensive and heard by a number of members here.
—The member for Shortland will resume her seat. If the Minister for Forestry and Conservation made a remark that was unparliamentary, I would ask him to withdraw it.
—I have made no unparliamentary remark.
—The Minister for Forestry and Conservation will at least do the chair the courtesy of rising and coming to the dispatch box.
—The member for Maribyrnong will also be dealt with shortly.
—Mr Speaker, I made no comment that could be considered unparliamentary. To test that, I will allow you to make the judgment. I called him a creep.
—You did not!
—If you rule that unparliamentary, I will withdraw it.

—The Minister for Forestry and Conservation will resume his seat. I find the comment by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation as offensive to me as the comment regularly used by the member for Maribyrnong about the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. I would ask them both to desist; neither was unparliamentary, both were undesirable.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment Services. Is the minister aware of any recent research into the performance of Job Network? What evidence exists to show that the government's employment services are performing well at a local level? Furthermore, is the minister aware of any alternative policies in this area?

—I thank the member for Wannon for his question, and I note that unemployment in his area has fallen from a peak of nearly 10 per cent to 6.5 per cent now, thanks in large measure to the policies of the Howard government. I am aware of a questionnaire being distributed by the member for Newcastle, along with an advertisement for a Labor Party fundraising dinner. Surveys of the type being distributed by the member for Newcastle are as easy to rort as membership of the Queensland Labor Party, and the results of any such surveys are as dodgy as the Queensland electoral rolls when people like the member for Lilley are referred to as the `master' of the rolls.
—I find that comment offensive, Mr Speaker, and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—What about forging letters?
—We are asking you.

—I warn the Manager of Opposition Business. On reflection, I withdraw that warning because I am unaware of who was interjecting on the government side, but members on both sides must be aware that that was quite unacceptable. I have to inform the member for Lilley that, as he is well aware—and this is not a criticism—I was in a conversation about a parliamentary matter with the member for Dickson and, for that reason, did not hear the remark made. I am not avoiding the issue. I simply did not hear the remark made. So I do not know whether it was parliamentary or unparliamentary. I will call the minister and ask him to exercise more restraint.
—Mr Speaker, I was simply referring to the fact that the member for Lilley was the Queensland state Labor Party secretary at a time when Labor Party members were rorting the electoral roll.
—The minister will come to the question.
—The fact is, for the benefit of the member for Newcastle—
—Mr Speaker, I was not.
—I recognise the minister and ask him to exercise more restraint.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Notwithstanding that the allegation was inaccurate, how can it in any way be a relevant answer to any question that was in order to the Minister for Employment Services.

—The Manager of Opposition Business is entirely right. As occupier of the chair I was attempting to facilitate the parliament. The member for Lilley made what was not in fact a point of order but I was accommodating enough to allow him to do that without any reprimand. It therefore seemed reasonable to me simply to recognise the minister. I would have thought that that exercise at equity would have been recognised by both sides of the House.

—For the benefit of the member for Newcastle, I can inform the House that my department has conducted scientific surveys of more than 10,000 jobseekers and employers. The surveys show that people who would use both the CES and the Job Network, and who had an opinion, preferred the Job Network by a margin of three to one. Last week the member for Dickson accused Job Network members of ripping off jobseekers, of profiteering and of kicking vulnerable people off benefits. That is what she was doing last week in this House. This week, the member for Dickson said in her electorate newsletter that organisations like East Coast Training deserve to be showcased. By all means they do, but I challenge the member for Dickson to get behind the 10 Job Network members in her area and to showcase them as well as organisations like East Coast Training.

answer.para: The Treasurer has pointed out something else in the member for Dickson's newsletter, which proves one thing: when it comes to Labor, you can never trust their numbers. The numbers that should be in the member for Dickson's newsletter are these: in March 1996, unemployment in the area of Dickson was 11.9 per cent. Today, unemployment in Dickson has come down to 4.6 per cent, thanks to the great work of the Howard government.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware that the latest edition of Great Scot, the magazine of the Scotch College family, tells parents and old boys about the recent old boys dinner in the Grant Hyatt ballroom and about the recent school cricket tour to the United Kingdom and the match against Eton College? If he did read that edition of the magazine, did he notice that Scotch's current fundraising appeal has already raised $6.2 million in donations for its new auditorium and theatre? Minister, isn't it a fact that, under your new school funding system, you take no account of the fees, fundraising and facilities at schools like Scotch and King's? Isn't your new funding system your way of making a $1 million donation to your old school?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The last question is out of order and should be withdrawn.
—I listened closely to the last question. I felt that the latter part of the question was framed in an undesirable way, but I do not think the question was out of order.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The government's policy for funding non-government schools is part of a massive investment in schooling which this government is currently making, and it produces increases in funding for non-government schools and government schools. In fact, the former school of the member for Dobell, De La Salle, has undoubtedly benefited enormously from the fair funding and the recognition of needs of the Catholic systemic and non-systemic schools under the government's funding arrangements. I do not think anybody—and I am sure the member for Dobell was not implying this—would think that the government's funding arrangements are related to the particular schools to which members of the government or the opposition went. One of the great features of this system is that it puts, for the first time, a clear downward pressure on school fees. It makes schools a great deal more accessible, regardless of the efforts that parents make. Let us make it quite clear that when the opposition talks about capital funding for these schools, this is all money raised by parents. The government is not making capital contributions to schools such as King's School. All these funds are being raised by parents.

answer.para: The government's funding arrangements for non-government schools are exceedingly fair. They are based on an objective measure of the needs of parents, not on the prejudices of the Labor Party and not on the views of the Australian Education Union—for whom you are making a very considerable down payment in this rhetoric of envy that you are producing at the present time. Schools serving high income communities will be paid 13.7 per cent of the amount that would be paid if the child went to the local government school. A school like King's, for example, will be paid at 31 per cent of the rate that would be paid if the child were sent to the local government school. So Parramatta High down the road gets $8,000 from the taxpayer and capital funding from the taxpayer. I am not saying that this is true for Parramatta High in recent times, but many government schools are getting capital grants from the taxpayer of well over $1 million, because this money is directed according to need. A school like King's, therefore, gets 31 per cent of the cost of sending a child to a government school, and that equates to $2,500 per student in 2004, compared to total government funding of $8,000 for the government school down the road.

The utter hypocrisy of the Labor Party in this matter is shown by the fact that they object to a school which principally services regional and rural Australia—where there has been a big income loss—getting 31 per cent of the cost of sending a child to a government school, whereas under their funding system they were prepared to fund a school such as Loreto Kirribilli, serving high income communities on the North Shore of Sydney, at 40 per cent. They claim that 30 per cent is too much for a school serving rural and regional Australia, but 40 per cent is not too much for a school serving well-to-do communities on the North Shore of Sydney. That is the Labor Party's utter hypocrisy on this matter.

If one wants to understand this contemptible line of questioning coming from the opposition, one only has to reflect on the fact that they desperately need the foot soldiers of the Australian Education Union out there at the polling booths at the next election. This rhetoric is just a way of making a down payment on the next election campaign. But in the end, as the Leader of the Opposition has said, he will pass this legislation in the Senate. He is so opposed to it that he will pass this legislation in the Senate. He hates it so much that it will become Labor Party policy when the Labor Party passes this bill in the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Is the Attorney-General aware of moves to disallow the Western Australian native title regime? Would the Attorney-General inform the House of the impact this move would have on Western Australia's mining and pastoral industries?

—I thank the member for Kalgoorlie for his question. It is extremely disappointing to see that the Labor Party is continuing to play its game of political chance with the state based native title regimes after allowing a Labor state to succeed in introducing its own native title regime—albeit only a half-baked scheme—in Queensland. Labor is going to knock out a scheme in a state with a coalition government.

answer.para: Mr McMullan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Manager of Opposition Business is defying the chair. The Attorney-General has the call. The Manager of Opposition Business, better than anyone else in this chamber, knows the forms of the House and what is available to him if he feels that a comment needs to be made.

—The member for Fraser, whom you have just been indirectly addressing, Mr Speaker, signalled Labor's intention to move a disallowance motion in the Senate only hours after the determination in relation to Western Australia had been tabled. With such a quick reaction there must obviously have been a very detailed consideration of the extensive explanatory statement that was tabled at the same time. The resource sector is a key industry for both WA and for Australia. It earns vital export dollars and it provides jobs for indigenous and non-indigenous people alike. The Premier of Western Australia is wont to say that Western Australia has 10 per cent of the population and produces 25 per cent of the export earnings.
—I have heard him say that.

—The Prime Minister says that he has heard him say that. The consequence of that is that uncertainty over native title has a significant impact on exploration and mining investment, with consequences for all Australians. According to the Chamber of Minerals and Energy, exploration expenditure in WA has fallen by 43 per cent from its peak in 1997; gold exploration has fallen by 60 per cent over the same period; annual exploration expenditure is $268 million a year less than in 1997; and outstanding tenement applications have grown from nil at the end of 1995 to 11,000 in 1998 due to native title complications.

answer.para: All federal members and senators have today been sent a letter seeking support for the WA regime. The letter was signed by six presidents of six organisations: the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Western Australia, the Chamber of Minerals and Energy of Western Australia, the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of WA, the WA Farmers Federation and the Forest Industries Federation—all involved with employers and providing employment to indigenous and non-indigenous people alike. In that letter, the presidents say:

quote.para: We contend that the scope for successful native title agreements between WA stakeholders could be greatly enhanced by allowing them more direct local control and involvement through the mechanisms of the proposed state legislation. Conversely, Senate full or partial rejection would seriously threaten future progress.

answer.para: Despite all this, it appears that Federal Labor is trying to compensate for its hypocritical deal on Queensland native title by threatening to throw out the WA regime. The member for Fraser is accusing the Court government of playing politics and being deliberately provocative with native title. The Court government has always made its intentions quite clear. WA wants its own solutions to native title—procedural requirements relating to certain mining tenements and compulsory acquisitions on pastoral lease and reserved land that have been specifically designed to suit WA. But it remains to be seen how Labor will explain its duplicity in the course of the coming state campaign to the people of WA, especially those in the places in the member for Kalgoorlie's electorate where mining is the lifeblood of the community, indigenous and non-indigenous alike.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon Father Michael Tate, former Minister for Justice and former Ambassador to the Netherlands and the Holy See. I am very pleased to welcome him to the gallery and extend to him a warm welcome on behalf of all members of the House.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business: Productivity

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Leader of the House and Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. My question goes to the issue of workplace productivity. Minister, can you confirm that, in the 50 sitting days until 9 October, you answered 60 dorothy dixers in question time—a productivity rate of 1.2 per day? Can you confirm that, since 9 October, your productivity rate has fallen to just 0.44 per day? This month, with no questions in four days, your productivity rate is zero—a rate beaten by even the Minister for Forestry and Conservation.

—Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I can see no validity in this question at all. I see no relevance in the preamble to whatever the question may be. I invite the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to come to a specific question.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Minister, can you think of anything that might have caused this dramatic fall-off in your productivity? If these were crane rates, wouldn't you be calling in the dogs and issuing the balaclava—
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Curtin.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—I call the honourable member for Curtin.
—Mr Speaker, I have a point of order.

—The member for Curtin will resume her seat. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition had indicated a point of order. I thought when he resumed his seat that he was not pursuing it. That was why I did not pursue it. I recognise the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The question was addressed to the minister in two capacities, one as Leader of the House with responsibility for procedure; and the second went to issues of workplace productivity. This is the minister who wants to come in with individual examples of everyone else's workplace productivity. Why won't he answer his—

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The chair has been generous in extending to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition the opportunity to make a point of order. The point of order bore no relevance to the standing orders. I deem the question quite inappropriate. I recognise the member for Curtin.

—There are obviously a number of members who do not believe that the chair intends to enforce standing orders. If they want evidence of it, they will not have to wait long in the current climate. That includes the member for McMillan. The honourable member for Curtin has the call.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Is the minister aware of concerns being expressed by the courts about the extent of litigation from his portfolio? Would the minister inform the House about the growth in litigation in his portfolio and whether this is having an impact on the taxpayer?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Curtin for her question. The reports of the High Court of Australia and the Federal Court of Australia that were tabled in the parliament last week are very instructive indeed. The report of the Federal Court records that Migration Act cases are a growing part of its workload. Since 1995-96 the number of migration cases has increased by more than 150 per cent, from 331 cases in 1995-96 to 829 cases in 1999-2000. In the court's appellate workload, migration cases in 1995-96 were eight per cent. Last year that had jumped to 36 per cent. That effectively means that people who have had a decision at first instance are appealing more frequently to the Full Federal Court.

answer.para: The High Court's report for 1999-2000 records that the increase in the migration workload has been very significant. In 1998-99 there were 25 single justice hearings involving what they call order nisi applications. By last year that had soared to 173, and 88 per cent of them involved migration matters. This trend is likely to continue. The High Court expressed concern in its annual report saying:

quote.para: These applications consume a large amount of judicial time, particularly in requiring more than one hearing.

answer.para: It is not just the courts that have been expressing this concern. I found a very interesting quote in these terms relating to the plight of the individuals who are seeking remedies. The quote is as follows:

quote.para: The real delay in the refugee determination process occurs when failed applicants decide to pursue litigation. It is the litigation process before the courts that can take years, not the determination process.

answer.para: That was a quote from a minister for immigration, but not in 2000; in 1995. It came from Senator Nick Bolkus.

It is obvious that in 1995 the Labor Party recognised that there was a problem, but it does not seem to recognise that any longer. Perhaps it might help the opposition if it were to know that those people who resort to litigation can obtain work rights or can, in fact, remain in Australia lawfully while they work illegally. At present there are 682 active litigation cases involving refugee and migration matters. Those litigants and their families could have work rights or could be working illegally. There have been 1,163 cases resolved during the past year—and, again, they could have been working lawfully or unlawfully. There are 5,000 people who are members of seven class actions currently before the courts. Many of those litigants and their families can get work rights or may be working unlawfully in Australia.

The Labor Party has professed to be concerned about people who come to Australia and breach visa conditions and work unlawfully. It professes to be concerned about people working illegally in the Australian community. But, if you take these figures and look at the almost 7,000 people who could be working—

talk.start.para: —The member for Grayndler!
—and if you add to this the dependants who could be working, you would be looking at something like 13,000 cases.

—Let me just elaborate a little. You know that we locate a very large number of people. When Labor was in office, we saw the location rates fall to something of the order of five or six thousand, and they have risen under this government to of the order of 13,000 a year. When people are located and are being removed from Australia, in well in excess of 50 per cent of the cases they admit to having been working unlawfully in Australia. The point I want to make on this is that there is a way of dealing with this important issue.
—The member for Grayndler is warned.

—If you have any concern about people working unlawfully and taking jobs from Australians, there is a way you can deal with it, and you can take the load off the courts by instituting a privative clause. In other words, you do not have to be—as you are today—part of the problem; you can be part of the solution.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer to your review of the IT outsourcing program, which you bravely announced under cover of the Melbourne Cup. Can you confirm that this program was expected to produce savings of $1 billion and that departmental budgets were reduced accordingly? Didn't the Auditor-General find that 40 per cent of the total program had produced only $70 million in savings, only a fraction of the amount budgeted for? Given that these savings are already factored into departmental budgets, how does the government intend to make up the difference—by further cutting programs and services, or by further eroding the already disappearing surplus?

—In 1997 the government announced a program which involved the market testing of information technology on a whole of government basis for the purposes of determining whether it was appropriate to outsource or not. In fact, that was a program that was first set in place by the then minister for finance, the now Leader of the Opposition. In the process of examining that in 1997, the government took into account some extensive work that had been started under Labor and it was finetuned by the government. It was a proposition at that point in time, which I still stand by, that there was capacity to make savings of about $1 billion over the seven-year life of the contract on a whole of government basis.

answer.para: The Auditor-General recently released a report in respect of the first three of some 10 contracts—in percentage terms, not yet 30 per cent of the outsourcing program. There has been a view expressed by the Auditor-General, a view which is based upon accountancy methodology, that the projected savings that were announced by the government in respect of those three contracts were not in fact as large as they might have been. In fact, those arguments become fairly academic; they are based upon net present value and things like competitive neutrality and also on whether or not there is a return of the assets and whether it is an operating lease or a financing lease.

The government stands by its methodology there, because that is backed by the Department of Finance and Administration, and it is the Office of Asset Sales and Information Technology Outsourcing that put this information together. The department of finance stands by the methodology, Treasury stands by the methodology, the Australian Bureau of Statistics stands by the methodology and several of the accountancy firms stand by the methodology. So we are now down to a point as to whether the savings are less than they were estimated or projected to be in 1997 when the program commenced.

What I can say—and nobody argues—is that there are significant savings to the Australian taxpayers. It is nice to be able to stand up here and say that a program of the government is making savings. For some 13 years, and particularly the last six years, under Labor, this House was all about the cost to the taxpayers of deficit budgets. We know just how accountable the then Labor government were when it came to managing the financial provisions of the Commonwealth. They certainly brought about significant losses—some $70 billion of general government debt in the last five budgets alone.

I think that covers the various questions that have been asked by the honourable member for Melbourne. There is a review. It is the mid-term or the midway in respect of this particular program. We have now signed on five contracts out of 10, and it is appropriate at any time for there to be a continuous improvement program in place. It was foreshadowed back in 1998 that there would be an evaluation of both the costs and the benefits. There are savings; they are significant. I stand by the methodology the government used because it is backed by independent people. I certainly stand by what this program has done for regional development and for the creation of jobs and what it has done for the information technology industry, which is a growth area of this economy. It has brought about a significant improvement in the amount of work that is occurring here. This is a growth area of the economy. Australia has significant skills, and this program is assisting the development of those skills, which is very important for the future of this nation.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of a paid political advertisement in the Australian today which opposes changes to non-government schools funding? Is the minister aware of alternative views to those expressed in this advertisement?
—The member for McMillan is warned.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Barker for his question. I am aware of a paid political advertisement that appeared in a newspaper today and was signed by 120 supporters of the Labor Party. Those legitimately concerned with funding for non-government schools would be aware of another, perhaps more credible, open letter that has been circulated to senators. This letter, which was coordinated by the National Council of Independent Schools Associations, was circulated again yesterday. The press release with which the National Council of Independent Schools Associations circulated this letter said that Australia's leaders should try to unite and lead the community on the issue of school funding, not divide it with an ill-informed attack on non-government schools. The executive director of the NCISA, Mr Thomson, said the open letter signed by 120 Australians failed the community and missed the point. He questioned the purpose and principle of those who would seek to divide the community by attacking non-government schools.

answer.para: I urge people to instead consider another open letter to the Senate signed by the leaders of Anglican schools, Christian schools, Lutheran schools, Rudolf Steiner schools, Seventh Day Adventist schools, Uniting Church schools, the heads of independent schools and the NCISA. It calls on the Senate to pass the SES legislation, which has the considered support of the independent school sector.

When it comes to the fair funding of non-government schools, who should we listen to? Sharan Burrow, the President of the ACTU, or the Archbishop of the Anglican Church of Sydney on behalf of the Anglican Church of Australia? Denis Fitzgerald or the Uniting Church of Australia? Joan Kirner or the Association of Christian Schools? The ACTU and the AEU or the National Catholic Education Commission and the Australian Catholic bishops?

The government's fairer funding reforms enjoy the support of the entire non-government sector, of all the major Australian religious groupings, of every major ethnic grouping in Australia and even of all the state premiers. Those running a campaign of opposition to these reforms show their sheer arrogance and what they are prepared to resort to to buy the votes of the Australian Education Union. The non-government schools have been working for years to find an objective, transparent, non-politicised funding system. All the Labor Party has to offer them is a return to prejudice and 19th century stereotypes. It is time for the Labor Party to come into the 21st century. As we know, the Labor Party hates this bill so much it is going to pass it. Cut the posturing and tell your senators to get on with passing the legislation.
Opposition member interjecting—

talk.start.para: —God, you're up yourself.
—Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation!
—Are you up for that too, Pete? Are you going to claim your TA like the telecard? Who paid for your unit?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—Mr Speaker, my question—

—Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I can understand why you thought you had the call. In fact, I was about to make a comment. But for your untimely intervention, I would have felt it entirely appropriate for me to require the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation to apologise for the remark he made. I am now in a situation where both gentlemen have made remarks that I would regard not as unparliamentary but as unbecoming.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer to the $2.6 billion you included in the 2000-01 budget for the asset sale of spectrum. Do you still stand by that $2.6 billion for 2000-01? If not, what will the figure be?

—I anticipated that there may be a question in respect of the midyear economic and fiscal outlook and what it might show, because the Treasurer has indicated that that will be released very soon. I would simply indicate to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he should wait until the midyear economic and fiscal outlook is there. Let me also say that as a general rule I do not comment on what the government might expect from any particular asset sale. I do not intend to comment on what we might receive. There are obvious reasons why I would not, and I am sure the Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows that. I think I can just leave it at that.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the minister advise the House of developments in the introduction of greater competition and diversity in the domestic aviation market. Is it a fact that the standard of service is well ahead of most OECD countries, including the USA, where Bush and Gore may be down to the wire but where you are lucky to get a coke or coffee on a midnight flight?
—The member for Lyons is warned! The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services will ignore the latter part of that question.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Farrer for his question. I note his interest in transport matters, although it usually extends to rail to a greater extent than it does to aviation. I am, nonetheless, delighted to be able to inform the House that the government's policy of encouraging new airline entrants and their activities in the domestic market in this country is really now paying off in a big way. Australian travellers, of course, as we have all noted through the media—and many have noted through booking air fares themselves—are benefiting from a range of excellent discount fares being offered by all airlines in response to very strong marketing by Impulse and Virgin Blue.

answer.para: Many people who have not previously flown, or who have not flown regularly, are now taking to the skies in a big way. This has resulted in a very significant increase in the size of the domestic aviation market. August statistics reveal that the growth of the total aviation market in Australia over the last 12 months has been of the order of 150,000 passengers. It has been even higher, relatively speaking, on the most competitive routes: Sydney-Melbourne is up by 78,000 passengers and Brisbane-Sydney is up by 37,000 passengers.

Both Impulse Airlines and Virgin Blue are now recording very healthy load factors. They both seem to be in a very good position to participate in the long term in this very competitive industry. Not only will there be new opportunities on the busy east coast sector but also, and more importantly, there will be more choices for Australian consumers elsewhere. There is plenty of scope for more competition on many more routes. I know those from Western Australia, for example, are watching with great interest, but so are people in rural and regional areas. I believe that there is very good reason for the airlines to accept, to recognise and to act on the importance of maintaining and increasing their services in regional parts of the country. We have seen the ushering in of a new period of affordable airline travel. We are seeing real benefits for the Australian tourism industry, in particular. We are also seeing more jobs in the airline industry as the new entrants establish themselves well and truly on the local scene.

All of these government policies—from the very important economic fundamentals that have made investment easier and more attractive through to the leasing of the major airlines, the improvement in terminal facilities and the diversification of operations that that has encouraged and, of course, particularly in relation to Sydney airport, the reservation of slots for new entrants under the slots management scheme—have undergirded and, indeed, encouraged this major expansion in our aviation industry to the benefit of travellers, to the benefit of tourism and to the benefit of jobs growth.

subdebateinfo.title: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, can you confirm that on Monday this week you spoke to the member for Sturt regarding his new role as Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters? Isn't it a fact that you did so for two reasons: (1) so that you could instruct him as to how to conduct the committee's future proceedings to the advantage of the Liberal Party and (2)—
—The Manager of Opposition Business is aware that under standing order 144 imputations are out of order. There is a distinct imputation in that question.
—What was the imputation, Mr Speaker?
—The allegation is that the Prime Minister instructed the member for Sturt in the way in which he may go about his parliamentary duties.
—That is the question that I want to ask him, yes.
—I am aware of that. I am saying that the question is not appropriately framed.
—The Prime Minister can deny it, Mr Speaker.
—There is no point; there is not a matter of—
—The member for Chifley is warned!
—Mr Speaker—
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is warned.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is simply that the question clearly contained an allegation. There are proper forms for people to make allegations. They cannot be made under the cover of a question. On that basis, the proper course of action is for the question as it is to be ruled out of order and for the Speaker to look to the other side for the next question.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the statements made by the honourable member for Fraser were preceded by the interrogative. It is a perfectly reasonable thing under standing orders to ask whether or not a matter is a fact. The member proceeded with this introduction: `Isn't it a fact that you did so for two reasons'. It is a perfectly appropriate question. There is no other way of ascertaining the reasons that the Prime Minister went down this particular road and proceeded to sack others on the way through. It is put in the interrogative and it is open to the Prime Minister to answer it.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Whether a proposition is put in an interrogative form or any other form—
—The member for Prospect is warned.

—the fact of the matter is that there is no form under the standing orders which allows you to disguise an allegation. An allegation of a statement of so-called fact—`is it a fact?'—is nonetheless clearly an imputation, clearly it is out of order and, on that basis, the question should be rejected, as I believe you have done.
—I have.

—If you rule that it is not proper to ask, `Is it a fact that you behaved in this manner?' it means that it is not possible to raise any question concerning allegations of improper behaviour by ministers. On your interpretation, Mr Speaker, we could not have asked, `Is it a fact that you misused your telephone card?' That would have been a question that you say we could not ask. I put it to you that that is reducing the capacity of people to interrogate ministers far below the level that accountability requires.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 147 gives you clear rights as the chair. It says clearly:

quote.para: The Speaker may direct that the language of a question be changed if it seems to the Speaker unbecoming or not in conformity with the standing orders of the House.

interjection.para: That gives you clear orders in that area.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Page for the reassurance.

—Mr Speaker, while we persist with the points of order and would like you to reflect on them, I am quite prepared to seek to rephrase the question if it will help you. I do not resile from the points of order, and we would like you subsequently to rule on them. I appreciate we are getting the House in a difficult situation.

—The House is not in a difficult situation. It is perfectly clear to the chair that the question was out of order because of the imputations contained in the question. As occupier of the chair, I have endeavoured to accommodate a wide range of questions, which have sometimes included argument, even inference, as ruled out of order under standing order 145, in order to allow the maximum level of penetration of government ministers as the parliament should be able to facilitate. In this instance, however, as I am sure the Manager of Opposition Business is aware, the question was framed in such a way as to make allegations and imputations that could not be allowed to stand unchallenged. I will allow the Manager of Opposition Business to rephrase the question.

—Mr Speaker, my question is in three parts and it is to the Prime Minister. I will seek to rephrase the first part. Prime Minister, did you instruct the member for Sturt as to how he should conduct the proceedings of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters? Secondly, did you move aside the previous chairman, the member for Eden-Monaro, because of concern over allegations—
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. This question is clearly out of order because the committees in this place elect the chairs. The question is, therefore, clearly out of order.
—The member for Port Adelaide is warned. I call the Manager of Opposition Business.
—before that committee of his earlier involvement in Liberal Party push polling, breaches of electoral disclosure rules and unlawful use of Northern Territory taxpayers' funds?
—The Manager of Opposition Business has a third question?

—Yes. Thirdly, Prime Minister, will you refer the possible breaches of the law contained in these allegations to the Australian Federal Police with the same alacrity with which you referred the weekend allegations in the Courier-Mail?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I make two points: firstly, the allegations against both the Prime Minister and the member for Eden-Monaro are of such a character that they require a substantive motion, with notice, to the members concerned; secondly—and I refer to page 511 of House of Representatives Practice—this committee is yet to conduct its inquiry and there is a significant risk that this line of questioning will anticipate the findings of the report. It is an assault on the committee and the parliament should not stand for it.
—I consider that of the three questions asked by the Manager of Opposition Business the second question also made an unreasonable imputation. I will allow questions one and three to stand.

—In answer to the Manager of Opposition Business let me say that, in all the time that I have known him, the member for Sturt has not been one who has been inclined to take instructions from anybody—let alone from me. I have always found him to be a rather independent spirit. I have frequent discussions with all of my colleagues. As the member for Sturt would acknowledge, I am an inclusive leader. All I can say is that the discussions I have with my colleagues are eminently proper. I also remind the Manager of Opposition Business that, in relation to the member for Eden-Monaro, I actually heard the member for Eden-Monaro on the airwaves, when I was out on an early morning constitutional, explaining why he was no longer going to be chairman of that particular committee. I thought it had to do with a commitment to his electors, which of course is characteristic of both the member for Sturt and the member for Eden-Monaro.

answer.para: As to the question of allegations, my view in relation to allegations made against people is that if they ought to be referred to the police they will be. Insofar as they are brought to my attention, it has always been my practice, where it is appropriate, that they be referred. I would remind the Manager of Opposition Business that there were some extremely woolly allegations made—they would hardly merit the description of `serious allegations'—on the 7.30 Report by Brian Courtice, a former member of this House. They were referred by me to the Minister for Justice and Customs the following day. Unlike the Evans-Beazley protocol, we act quickly.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Would the minister advise the House of any new national tourism initiative aimed at growing the domestic market and what impact this will have on tourism activity and jobs throughout Australia?

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —I commend the member on his interest in tourism. I know that as a former New South Wales minister for tourism working under the previous Hawke-Keating governments he had extreme trouble getting a unified approach to growing the domestic tourism pie. It has been the leadership of this government that has put up $8 million to join a $16 million domestic tourism initiative that is going to grow the domestic pie. This has culminated in the launch this week of an advertising campaign right across Australia using Ernie Dingo telling Australians to take their holidays in Australia. With this program we particularly hope to grow the tourism pie. Rather than leaving our state tourism ministers to fight amongst themselves over pieces of the pie, we are actually going to grow domestic tourism in Australia. It really comes from the leadership that this government has shown in developing this program. We have had Labor for the last 12 months running a big scare campaign on the effects of the GST. We have seen this in the electorates of Lilley, Griffith and Dickson, with predictions of the terrible impacts that were going to come that have not shown through. We have already seen international tourism growing at nearly double-digit figures. With this program working in a unified way across Australia, we certainly expect to see the same with domestic tourism.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, can you confirm that the 2000 budget assumes that you sell the rest of Telstra and therefore includes a reduced amount of public debt interest outlays? After offsetting lost dividends, how much is this amount? Minister, if you do not know, will you report back to the House later today with the answer?
