—The budgets which have been delivered now for five years by the coalition government have adopted the same methodology when it came to asset sales that was applied by the previous Labor government for some 13 years. As I indicated in answer to a question earlier in question time, it is not the practice of governments to speculate on what any particular sale might bring. Clearly, one does not speculate for reasons of not giving any indication to the market as to what the government considers the value might be or might not be. The same methodology is adopted in preparing the budget on asset sales as was used by the former Labor government, and the government will continue to apply that methodology. If the honourable member wants to find out what was in the 2000 budget, I suggest that, despite the fact that it is now six months since the documents were released, he might go back and have a look at what was in those papers and examine them a little more thoroughly. But the methodology is the same and I do not intend to speculate or change that. It will not be the practice of this government to change what was previously done by the Labor government when it came to questions of asset sales.

—My question is to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House of recent developments in Australia's trade with East Asia? How will the forthcoming APEC meetings in Brunei help to increase Australia's export opportunities, and are you aware of any threats to Australia's export prospects in the region?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. He obviously takes a great deal of interest, representing an electorate that does a considerable amount of export business for Australia. It is interesting to note that, three years after the start of the Asian economic crisis, Australia's merchandise exports to East Asia are at a record high of $55.8 billion. Exports to East Asia are now 66 per cent above the lowest level during the crisis, which was in February 1999. During that time of the Asian economic crisis, Australia diversified into new markets, showing that the government's Asia-plus trade strategy was exactly what was required during that period. We have maintained those new markets as well as regaining our market share within East Asia. Some of the spectacular export performers into that East Asian market are interesting to note. For example, oilseed exports to China have increased from $64,000 worth in 1996 to $406 million worth in 1999-2000. I spoke about our automotive exports yesterday. In 1996 we exported $31 million worth of car parts to Korea. In 1999-2000 that is $103 million worth—certainly a significant increase over that period of time.

answer.para: Later this week the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I will be going to the APEC ministerial meeting in Brunei, and next week the Prime Minister will attend the leaders' meeting in Brunei. Australia has worked within the regional forum of APEC to underpin the success in Asia and East Asia as we have fought back since the depths of the economic crisis. Australia has led the way in strengthening the reporting of progress towards the APEC goals of free and open trade and investment with policies such as the electronic individual action plan, which we presented and led the way with in the ministerial meeting in Darwin earlier this year. Also at that ministerial meeting in Darwin, which I chaired, we agreed to the launch of the BizAPEC.com web site, which gives exporters an opportunity to go through a single portal and access new markets, getting market intelligence and information off the web. Since we launched that BizAPEC site in June of this year, the Australian business community has responded enthusiastically to the site, with the latest statistics showing an average of over 12,000 hits per month from Australian businesses accessing market information through the BizAPEC site. Of course, that will get further endorsement at the Brunei meeting next week.

We all know, and Australian exporters know, that the only threat to the current success of Australia's exporters is a possibility of the election of a Labor government in the future and rolling back a lot of the economic reforms we have introduced in this country that have provided a very sound economic base domestically within Australia from which they can launch themselves into the international marketplace. As the statistics continue to show, they have been doing that during our period of government since 1996.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, I address a question to you regarding the conduct of the proceedings of the House. I preface my question by referring to standing order 144 about the content of questions. Also, it is asked in the wake of your ruling concerning the question asked by the Manager of Opposition Business and it relates to what amounts to an imputation. You would be aware that, during question time, a question asked of the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs by the member for Dobell contained what some would have seen as an imputation that a decision taken by the minister was not based on public policy grounds but on personal prejudice—in other words, a desire to deliver a million dollars to the school attended by the minister. Whilst naturally I reject that allegation, I accept that it would be consistent with the rules of the House for the member to make that allegation in a debate or in a substantive motion and it would be dealt with in the ordinary fashion. But am I to infer and is the government entitled to infer from your ruling in relation to the earlier question I referred to—that is the one asked by the Manager of Opposition Business—that in future an imputation of that kind against that minister, or indeed against another minister, of a similar character will be regarded as out of order, because quite plainly it is an imputation? I found it highly offensive and I am sure the minister did too.
—Mr Speaker—
—The Prime Minister has in fact not raised a point of order but has asked for a comment from me. What does the member for Dobell wish to do?
—To comment on the same matter, Mr Speaker.
—I call the member for Dobell, on the same matter.
—If I need to raise a point of order on the Prime Minister's question, I will, but I will address it to you as a question on the same matter.
—I will hear the member for Dobell.

—You will remember, Mr Speaker, that when I asked my question a member of the government took a point of order on the part of the question that the Prime Minister seems to be taking exception to—I think it was the member for Boothby but I might be wrong. You ruled on that point of order, that you allowed that part of the question to stand, and I do not think it is proper for the Prime Minister to seek to revisit your ruling by way of a question to you.

—The member for Dobell will resume his seat. It is entirely proper for the Prime Minister to ask the question he has asked and I am very happy to consider it, consistent with the rulings that I have already made today. The Prime Minister may also have noted that a similar imputation was contained in a question that I think was asked of the Deputy Prime Minister.
—No, Mr Speaker; that is not so.
—I will check the record and if I am in error I will indicate that to the member for Dobell.
—Mr Speaker—
—I am currently addressing the House. I am not aware of having said anything that would prompt a point of order.
—My point of order, Mr Speaker, is that I was the person who asked the Deputy Prime Minister that question, and you are reflecting on me by saying that.

—The Chief Opposition Whip will resume his seat. As the Chief Opposition Whip would be plainly aware, the chair has just gone out of its way to indicate to the member for Dobell that if there were anything in error in what had been said by the chair I would address that.

answer.para: The Prime Minister has raised a very valid point about the whole question of the level of imputation contained in questions and, not surprisingly, I had opened the standingorders at 144. As everyone is aware, under standing order 144 questions should not contain arguments, inferences, imputations, epithets, ironical expressions or hypothetical matter. If I were to apply that rule rigidly, few questions would survive. On the other hand, there are imputations made that ought not be allowed to stand and, in an effort to be consistent, I ruled a question out of order today because it did contain imputations that I felt were highly disorderly.

I will look at the issue raised by the Prime Minister and report back to the House beyond the next fortnight recess. I believe that in fact the questions that have been allowed have been consistent with questions allowed in the past, but I am more than happy to check what questions have been allowed in the past to ensure that we are not creating a precedent and that the opportunity for members to ask questions is not being eroded and neither is the integrity of the parliament being eroded by the questions asked. The Prime Minister has made a valid point about an issue that caused me a great deal of concern today and for that reason I am happy to pursue it.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, we have no objection to that practice but could I ask you in the process—
—Oh! After all, he is only the Speaker!

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs! The whole parliament exists so that people can in fact have a free exchange of views. There is never a licence for anyone to interrupt anyone else who is addressing the parliament in a parliamentary manner.

—Mr Speaker, I repeat that I am not rising to express concern about that but to ask you to consider at the same time a second matter, which is the related question of the imputations included in answers. I refer, for example, to today and the answer given by the Minister for Employment Services, but it is only one in a long series of such answers. I understand the difficulty of the standing orders in both matters and simply ask that, when you are considering one, you report in a balanced manner on both. I appreciate that they are both difficult for you. I am very content with your suggestion that you should take them away and consider them, but I would ask you to consider that at the same time.

—I thank the Manager of Opposition Business. I would ask all members to reflect on the fact that of course none of these interventions are necessary if we merely extend to each other the courtesies that we expect to have extended to ourselves.

—I wish to raise a matter of privilege and the contempt of the parliament. It concerns Corporal Craig Smith, formerly a member of 3RAR. I apologise to you, Mr Speaker, and to all honourable members for not having raised this matter on Monday, the earliest opportunity I had. However, I wished to extend the courtesy to all members of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of advising them of my intention to raise this matter with you at our regular meeting on Tuesday evening.

speech.para: Following a resolution of the Main Committee on 28 August 2000, terms of reference were agreed for the subcommittee's current inquiry into the conduct of military justice and the alleged events in 3RAR. I table the terms of reference.

At its meeting of 3 October, the subcommittee debated whether or not, for its hearing on 6 October, it would need to produce for its own credibility one public witness who could convey the entrenched nature of the brutality. The committee resolved to accept Corporal Smith's courageous offer to appear as the sole public witness from 3RAR. Other witnesses appeared in camera. I table the minutes of the meeting.

You may be aware that Corporal Smith claimed that he had already been victimised because of his acceptance of the role of defender of Private Nishimura against charges. The role of defender is to ensure that the proceedings are fair. Further, he claimed that he had been threatened afterwards, that he would be drummed out of 3RAR and that his career was over. This material can be examined in the public record of the interim Hansard transcripts at pages 39 to 42 and in the publicly released submission of Corporal Smith, which has certain words blacked out, making it suitable for release. The balance of the submission has been retained as a confidential submission, available to you from the secretariat. I table the publicly released submission of Corporal Smith and the transcript.

Clearly, on 6 October, the committee was concerned about the protection of its witnesses, those who appeared in public and in camera. I wish specifically to draw your attention to questions asked by me to Admiral Barrie, the Chief of the Defence Force, and his answers which appear in the interim Hansard transcript of evidence at pages 7 to 8. I table the transcript.

The story of the victimisation to which Corporal Smith was subjected was broken by the ABC news and Lateline on Monday night, 6 November, and again on 7 November. I have videos of those programs for you—they are a bit difficult to table.

The death threat graffitied over his barracks at Duntroon was, thankfully, not broadcast in toto. It remained there for some days. He had personal property damaged and he has been removed from barracks to private accommodation for what I understand has been his own safety. I am not privy to the precise nature of these arrangements.
I also table transcripts of the Lateline program for 6 November and of ABC News Online concerning the reactions of the Minister for Defence, Mr Moore, and those of Major General Simon Willis.

I am unaware of any communication to the committee by ministers, by the ADF or by the Army about the recent incidents surrounding Corporal Smith. While the committee hopes to table an interim report, its examination of these matters is far from over and inevitably further witnesses are sought and will be called.

I believe that all members of this parliament owe a duty of care to those young men and women who voluntarily put themselves in harm's way in the national interest and serve this country so well. Given the nature of their service, an examination of military justice is an important issue for them.

It is fundamental to the proper workings of this parliament that witnesses who come forward to parliamentary committees are not subjected to any form of discrimination or victimisation as a result of evidence tendered to a parliamentary committee. The committees and the parliament must protect its witnesses. These matters are addressed in House of Representatives Practice, Barlin edition, pages 667 to 669 dealing with committees. If I might just quote one section:

quote.para: Witnesses are protected from arrest (other than on criminal charges), molestation, tampering or other acts aimed at deterring them from giving evidence before a committee or punishing or penalising them for having given such evidence under the traditional power of the House to punish contempts.

speech.para: I table those relevant pages as well. I believe that Corporal Craig Stephen Smith has been a victim of such discrimination and victimisation. I urge you to act promptly on the matters which I have raised today. I seek leave to table the documents referred to.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I will look at the matters raised by the member for Chifley. Clearly, any matter of privilege is a matter of major concern to the House. I would also expect the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to consider the matters raised and report back to me.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The member for Lilley may proceed.

—An article in today's Australian entitled `Rort claims embroil ALP frontbencher' suggests that I may be involved in the matters currently being investigated by the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission's Shepherdson inquiry. This article follows on from the slur in the House yesterday by the Minister for Community Services, the member for Richmond, that I was `cooking the books and getting more people on the electoral roll'. I totally reject the minister's unsubstantiated allegation and slur. To the best of my knowledge, there has been no evidence or allegation to the Shepherdson inquiry of improper conduct on my part. Today's Australian article suggests that I may be forced to give evidence to both the Shepherdson inquiry and the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I have not been approached to give evidence before the Shepherdson inquiry or the committee of any other relevant state or Commonwealth authority. If I am so approached, I will happily provide whatever information is required, because I have done nothing wrong and have nothing to hide in these matters.

speech.para: Also in question time today, the Minister for Employment Services said that I was the state secretary or campaign director of the ALP during the period the Shepherdson inquiry is looking into. The terms of reference of that inquiry do not include the period when I was state secretary or campaign director of the Queensland ALP.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I have a question about process, and I refer particularly to standing order 75. On two occasions today, members raised with you language which they found personally offensive. In both cases, you indicated that you had not heard the expressions. In the past, when a person found language offensive, you have asked the person who uttered it to withdraw it, partly as a courtesy and partly because you had not heard it and therefore could not adjudicate. In both cases today, you converted the issue to `unparliamentary' rather than `offensive' language. I am curious about this because the word `unparliamentary' does not appear in standing orders 75, 77 or 78. The incident seemed disorderly and offensive, but now the operative word is `unparliamentary'. I know that the judgment of that is difficult if you have not heard it, but in the past you took the view that, if a person was offended, it was appropriate for it to be withdrawn. Today that was not the case, so could you clarify the situation?

—I will seek to clarify the matter. Clearly, unparliamentary terms are out of order, and, as the member for Newcastle has indicated, anyone has the right to indicate that they have been offended by the use of a particular term. No-one in the House would want to be in a situation where people were alleging that a term was offensive when in fact it was a relatively flippant term. I sought clarification from the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, if my memory serves me well. He indicated the term he had used. As I said, I did not consider it appropriate. I did not require him to withdraw it—once again I am going by memory, and I will check the Hansard—there being, regrettably, another inappropriate and potentially offensive term used by someone else. I simply felt that the procedure and the dignity of the House were not being assisted by the whole procedure and that there had been fault on both sides. If members feel that the terms used are offensive and ought to be withdrawn, then on the assumption that the accusation is made because someone is genuinely offended I will of course enforce standing order 75.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Dickson claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, yet again.
—The member for Dickson may proceed.

—In question time today, the Minister for Employment Services misrepresented me when he said that I had attacked Job Network providers for ripping people off and profiteering. What in fact I have said in press releases and in speeches in this place is that there is no independent, transparent monitoring of Job Network which allows questions about the allocation of funding for training to be answered accountably. I drew a distinction between the government's design of the system and the work of the providers.

—Mr Speaker, may I also take this opportunity to ask you, on the matter of imputation, inferences in answers and standing order 144, to consider the question of what protection is afforded to members when their personal explanations are ignored and incorrect allegations on the same matter are repeated regularly by the same person in question time?

—If the member for Dickson is frankly seeking to have the standing orders amended, which is not clearly in the power of the chair, I think I have interpreted the standing orders more literally than some of my predecessors in indicating, on an occasion within the last month or so, that since a member of the opposition had stated that the allegation could not be substantiated and that it was something that they had not done it ought not to be pursued. I would stand by that, and I think that that is a matter of common courtesy.

answer.para: I must, however, point out to the House—and this is a matter I have discussed with the Manager of Opposition Business—that everyone in the House has the right to raise issues that they believe are of concern. While the chair will endeavour on all occasions to maintain, as we frequently say, the dignity of the House, the chair cannot stop other members from making allegations if they genuinely believe them to have occurred. This is a bind for all occupiers of the chair. I have endeavoured to be as literal in my interpretation of the standing orders as I can, and my interpretation has been more literal than those of some of my predecessors.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise a matter of privilege. The matter concerns the reversal today by government members of a decision made last week by the JCPAA to establish a full public inquiry into IT outsourcing. Given that the government last night announced a review of IT outsourcing, the circumstances suggest that the deliberations of the committee may have been conveyed, by whatever means, to the government. Today at a meeting, government members voted to replace the inquiry with a roundtable hearing early next year. I raise with you as a matter of privilege the apparent, unauthorised disclosure.

—I will, of course, deal with the matter raised by the member for Kingston, as I indicated I would deal with the matter raised by the member for Chifley. I will look at the evidence the member for Kingston has, but the custom in the House has been for the committee to look at the evidence and then report initially to the Speaker's office, to the Speaker and then to the House.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Newcastle claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—This afternoon in question time the Minister for Employment Services referred to a survey on Job Network which I distributed in my electorate. In his comments, he alluded to rorting and to electoral fraud of some kind or other and he associated that with the survey. The inferences and imputations that he made were absolutely incorrect and were insulting, not just to me but to the whole of the Newcastle community, to Job Network providers and to their consumers.
—Manager of Opposition Business! Member for Dickson! You are not really facilitating the general standard of the House at this point in time.
—Mr Speaker, as you know, one of my many onerous chores is to table papers!
—Member for Lalor! The Leader of the House has done nothing more than engage in a good-natured exchange, which once again has been misrepresented.

—I may well have been misrepresented, but I was not going to seek leave to make a personal explanation! Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:

motion.para: That the House take note of the following paper:
Department of Finance and Administration: Service charters in the Australian Public ServiceReport for 1999-2000.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Melbourne proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The government's failure to prudently manage the Commonwealth's finances.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Earlier this year, the Minister for Finance and Administration received an award. Unfortunately, not many members of the House would be aware of this award because the government and the minister chose not to publicise the fact that he had received it. It was not, as you might expect, something like the `euro money award for finance minister of the year' or anything of that nature. The award he received was the wooden spoon for privatisers. He is the worst privatiser and the most generous with taxpayers' money in the history of Australia. The award was given in a book entitled Privatisation: Sell Off or Sell Out? by Professor Bob Walker and Betty Walker, which was published only a couple of months ago. The minister has been deemed to be the biggest waster of taxpayers' money in Australia's history. And he did not win only the gold medal for privatised wastage; he also got second place for the sale of the State Bank of New South Wales. So Telstra 1 and the splashing of vast amounts of public money as a result of underpricing the first tranche of Telstra got him the gold medal, and he got the silver medal for the privatisation of the State Bank of New South Wales. The other contenders in the field were way behind.

speech.para: On recent evidence, it would appear that the minister is not just a one-trick pony. He is not somebody who is good at just one event, good at stuffing up one particular aspect of his portfolio. He is actually a multitalented person who has managed to achieve a variety of disasters in his portfolio. I will turn firstly to the Telstra 1 sale and precisely what the Auditor-General found the minister had achieved in the process of the sale of the first third of Telstra. The sale costs were $65 million over budget—$275 million was spent when the actual budget for the sale was $210 million. The fee for the sale to the global coordinators was negotiated after they had been chosen—in other words, when they were in a position of strength to negotiate, not when the government was in a position of strength. The success fee benchmarks that were set, over which their incentive payments were provided, were below those originally provided in the scoping study and below those originally recommended by the Office of Asset Sales and Information Technology Outsourcing. As a result, $5 million to $10 million went west. Half a million dollars in success fees was given to the global coordinators for giving away shares, and $26,000 was provided in success fees for shares that were not sold. So around half a million dollars was given for doing nothing. Five million dollars was spent on underwriting the sale of shares when no underwriting was required. Seven hundred thousand dollars was lost as a result of the absence of foreign exchange hedging that would have been appropriate and, of course, most importantly, the price at which the shares were sold was massively underweight, massively undervalued. The share price went up within less than a year by $12 billion—so it was almost double—and it was noted by the Auditor-General that, in this time, the price of Telstra shares went up by 160 times the average price on the All Ordinaries index of the Australian Stock Exchange.

The Auditor-General has also been on the minister's case more recently. The minister must hate the Auditor-General because he keeps catching him out in incompetence and mismanagement. More recently, the Auditor-General has found massive losses on the part of the government, as supervised by the minister for finance, on foreign exchange and transactions associated with international contracts, where there has been a complete absence of foreign exchange risk management. The minister has presided over billions of dollars of losses, particularly in the Defence portfolio. For example, Defence had a contract to buy 14 helicopters. By the time it came to delivery they found that, as a result of the deterioration of the value of the Australian dollar against the US dollar, they could afford to buy only 11. The minister's own department was found by the Auditor-General to have substantially mismanaged its own foreign exchange risk with respect to purchases of properties overseas, to the point where the Auditor-General found that `its inconsistent approach to foreign exchange risk in its overseas property developments has meant that the Commonwealth has been exposed to significant foreign exchange risk in this area' In other words, the minister's own department was not up to scratch, let alone his supervision of other departments. The Auditor-General found that there was `widespread disregard of risk management principles' in this area and that there were no proper procedures in place in order to ensure that there was appropriate management of exchange rate risk.

The minister has responded to this by saying that these principles in place are the same as those that the former Labor government had in place. But that is not true. The approach the government has taken since 1997 has been one of radical decentralisation of responsibility, under the provisions of the Financial Management and Accountability Act, which was introduced in 1997. As a result of this change, the degree of supervision by the Department of Finance and Administration of other departments engaged in foreign exchange related transactions has substantially diminished. In effect, the department under this minister has gone to sleep. It has decided that it no longer needs to supervise the activities of departments such as the Department of Defence when they are engaged in major contracts with foreign suppliers. As a result, we have seen very large sums of money lost to the Commonwealth. The minister himself admitted in answer to a question a couple of months ago that the government would have to have another look at this model because, clearly, it was not up to scratch.

It is also rather disturbing to note that, in spite of the minister's statement in this regard, in the annual report of the Department of Defence tabled in the parliament last week it would appear that the Department of Defence is totally unrepentant. It had the gall to state that the Auditor-General had misrepresented the department's position. No evidence or substantive arguments were provided as to why. It was put that the Auditor-General had misrepresented the department's position and it simply restated the established arrangement that these contracts were done on the basis that there would be no gain or loss to the Department of Defence and that it would be covered by the government, by the department of finance. In other words, the Department of Defence can simply go out there and undertake contracts on the basis that, if there is a foreign exchange rate gain, it will simply hand that over to consolidated revenue. If there is a loss, somebody else will pick up the tab—that is, the taxpayer. That is the sort of thing you get when the minister is asleep, when the department is asleep and when there is no supervision. That is the sort of thing you get when you get one of the biggest expenditure departments effectively saying, `The Auditor-General is wrong. He's misrepresenting us. He doesn't know what he's talking about.'

More recently we have had the Employment National disaster, where first the minister colluded in a rorted process which was designed to ensure that major providers such as Employment National missed out on—

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—Order! The chair requires you to withdraw that allegation that the minister colluded in a rorting process.
—I withdraw that allegation in order to stop wasting time, but I resent your intervention.
—Are you reflecting on the chair? Do you want to continue?
—No, I am not reflecting on the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not believe your intervention is appropriate, but I withdraw the imputation.
—Continue.

—The second stage was that the board of Employment National advised the minister that the contracts that it had been awarded—the job matching contracts that it was successfully awarded—were not sufficient to enable it to continue to operate economically and that it therefore should not accept those contracts. They were loss-making propositions based on the outcome of the tender. The minister did not like this advice, so he decided to reject the advice and sack the board, and he put in his own stooges to ensure that they would accept the position that he wanted, which was to accept those contracts. He also instructed them to give up their existing Job Network 1 contracts for intensive assistance, which he said concluded on 28 February this year anyway—which is, strictly speaking, not true. The full flow-on of contracts and activities entered into up to 28 February this year would have continued on for some considerable time after 28 February. That related only to clients who came on board up to 28 February for whom assistance would continue for some considerable time.

speech.para: As a result of the minister's brilliant interventions in all of this, the $72 million profit that was recorded by Employment National for the 1998-99 financial year has turned into a $92 million loss for this financial year—all due to his blundering intervention. He has issued an open-ended letter of comfort to Employment National saying that the taxpayer will pick up any losses—`You just keep going, thank you very much'—and it was all due to a deliberate strategy of getting rid of the independent board and imposing uneconomic, uncommercial decisions on it, and it has done it absolutely brilliantly.

Interspersed with these decisions and activities, we have seen his and his department's role in the infamous Reith telecard scandal, where it took five years before anybody was aware of the fact that the card had been misused and that it was in the wrong hands. The matter was raised in July 1998 by Telstra and a query was raised about the use to which the card was being put. Nobody took any action, nobody determined that it was not being used by people who were entitled to use it, and nobody checked with the minister as to whether or not his card was being used appropriately. Then when obvious fraud was apparent, in August and September of 1999, he set up a departmental committee to have a look at what was going on, and it was eight months before the Federal Police were called in to investigate what was clearly a fraud on the face of it back in September 1999. His own department had recommended that the Federal Police be called in at that time. He did so ultimately, in breach of his own guidelines that had been adopted by a predecessor junior minister, Senator Minchin, with respect to dealing with these matters. The guidelines said that the secretary of the department would deal with the matter and refer it to the Federal Police. Of course that did not happen; that was subsequently done as a result of a conversation with the Prime Minister. So there were no checking procedures and no action was taken when they were first advised of the problems. The response to apparent evidence of fraud was simply to sit on the issue and let a departmental committee look at it rather than referring it to the Federal Police, and they did not even follow their own guidelines.

He has also been a great performer in dealing with budget honesty and information in the budget. The 2000 budget is built on the assumption that Telstra is going to be sold. Not content with a $2.6 billion spectrum sale—which is clearly both inappropriately incorporated within the effective surplus and now clearly under some doubt—and a $1.6 billion loan to the states for GST purposes, we now have the fiction in the budget that there will be a substantial amount, which he refuses to disclose even though the equivalent amount was disclosed in the 1998 budget, which is as a result of all of Telstra being sold and therefore is a substantial reduction in public debt interest. It is very obvious that it is in there when you compare the underlying cash surplus with the headline cash surplus, because that shows a massive asset sale program which can only be about Telstra. The figure is in there, but it is used to bolster a phoney surplus. We know it is in the budget, we know that Telstra will not be sold, because it will not get through the Senate, and we know that, as a result, the minister is presiding over a meaningless surplus projection.

The final acknowledgment of the minister's incompetence arrived yesterday, under cover of the Melbourne Cup—which was very convenient for the minister because he was able to put out a press release on a matter that was very embarrassing for him and pretend that nothing was happening and that it was all quite routine. The Auditor-General found, with respect to the information technology outsourcing program, that the first 40 per cent of the program produced $70 million of savings—a one billion dollar savings program, according to the minister, and 40 per cent of it has produced a mere $70 million. He found that $17 million was spent on a US consultant where there was no tender process for the position initially, no contract was put initially, and all of these things were done retrospectively.

The program was two years behind schedule, the cost of the program's administration was three times the original budget of $13 million, and only 30 per cent of the work under the program had gone to small or medium Australian enterprises. Now the minister simply says, `Everything is fine, but we were always going to have a review.' That strikes me as being rather strange because as part of this review work is being put aside on groups 9 and 10 and the defence department IT outsourcing. I find it a bit hard to understand how they would have projected that as well. Clearly the minister is panicking; he is realising that public pressure on these issues is starting to rise, particularly from within the information technology sector. We now have a situation where this review will identify and assess implementation risks to be managed when transitioning from in-house IT operations to an outsourced environment managed by an external service provider. We might well ask why this question was not asked at the outset. It appears we have gone through half the program and finally they have decided they need a review to look at the risks of implementing these programs of changing from in-house provision to outsourced provision. Thankfully, the minister has put some of these contracts on hold, and therefore some of the madness that is starting to emerge in the IT outsourcing area is being at least put aside—some of the madness, for example, of asking the CSIRO to outsource the information technology provision that is integral to the delivery of its scientific work.

Even where the minister is engaged in delivering a supposedly grand savings program that will produce enormous benefits for the taxpayers, he has managed to muck it up rather chronically. The minister's response to all of these claims will be quite simple. He will announce that they have all been brilliant successes, he will then claim that they are all Labor's fault, and he will then allege that some sort of thing happened under the Labor government that is broadly similar to what we are alleging against him.

The minister is seen in some quarters as a nice bloke—the sort of person whom it would be nice to have as your neighbour—he would mow your lawn while you were on holiday, he would feed the budgie and whatever. But I do not think you would give him power of attorney. I do not think you would let him manage your share portfolio or anything like that. When you got home from holiday, you would probably find that the lawn was mowed and the budgie was fat but you would also find that you were bankrupt if he had been in charge of your finances. He is a very good illustration of why, however decent somebody might be in some people's eyes, you do not necessarily put them in charge of the money. This minister is incompetent. He should be removed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Before I call the minister, I would like to comment briefly on the member for Melbourne's rejection of the chair's intervention. I know that he would not normally ever reflect on the chair, but just for his information I wish to point out that, according to the Macquarie Dictionary, `collusion' is `a secret agreement for a fraudulent purpose; a conspiracy'. I advise him and all members of the House that anybody who makes that sort of allegation will always be interrupted.

— The matter before the chair is `the government's failure to prudently manage the Commonwealth's finances'. There are reams of paper that indicate clearly to the Australian public that under the Howard government over the past 4½ years the government's finances have been brought from a state of chaos, from a state of disrepair, from a rather disastrous situation, into a balanced position. In fact, surpluses have been delivered now for four of the five Howard government budgets. So the matter should rest there. The facts speak for themselves.

speech.para: The management of the government's finances by this government, by the coalition government, has been one of the great success stories of any government in terms of economic management over the past several decades. That has brought with it significant benefits to the Australian community. They are apparent in the context of interest rates, in the context of inflation, in the various productivity gains that have occurred and in the standing that the Commonwealth has with the rest of the world, particularly on a comparative OECD basis. So in general terms I think that puts paid very quickly to the assertions made in the matter before the chair that the government has not prudently managed the Commonwealth's finances.

The member for Melbourne has engaged for the past 15 minutes in an inaccurate spray of various aspects, attributing many matters to me which certainly do not come near my role or responsibility. I do not walk away from the fact that those assertions have been made. I am happy to answer many of them. But when you are desperate the idea is to assert many things and leave them hanging out there. That is clearly the way in which the member for Melbourne has approached this debate.

Starting from events that occurred in New South Wales: when it comes to matters commented on by that very good man for the Labor Party—at one stage operating a think tank paid for by the unions—Professor Bob Walker, I see it as a badge of honour when he seeks to criticise me in any shape or form, because it is consistent with an approach that he took to me over a number of years in my former professional life. I would simply point the honourable member for Melbourne to some events that happened in his own state with regard to the State Bank. Would that Joan Kirner had got a dollar for the State Bank down there instead of a fire sale that required money to be put in and resulted in a debt that the subsequent Kennett government had to address over a number of years because of the management of the State Bank in Victoria.

Perhaps I should move a little to the west from there and talk about a couple of other state banks under the stewardship of Labor governments. I am eternally grateful for the fact that the State Bank of New South Wales was not a liability for the people of New South Wales and that it in fact returned a dividend to them when it was sold, when the government decided it ought to get out of banking, just as the Keating and Hawke governments in their time decided that they ought to get out of banking and moved to sell a couple of tranches of the Commonwealth Bank on their way to complete privatisation. They had it right then. I had it right in New South Wales. Unfortunately, the Labor premiers of the southern and western states did not make those decisions when they had a chance, and consequently their citizens are paying for that,

We then had a tirade regarding the sale of Telstra 1. I noted with great interest that there was reference by the honourable member for Melbourne to the Auditor-General's comments in respect of the sale price that was achieved on the sale of shares in the first tranche of Telstra. I can only point out again, as I have many times publicly, that the advice taken by the government reflected the fact that several people rated as worldwide experts gave advice on what they considered the value of the shares ought to be at the listing of those shares. The government settled upon a figure in the top quartile of that advice. These were people who did not have an interest. They were not the global coordinators or the lead managers. But their advice was given, and there were many of them. As I say, the price it was ultimately struck at was very much in the upper quartile of the average of those.

You could quote whomever you like on that. I simply say that the experts who gave that advice gave it on the state of the market at that time. If those opposite want to start playing what's your loss because of an increase in price, I simply point out that the Labor government sold Commonwealth Serum Laboratories for around $2 and it now trades in the mid-30s. If you want to look at the price that was hit by any particular share, then the markets move and it is simply a fatuous argument to suggest that because of price moves in the market, market moves, you can make an assessment, with the wisdom of hindsight, on what the value should have been.

We then had a reference to the foreign exchange. I said on another occasion in this House that the honourable member for Melbourne should be patient on the Auditor-General's report in respect of foreign exchange. If he looked at it appropriately and wanted to give a factual account, an honest account, of that report to the House today or on any other occasion he would note that it related to a number of matters and a number of agencies, spread over many years.

As I understand, it started way back in the 1980s and has continued for a long period of time. For the great bulk of that time there was a Labor government. But I will reserve my views on that because it was the government's intention, as I indicated, to examine that report and to have discussions with the Treasurer. Those discussions have taken place and there will be a very factual account given to this parliament in response to the Auditor-General's report. From what I understand, that will be enlightening. I invite the honourable member for Melbourne to keep it in mind and to perhaps make comment when he sees the facts. He is certainly running on what is mere supposition at this point in time.

There was reference to my appointing stooges to the board. People were appointed to the board of Employment National when it became abundantly clear, as a result of its failing in the contracts under the competitive tender process—in a program which has delivered significant benefits to unemployed Australians and which continues to do so day in and day out—that the former board did not have a way forward and were no longer right. The view that the honourable member for Melbourne takes is that, when the board did not give me the sort of information I wanted, I simply got rid of them and moved to put stooges on the board. When the tender submitted by Employment National for the Job Network 2 round failed significantly—they received approximately 10 per cent of the work they had in Job Network 1—it was clear that there had to be a restructuring of and a whole new approach taken to Employment National. It required specific skills, and the people who were appointed to the board, and who are still the members of that board, are senior public servants whom I regard as professional, independent and non-political. Those senior public servants, who operate diligently, honestly, with integrity and in a manner which I regard as professional, have been described here as stooges by a person who aspires one day to be the finance minister.

talk.start.para: —You're their boss.
—With your approach to public servants—if you regard them as stooges, as you have labelled a number of them today—all I can do is wish you good luck if you ever get the chance.

speech.para: Then there was again a distortion with respect to the telecard affair. That has been canvassed to death. The full facts are available for anyone who wants to have a look at them. There was again a slant placed on it. Then of course we came to doubts about whether the government is intending to sell spectrum. I can assure you that the government is intending to sell spectrum. That is the intention.

talk.start.para: —I didn't suggest that.

—You made a suggestion that there was a doubt about whether we would proceed or not. Lastly, we come to the allegations of `under the cover of the Melbourne Cup'. Yes, I was working yesterday afternoon. This is a matter that I believe is appropriate and about which I have had discussions with the Prime Minister over some considerable time. In that context—as one should have a review—the choice was to have an internal review of it. I chose, and suggested to the Prime Minister, to have someone come in from outside, a former Auditor-General, someone with skills in this area and someone who has had experience in the context of significant change.

—No, the Auditor-General from Victoria—just to assist the honourable member from South Australia. I am looking at that review in the context of the continuous improvement program. The government stands by the program. There was this rather strange argument about what the level of savings is. There has been significant benefit to regional Australia from that program. There has been significant benefit to small and medium IT companies in this countryso much so that one company, IPEC, which bid in one of the early contracts as part of a consortium as one of the small and medium enterprises, was able to grow its business significantly enough to actually become the prime contractor in a subsequent contract. It is a success story for an Australian industry in the growth area of all economies: information technology. But we do not hear the honourable member for Melbourne speak about that. So the program will continue.

speech.para: There was criticism that the program was behind schedule and, as a result, there was a cost blow-out. It is about ensuring that the optimum return is there. Would the honourable member for Melbourne suggest that, when it was believed at the start of the program that we could do it within a particular period of time, we should have stuck to that timing and blown some money as a result—blown some savings—and got less in the way of industry development and less in the way of involvement in small and medium enterprises? They were the suggestions made in the honourable member for Melbourne's contribution to this debate. I say again that the government stands by that program and it will continue with it. It will ensure that there is continuous improvement. Part of that continuous improvement is to have a review—in this case involving someone external. I look forward to receiving that report. I am confident that it will stand by the program and that it will ensure that we can do it even better in the future.

If it were left to Labor there would have been no knowledge whatsoever about what information technology was costing the taxpayers of Australia. There was no idea of what outcomes they required. There was no idea of what resources had to be put into it. There was no idea about whether there was any flexibility in the programs that were there. There was very little compatibility in a lot of the systems that were there. We now know the cost, because we have done market testing, and we can tell the Australian people what the cost is and what the savings are that can be achieved with the delivery of effective and efficient services as a result of the contractual obligations that the private sector takes on with respect to that program. There will be a report, and I look forward to the honourable member for Melbourne making some constructive comments, based on fact, at that time.

I will conclude in my remaining minutes by talking about the prudent management of Commonwealth finances. This is the government that introduced the Charter of Budget Honesty. This is the government that, on the last occasion, introduced a 178-page mid-year economic and fiscal outlook. The previous government's mid-year economic and fiscal outlook consisted of a press release which had 2½ pages and then a two-page summary of a table. This is the government that has said to the Australian people, to the markets, to anybody who wants to see what accountability and transparency are all about, `We'll tell you what the situation is in the middle of the year, in 178 pages, instead of in a simple statement in the form of a press release.'

We know how much store the former Labor government put in the factual information it provided to the Australian people. Just prior to the 1996 election—I think it was in February of that year—the then Labor finance minister and now Leader of the Opposition said to the Australian people, `The simple fact is that we are operating in surplus and we intend to stay that way.' Well, we know what came through a very short time later: by the end of that financial year, a few months later, $10.3 billion of deficit. The facts are now known. Those facts will be judged by the Australian people. It is very clear that for financial management the coalition government have delivered new benchmarks and new standards, and we will continue to do that. One of those was to say that the Australian people should never again before an election be in any doubt as to what the state of the books is. We introduced, as one of the provisions of the Charter of Budget Honesty and the legislation that underpinned that, the requirement for the Secretary of Treasury and the Secretary of Finance to disclose the full facts about the government's finances prior to an election so that there can be a proper appraisal undertaken by all voters, all taxpayers. What did Labor do? For 12 months they refused to support that legislation. They gave a clear indication of what they regarded as transparency and what they regarded as accountability by opposing that legislation for 12 months. They were scared that it might ultimately come back to haunt them when they got back into government. I stand by the management of finances by this government. The record has been attested to by the OECD, the IMF and the World Bank as third party endorsements, and it is a very good record. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have not had a chance, as has the member for Melbourne, to read all of Bob and Betty Walker's book, but I have read some of it. There is a very interesting comment about the Minister for Finance and Administration when he was Premier and Treasurer of New South Wales: he would avoid answering financial questions by replying, `I know my limitations.' As the member for Melbourne has pointed out in his assessment of the finance minister's performance on a number of privatisations, those limitations have not diminished even if the minister is no longer able to recognise them. The minister's performance in the other major area of his duties—the control and management of government outlays—also demonstrates those limitations. The parliament and the public deserve to be made aware of those limitations. Managing Commonwealth outlays is a very difficult task, because Commonwealth outlays are not a static thing. There is an economic cycle which, try as we might, we can never quite eliminate. Most responsible finance ministers attempt to achieve balance over the course of that cycle and perhaps even strengthen the Commonwealth's balance sheet. That is a hard thing to do because you have a lot of people around you who want to spend money for political reasons, some of it on things that are worth while and some of it on things that are not, and you have a responsibility in that role to make sure that you are funding adequate services in health, education, defence and justice at a level that is appropriate to Australia's standard of living and in a manner that both is sustainable and Australia can afford in the long term.

speech.para: As with the Treasurer, this minister's only defence is that he has presided over some budgets that have produced surpluses. Today he has been questioned about the strength of the budget surplus in the present year because there is severe doubt that the privatisation on which that surplus depends will produce the expected amount of revenue that the minister announced to the press gallery in the budget lockup last year—$2.6 billion. The minister has suggested that it is somehow infra dig for him to make any comment on that, when he was quite happy to tell everybody in the press gallery about it last year. Let us have a look at the minister's performance. He and the Treasurer came into office; they got some advice from Treasury that said that basically Treasury had revised the revenue forecast downwards, as part of the process of managing an economy over the course of the cycle. In this case inflation was lower than we have had in the past—that was a happy fact that this government was able to inherit—and that meant that revenues were growing more slowly than they had in previous cycles and Treasury had a little bit of difficulty in forecasting them. So they inherited the situation where there was less revenue coming in. They hypothesised that there was a certain financial target that had to be met and in their first two budgets they set about meeting that target. They did that with absolutely reckless abandon. They really were not at all concerned about the quality of services that they were delivering to the Australian people. They just wanted to hit that target and they went at it with fairly wanton abandon. After their second budget, they announced that they would achieve the target in the third out year. That third out year is the financial year that we have just completed. Having declared victory, they then started spending. The brakes came off, they began to spend, and they have continued to spend. They had an election so they had to spend for that and they spent up big.

Normally after you have had an election and you have won it, that is the time to pause and think about how the economy is going. But not this lot; they just went right on spending. By the time they got to the end of the financial year that we have just completed, they had almost spent everything that they had ever saved. They have spent pretty well all the proceeds of economic growth; and, with the outlays they have made this year to compensate people for the GST and in the form of tax cuts, they have made a further fiscal loosening, which means that they are in fact a bunch of big spenders and not a bunch of big savers. Before the budget the Treasurer was criticised for this by me and other commentators, and his defence was, `Well, look at us; we've cut debt by $50 billion; therefore we must be a prudent government.' Well, the finance minister is equally responsible for the state of that debt and in fact he is more responsible that the Treasurer for the way that they have gone about reducing it.

The interesting thing about reductions in debt by this government is that they are more than entirely due to asset sales. There are two types of assets. There are financial assets like Telstra, which is based on securities, and the Commonwealth Bank; and there are non-financial assets like government buildings. This government has had a veritable fire sale of government buildings as part of its process to fill that debt. It has sold off, for example, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade building for a fraction of the price that it cost to build. The organisation that bought it paid the top price that was offered—bought it at a premium—because they realised that, unlike commercial real estate, there would never be a square metre of it that would be empty. They paid a good price for it and they have been absolutely delighted. It earns the Motor Trades Association's super fund a huge benefit.

The Treasurer, in his last budget, claimed that debt would fall by the end of this financial year, I think by $47.4 billion over the course of the time that this government has been in office. Unfortunately for him and unfortunately for the Minister for Finance and Administration, he had to sell $50.3 billion of assets to do it. When you are selling assets like government buildings, which cost more to rent in the long run than they do to buy, you are weakening the government's balance sheet. When you are selling off assets like Telstra, and spending $1 billion of the proceeds, you are weakening the government's balance sheet. When you are selling off government assets below their true market value, as was the case with Telstra 1, you are weakening the government's balance sheet; you are making the government's budget less sustainable over the course of the cycle. That is something that this finance minister has never shaped up to.

We have tried to look at information technology outsourcing. The Auditor-General has looked at it and he has said that the savings that the finance minister forecast are not there. The finance minister has said, `I don't like that Auditor-General's assessment of my performance; I will find another Auditor-General'—Mr Humphry, a former Auditor-General of Victoria—`and get him to make another assessment.' He is putting off judgment day—but judgment day will surely come for this finance minister. There are pressures building up everywhere in the Commonwealth budget. There was a story in the Financial Review this morning that the security committee of cabinet had met last night and decided that they were going to spend an additional $3.5 billion on defence. In fact, they were looking at a three per cent increase in defence outlays every year for the next 10 years.

That is going to be a big burden. We have seen other pressures bearing down on this budget that the government is going to have great difficulty accommodating. This finance minister is going to face those pressures in the upcoming budget. We are waiting to see what the midyear economic and fiscal outlook is going to be like, to see where he is in relation to his budget forecasts. Will he be slightly ahead of his asset sales in reducing debt or will he be slightly behind them? We do not know yet. We look forward to seeing that. What people need to understand is that their budget has been weakened by this finance minister. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I must say that I was very surprised when I saw the text of the MPI today. In watching the reports coming in from the United States about the election, it struck me that the Labor Party lecturing the coalition about fiscal prudence is like Bill Clinton giving a lecture on fidelity in marriage. This is not something that we can take seriously. If Bob Brown turned up here and started lecturing on the importance of private enterprise you could be forgiven for sitting there speechless. That is how I feel. When I think back to the last few years in this country, the thing that strikes me is that there has never been a Labor government that has not gone broke. We heard from the Minister for Finance and Administration reference to some of the things that had happened in the southern and western states—names like John Cain, Joan Kirner, John Bannon. Others come back to mind. That State Bank in the member for Kingston's own home state—what a wonderful record! And, at a federal level, think back to the seventies and the profligacy of the Whitlam years. Time passes, and there again in the eighties it starts to happen again, especially when the Leader of the Opposition held the portfolio that my friend Johnnie Fahey holds now. You have the hide to come in here and get stuck into Mr Fahey about his record, which is a good one.

speech.para: Prudent management of the Commonwealth's finances is not simply a matter of transparency, balanced budgets, budget honesty or even avoiding the zealotry of some spending ministers that the member for Kingston referred to. It is also about reducing the size of government. Government in this country has long been too big. That is a very firmly established public opinion. We in Australia do not want our government to be our master; we want it to be our servant. When we get lectured about weakening the government's balance sheet, the phrase that came from the lips of my friend the member for Kingston leaves me speechless. That said, with the Chief Government Whip back in the chamber, I will persevere.

Some of the things that Labor governments have done in the past have made the United Nations look fiscally responsible. We do our best on some committees of this chamber to stop this kind of thing happening. Again they try to establish some other fiddly little body somewhere in Europe to administer another stupid treaty and fill its coffers with taxpayers' money, with no accountability. We have to put a stop to that. There is a basic misunderstanding here—a deep philosophical difference between these two sides of the chamber. The money that flows through this parliament is not yours and it is not ours; it is theirs. It is the public's money.

When people talk about `public' in terms of money that is administered by ministers of the Crown and so forth, I do not believe there is any public money; I think there is private money and nothing else. When, sadly, members of the public have their incomes plundered—if I can use that verb—by the Australian Taxation Office and some of that money ends up here, we have to make sure that it is well spent. Big government is the father of profligacy and big government is Labor's favourite child. It has given birth to some other problem children: political correctness, secret treaty making, kowtowing to foreign despots and, perhaps the worst of all, sacrificing workers for job-hating green preferences. Nothing makes me angrier than seeing the jobs and livelihoods of the men and women who inhabit what I call the `metal and diesel economy' of this country wiped out by a deal done with the greenies in Canberra. This sort of thing happened time and time again in the eighties under the Hawke and Keating governments, but it will not happen here while we hold these benches.

The member for Melbourne is a fine fellow in many ways. He barracks for Essendon—we can put that aside; he plays the piano very well; he represents the part of Melbourne where my father's family grew up, Brunswick. Were my grandfather still alive and voting I cannot really see him manning the booth for Lindsay, although I think he might have been a Labor man. That aside, we have to ask ourselves: have we forgotten in this place what happened in the past? Have we forgotten the Collins class submarine, the sports rorts and the $10 billion deficit that we were left? Oh, but it was a surplus in February 1996, and then the election changed the government and, suddenly, as if a magic wand had been waved, it was red, not black. We remember some of the major robberies of the past such as the l-a-w tax cuts that were stolen from those to whom they were promised, and then we go back along the winding road to the days of the great Colston cover-up. One of the accused in that crime has been sentenced to obscurity in Europe. Gareth has gone. He is somewhere out there running something called the International Crisis Group. He used to be part of the Australian crisis group that was the Labor government. These days, of course, he is issuing predictions about the world. Apparently one of his recent predictions was that Mr Milosevic in Yugoslavia was too strong to move; they would never get rid of Milosevic, he told his clients. A month later, he was gone—outski. That was much the same sort of quality that he brought to bear here in Canberra while he held office.

But, of course, the other accused is still here, marauding around like a dangerous bear, hungry to get his claws and his paws on that honey pot of public money. It reminds you of that advertisement that ran during the Reagan years. I think some of the members opposite might remember it. It was the advertisement about the big bear which said, `There's a bear out there; some people think he is tame, some others don't really know; but, if he is there, isn't it best that you're stronger than the bear?' That is the way.

I had a friend called Clyde Nelson. He was an American fellow who worked with me in a bank. He was from North Carolina and his father grew blueberries. He told us the story of the day that the bear came out of the woods and started eating his dad's blueberries. We said, `Clyde, what did you do?'—that was the way he spoke—and he said, `My daddy got his shotgun and he filled that bear's hide full of buckshot, and that bear went back into the forest and never ate daddy's blueberries again.' We ought to do that with the marauding bear here in Canberra. We ought to break out the 12-gauge and put a couple of cartridges of buckshot in the breech and fill his hide with buckshot, and back he will go into the forest!

To have the Labor Party lecture us about prudence in fiscal management is like George Speight lecturing on gun control. I talked about Bill Clinton lecturing us on fidelity in marriage. We could talk about the AWU lecturing on the importance of integrity in elections, Saddam Hussein talking about world peace or Cheryl Kernot discussing party loyalty, perhaps. The list could go on. We have to remember one thing: in the time of the Labor governments in the eighties a significant number of privatisations took place and a significant amount of funds was raised. Where did the money go? Did it go to pay off debt? No, it did not. There was Qantas, CSL, the Commonwealth Bank, the embassy land in Tokyo—a very perspicacious act to sell that land at the top of the market—but where did the folding stuff go? It really takes a certain kind of genius to manage to spend the proceeds of asset sales on recurrent expenditure. If you are out there in the private sector and you have an income producing asset, you sell it either to buy another income producing asset that is better value or you retire some debt. As I say, there is a basic difference between the parties here. The money that flows through this parliament does not belong to us—either your side or my side. It belongs to those wonderful people out there who elect us, who pay their taxes loyally and who now and then come and have a say about things through their members of parliament. One thing they want above all is to make sure that their money is safe. As long as the Labor Party occupy benches on the opposition side of this place, I think that will remain the case.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
