talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Proposed fitout of new leased premises for the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Belconnen, ACT.

speech.para: The Australian Bureau of Statistics proposes to fit out new leased premises at Belconnen in the Australian Capital Territory. The ABS is Australia's official statistical agency. Its mission is to assist and encourage informed decision making, research and discussion within government and the community. It provides a high-quality, objective and responsive national service. The central office of the Australian Bureau of Statistics has been housed in the Cameron Offices complex at Belconnen in the Australian Capital Territory since completion of the building in the mid-1970s. More than 20 years experience as tenants in the building has revealed inherent limitations in building layouts, and shortcomings in the building fabric, services and amenities.

A proposal to improve the short-term situation of the ABS was developed and submitted to the Public Works Committee before the government decided to secure new accommodation for the ABS when selling Belconnen properties in the Commonwealth property estate for redevelopment by the private sector. In December 1997, my colleague the Minister for Finance and Administration announced that the Commonwealth would market test the sale of Benjamin and Cameron offices and the provision of new accommodation for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Department of Finance and Administration made a public call for expressions of interest from potential purchasers and developers interested in purchasing the Benjamin and Cameron offices site and constructing new accommodation for the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The outcome of a lengthy selection process was the acceptance by the Department of Finance and Administration of a development proposal that will include the partial demolition of the Cameron offices and the construction of a new, purpose designed building for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The ABS will be the sole tenant in the new building with an initial lease term of 15 years and options to twice renew the lease for a further two terms of five years. This proposal covers the fitout of the leased premises as offices for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Approximately 35,300 square metres of floor space will be fitted out to commercial office standards and the special operating requirements of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The accommodation will provide the staff of the central office of the ABS with a work environment that is more functionally effective and space efficient. The project developer has provided the ABS with a guaranteed maximum price for the fitout, based on the fitout brief, of $22.8 million.

In its report, the committee has recommended that the project proceed subject to the implementation of the recommendations of the committee. The Australian Bureau of Statistics agrees to the recommendations made by the committee and will carry out an independent audit of the project management fees to demonstrate that the Bovis Lend Lease estimate is competitive. Subject to parliamentary approval, this fitout project will be fully integrated with the construction of the new building under the management of the project developer to maximise cost savings and to minimise construction time. Fitout works are scheduled to commence on site in December this year for completion in March 2002. I would like, on behalf of the government, to thank the committee for its support. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT (IMPROVED MONITORING OF ENTITLEMENTS TO PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —When I was interrupted prior to question time on the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000, I was talking about pharmacists. Not only are they responsible for the bulk of the extra work but once the system is up and running pharmacists will take financial responsibility for ensuring that there are no discrepancies between the Medicare number on the prescription and the information held by the Health Insurance Commission. If discrepancies are found, the pharmacist will have to forgo his or her subsidy reimbursement even if he or she has acted in good faith and taken all reasonable care. So now it seems that pharmacists can add HIC fraud squad to their professional CVs.

speech.para: The general public could also find themselves rather inconvenienced by the implementation of this new system. Firstly, the rush with which this system is being introduced will mean that as of 1 January next year, just 2 months away, members of the general public will have to provide the pharmacist with their Medicare number as well as their prescription for verification in order to receive their full PBS benefit. No number, no PBS benefit, and the consumer will either have to pay the full cost of the medicine or go home, get their number and re-present their prescription. Given that this particular change to the way people will receive their prescriptions has had little, if any, publicity, I think there are going to be some very surprised and very angry consumers out there come 1 January. Personally, I would not want to be a pharmacist during the implementation period having to bear the brunt of public anger at this poorly publicised and rushed change. This raises a couple of questions for Dr Wooldridge. Will there be a publicity campaign in the run-up to these changes? If so, what will it cost? Hopefully, it will not cost as much as the one-off GST advertising campaign. And, if there are no plans for a campaign, how are people going to be informed about the change?

At the centre of this entire system is the attachment of a person's Medicare number to their prescription. This is also the weakness of the system. The fact that at pharmacy verification level a person does not have to provide their Medicare card but just a copy of their number and expiry date means the system will continue to be open to abuse. As Mr Reith has so recently and publicly discovered, once your number is out there, it is amazing where it can turn up and how it can be used. Under this system, there is nothing to stop a person giving out their Medicare number to others unlawfully, lawfully to allow an agent to collect a prescription, or accidentally.

In addressing the issue of doctor shopping, again this new system may make it a little harder to occur, but it certainly is not foolproof. Doctor shopping is a complex issue. In its most base form, people use the system to make money by on-selling their prescription medicines. At a more subtle level, there are people whose doctor shopping behaviour is often an indication of serious social and mental health issues. All this system will do is identify after the fact—how long after will depend on how fast the HIC can process the information—that someone is doctor shopping. What happens then is not outlined in this bill. The only way in which this system could operate to prevent doctor shopping at the level of dispensing is if all pharmacy databases are linked and can share information. In that case, a person presenting several prescriptions to several pharmacies on the same day or within the 21-day statutory limit would be identified immediately. This, however, would mean that the Medicare number is being used as a unique identifier and that that number is being used to track a person and their information.

This brings me to my next concern. Maybe this concern is the product of an overly suspicious mind but, to the extent that this bill only provides an improvement, however flawed, on current PBS fraud detection processes, I wonder whether it is just a Trojan horse for the introduction of a unique patient identifier without the required privacy protection. If I am being overly suspicious, I apologise. Perhaps this bill is what it seems: benign. Yes, it does address fraud to an extent, and it may help identify more doctor shoppers, but that may be all it does.

I see nothing in this bill that addresses quality use of medicines, an issue that may not create $16 million or 0.55 per cent of last year's PBS in the short term but would save considerably more over the medium to longer term. Quality use of medicines is a major plank of Labor's health care platform. At prescriber level, improving quality will lead to more appropriate prescribing habits based on best practice and evidence. At pharmacy level, it will allow the pharmacist to act as a safety net, ensuring that medications being dispensed will not interact with other medication being taken by the patient, resulting in a decrease in adverse reactions. At a patient level, quality use of medicines means an improvement in health outcomes and quality of life. For the taxpayer, quality use of medicines saves on costs across the health care budget—MBS, PBS and hospital costs. However, for a government with its eye constantly on the bottom line, improving quality is not a priority: its payback is not fast enough. So instead we have this bill with a laudable aim, a nice saving at the end of it and little else.

But back to my suspicions. This bill is the first part of a three-part package to introduce online health records. The other two parts of the package are the Better Medication Management System and HealthConnect. The basis for any online system will be the ability to track, monitor and share health information—something that will require a unique identifier. Any integrated system that does enable quality use of medicines is supported by the Labor Party, but—and I emphasise this—not until there is strong legislation in place to protect the privacy of Australians. Adequate privacy protection has to come first, has to be strong and has to have the confidence of the Australian public.

This government is on notice. Its attempts to pump up the bottom line as much as possible as fast as possible will not be tolerated if the price is the privacy of the Australian public. Instead of rushing through legislation such as this, the government should be focusing on producing a comprehensive package of legislation with protection of privacy at its centre. And this legislation is being rushed through. As the member for Jagajaga has already pointed out, the government has signalled its intention to introduce six pages of amendments to this bill to deal with an oversight in the original drafting. I have had an opportunity to briefly look at these amendments, which arrived just prior to my coming down to the House earlier today, and they cover a lot of ground. I will study them with interest following this speech. These amendments, however, do not change the fact that the Minister for Health and Aged Care must have the backbone to stand up to Treasury and let it know in no uncertain terms that short-term financial gains at the expense of quality and public trust are just not acceptable.

Having made these points, as I said at the beginning of my speech, Labor will be supporting this bill—not for its content or its possible hidden outcomes but for the stated principle behind it: that is, the prevention of PBS abuse. I do urge the minister, however, to try to ensure at the very least that the general public is made aware of these changes so that pharmacists and other health professionals do not end up bearing the brunt of public frustration. It would also, I believe, be appropriate for the minister to address this House and to reassure Australians that this bill is not the Trojan horse it seems to be and that their privacy will be protected no matter what the cost.

talk.start.para: —The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 is quite an important bill for the whole health industry. I have had a special interest in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme because of its unique nature and the contribution it has made to the health of Australians. It is interesting that at this very moment, Mr Deputy Speaker, the US election is swinging in a very tight battle and one of the issues there is the availability of pharmaceuticals in the state of Florida.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—I am glad you tied it to the bill.
—I was fortunate enough to visit America to see one of the primaries in action and certainly the debate about the cost to the elderly of pharmaceuticals was a very big political question in the US.
—You would be interested in that, Stewie.

—Interestingly enough, the member at the table would understand that ironically the outcome of the US election might actually swing on this issue of the two candidates for presidential office and their attitude to Medicare and pharmaceuticals.

speech.para: The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, as members would be aware, has been in action for 50 years and has been built upon and added to. It provides 559 drug substances, generic type drugs, and produces about 1,900 drug products or brands. The key element is that for non-cardholders it costs about $20 for every prescription, but we well know that they are subsidised. More importantly, individual pensioners pay $3.30 and they do have a safety net of $631 for a family if they exceed that amount of money. The cost of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is $3 billion, with 80 per cent of these costs being covered with the concessional benefit subscription. So what we are really saying is that this quite massive cost to the taxpayer in providing good quality drugs for Australians, especially older Australians, is a system that has worked very well.

The key element of this bill is the concern about doctor shopping and the availability of the PBS to people from outside Australia. For visitors whose countries have reciprocal rights with Australia—those coming from the UK, Ireland, New Zealand, Malta, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands and Finland—that is okay, but those people who come from outside that grouping should be identified and this bill hopes to ensure that eligible Australians can receive the drugs.

Because of my interest in the matter and the importance of the local pharmacists in the electorate of Corangamite, I made it my business to talk to my local pharmacist, Mr Neville Preston, who is both a professional friend and a personal friend of mine. He runs a very efficient and effective pharmacy in High Street, Belmont in the heartland of Corangamite, and he has very friendly staff who provide good advice to customers on pharmaceutical problems. I just put on the record the very effective nature of that provider. They are open from 9 a.m. till 9 p.m. and, like most chemists throughout Australia, they provide a professional service. They are very highly regarded by the public for the advice they give, often for free, and for the method in which they dispense drugs on behalf of the government.

In my discussion with Mr Preston, I asked him about the bill before the House to get an assessment on the ground of what he thought about it. Basically his assessment of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme was that it was a good scheme, that the government paid on time, unlike some previous experiences, that the administration was good and that it was an efficient administration and they paid within 14 days. That is an important aspect of the whole Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It was interesting that, in making some observations about the PBS, he said it was one of the best in the world, that the availability of drugs was good and that the accessibility was good—and that was from an independent organisation. So I think the system in Australia works pretty well.

There has been some discussion about the quality and the research required for the drugs and about the factor F scheme, where the government is able to purchase these drugs at a very competitive price and where drug companies may or may not have as much money available for research. I do observe that many of these drug companies have parent companies in the US or in Europe, so the research factor might not be so important.

I observe that the shadow minister for health matters, the member for Jagajaga, at least agreed with this legislation. That is a refreshing change, unlike her approach to the private health rebate, to which she will not really commit herself, she and her leader having argued strenuously in this House against that proposal. They will not give a commitment to the Australian people that they will retain it, and certainly even in this place yesterday it was not clear what the opposition's position was. So I am delighted that the shadow minister is supporting the bill before the House, because it is sensible and it does provide a mechanism to ensure that those eligible to receive medication from chemists can provide their Medicare card. The administration of the Medicare card has been raised with me, particularly providing the number to the chemists.

Five or six years ago, when the pharmacists were under a certain amount of pressure from the then Labor government, I took it upon myself to visit five or six pharmacists. I stood behind the counter for two or three hours at a time and watched the pharmacists serve patients. What I came to observe then was the very efficient and effective mechanism that the pharmacists, in my electorate at least, used and the way in which they provided service to the patients. They had a patient record for those patients who were regular customers, they identified the drug and they were scrupulous in the way in which that drug was mixed and dispensed to the patient. I commend the pharmacists for this process and for their backup mechanisms, both the computer software and the reporting mechanisms to identify their customers.

We have a problem in this particular situation where we get doctor shopping, which other members have alluded to, where individual patients obtain drugs for their recreational or personal use beyond the desirability of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Having very much in mind that it costs $3 billion a year, the government need to do everything they can to contain the cost of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. This bill moves in that direction. We are yet to see whether we can stop doctor shopping because of the privacy arrangements. While it would be hard for pharmacies to identify patients who have taken drugs from various pharmacies without a wide net of information, it is the objective of the government to clamp down on doctor shopping, and we hope that the bill will help to prevent that when people can be identified as having undertaken that activity for both personal and commercial reasons. It has come to my attention that some people seem to want to go to pharmacists for personal reasons, to get a stock of drugs, and they use two or three pharmacists for that reason. I think the legislation will help in overcoming that problem.

Use of the Medicare card will ensure that we can identify patients, customers or clients and that those records with computer technology can be aligned with the particular prescriptions. I think it is all possible and it can work. While there is some latitude in the administration of the scheme—and Mr Preston tells me that, being a nine to nine operation, there are a number of other people from outside his area who come to his pharmacy—it might be hard to identify people on a regular basis. We do have the problem of privacy provisions which the shadow minister mentioned. We have an interesting debate here in the parliament on whether the provider number, the Medicare number and the prescription should be available to the chemists and the doctors and whether there should be some privacy provisions to ensure that those numbers are not used in the wrong manner. I do have a view that in the modern age the Australian public will be well served if individual patients are identified and that they can be well served in Victoria or Queensland if they have a medical problem and their records are available.

I commend the bill for its philosophical content, I commend the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for its success in providing high quality drugs to Australians, especially older people, and I commend the special concessional set of arrangements which, on one hand, encourage people to pay a small sum often not related to the true cost of the drug. Mr Deputy Speaker, from time to time you would run across the problem where individual pensioner patients require the best drug which costs $80 to $90 and they are paying a mere $3.60. We do have some anomalies in the system but at least they have to pay a certain amount of money for these very high quality drugs.

I think the legislation moves in the right direction to overcome some of these problems by ensuring that Australians with a Medicare card can receive their drugs and by attempting to curtail doctor shopping, to which most members have referred, through pharmacists helping to make sure that there is a containment of the cost of the drugs. The legislation has the support of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, the professional pharmacist association. That is helpful to the government and to the opposition. I thank members of the opposition for their support for the legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 proposes a new system to check the eligibility of people obtaining pharmaceuticals under Medicare. The legislation will require the inclusion of Medicare numbers on prescriptions for pharmaceutical benefits. This is needed because currently there is nothing in place to monitor the use of drugs within the community. This is a detailed and complex piece of legislation which reflects the complexity of Medicare eligibility.

speech.para: It is surprising that the government is rushing through the three-stage implementation program in such a short time frame. The government plans to have the new system up and running by 1 July 2001. This is a major change with quite a few steps along the way. I worry that it is going through too quickly—although, as I have already stated, it is something that is needed to get around the fact that drugs are often prescribed by a number of different pharmacists and there is no way of checking that. However, I do feel that we need to ensure that we have a system in place which will be effective and will be implemented without causing too much hardship and too many mistakes simply because it is rushed through. From 1 July next year, it will be mandatory for pharmacists to ensure that each and every prescription has a patient Medicare number on it. So, after 1 July next year, pharmacists will not receive a government payment if the prescription is supplied without a Medicare number or with an incorrect Medicare number. That is putting the onus on the pharmacists. I am quite concerned about this because the government will penalise the pharmacist if there is a mistake—and it may not be his or her mistake. For instance, the general practitioner could have put the wrong Medicare number on the prescription or, alternatively, the person who goes to the doctor may have obtained that card through unlawful means.

As I have already said, it is a very unrealistic time frame. I feel that there needs to be a lot more discussion about this and that it should be phased in over a longer period. Whilst I commend the government for looking at this issue and recognising the fact that there is a problem in the community, it should not try to change something in a very hurried way that is not thought through properly. As I have already mentioned, the rationale behind the legislation is to stop the doctor shopping that takes place. I do not think that this legislation will really fix the problem, because people are still able to send an agent along to pick up their prescriptions from the chemist. It is also a worry to me that more than one person's name can be put on a Medicare card. Incorrect conclusions can be drawn from the fact that one Medicare card number may appear time and time again, when it could refer to a number of people. The legislation really is a knee-jerk reaction to a very serious problem that exists in our community.

I would be most pleased if the government were to try to address the problem at its roots rather than just come in and introduce legislation of this nature, but it is a step in the right direction. On this side of the House, we would favour much more a unique patient-identifying number—something that related to a person. At the moment, as I mentioned, a number of people's names can be on a Medicare card, which is a problem. I understand that a paper currently being prepared by the Evatt Foundation is looking at this issue and fully appraising the situation. There will be community consultation, and all parties and interest groups should be involved. I do not think that there has been enough consultation or that all interest parties have been involved. I also think that there is still some reluctance to become involved amongst people that will be affected by this legislation.

We have just finished debating the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000 in this House. A number of members emphasised the need to legislate to ensure that the privacy of Australians is respected. A number of flaws were identified in that legislation which signal the reluctance of this government to ensure that the privacy of Australians is respected. Unfortunately, the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 also raises concerns about privacy and about the government's commitment to ensuring that the privacy of patients issued with prescriptions is respected. The legislation makes it a mandatory requirement that the Medicare number be on all prescriptions. Medicare numbers will therefore become a unique patient-identifier—and that is a problem. That is a problem because it relates to a number of people, not just one person, and will allow a large amount of data to be collected about the people whose names appear on that Medicare card. Doctors and pharmacists are able to keep records of those Medicare numbers. I know that very few, if any, doctors and pharmacists would abuse the privilege of having that information about their patients and customers, but the possibility exists. That issue needs to be looked at in advance.

There is also the possibility that the scheme will be expanded. If it is expanded, we need to know the direction that it is going and the safeguards that need to be in place. It needs to be really well thought through before we go down that track. What will the Health Insurance Commission do with the data it collects? It is obviously there to stop doctor-hopping, overprescribing and the misuse of medication. But who will have access to that information, and for what purpose will the information that is collected be used? I really feel that that needs to be spelt out in more detail. I know that this is part of the government's Better Medication Management strategy, but there need to be assurances that patient privacy will be paramount. The government foreshadowed further legislation containing privacy measures, but that is not good enough. It is a very piecemeal approach to privacy. The privacy legislation that I mentioned previously also fails to deal adequately with health privacy. The government has a very poor record in this area, and I feel that it does not respect the privacy needs of individual Australians.

I have serious concerns about the government's commitment to Medicare. At least this legislation shows some commitment to it, even if it is only to monitor medication usage. The government mouths its support for Medicare time and time again in this place. The Minister for Health and Aged Care constantly assures the House that the government is committed to the preservation of Medicare. My question to the minister and the government is: if he and the government are so committed to Medicare, why don't they do more to ensure that doctors bulk-bill? Bulk-billing is a key component of Medicare. It is the one thing that ensures that all Australians can access medical treatment when they need it. But the minister and this government do nothing to ensure that doctors bulk-bill or even to encourage doctors to bulk-bill. Recently I raised in this House the fact that a number of doctors in the Shortland electorate had stopped bulk-billing. I was so concerned about the matter that I called a public meeting in Swansea, where, on 1 September, the two major medical practices stopped bulk-billing. Swansea is an area with a lot of older people, and this has caused them enormous hardship. There is no real alternative; the only practice that offers bulk-billing now is a part-time practice that operates for only 12 hours a week. Out of that public meeting on 8 September a community committee was formed, and that committee has been fighting to have bulk-billing reintroduced in the area—together with the efforts that I have made towards this.

The cessation of the practice of bulk-billing is not limited to Swansea. It is happening throughout the electorate that I represent—in Lake Munmorah and in Belmont. In Toukley there is only one doctor who bulk-bills. The campaign supporting bulk-billing has received widespread support throughout the community. Why? Because bulk-billing is the single most important factor in making health care affordable and available to all Australians who need it. No Australian should have to choose between seeing his or her local doctor and eating. The interesting aspect of bulk-billing is that, while the general practitioners in Swansea have stopped bulk-billing, most doctors on the North Shore of Sydney still bulk-bill. It hardly seems fair when you look at the demographics of the area and the fact that there are a lot of people who rely on being able to access a doctor free of charge in Swansea.

You might ask what the government's response was to the fact that doctors in my electorate have stopped bulk-billing. You would think it would have been one of outrage, or at the very least an offer to mediate or to explore the situation. But, no, this is the response I received from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator the Hon. Grant Tambling. He was sympathetic and apologised for the delay in responding to my correspondence. He said that the government `strongly supports bulk-billing' but that it is the individual doctor who decides whether or not to use this facility. I believe that if you strongly support bulk-billing you should get in there and encourage doctors to bulk-bill. The parliamentary secretary went on to say that he appreciated that some people may have problems making up-front payments to doctors. He also said that some doctors may allow the accounts to be sent to Medicare by their patients but that, if not, the patient should negotiate with the doctor to see if he would allow them a special payment system.

This is just not good enough. Health care is one of the basic rights of every person in Australia. People should be able to see a medical practitioner if they need to. I call on the government to make a real commitment to Medicare—a commitment that will ensure that the pensioners of Swansea and other areas in the Shortland electorate and throughout Australia have access to bulk-billing and have the same access to bulk-billing as the constituents of the minister for health and the Prime Minister. Not only, under this minister, has the practice of bulk-billing stopped within my electorate but the Medicare office at Belmont, a central location within the Shortland electorate and an area that the pensioners of Swansea could have access to, has been closed. It was a Medicare office that processed a large number of claims. Now these pensioners are forced to travel for an hour by bus to Charlestown to claim their money. It may seem that the distance of 20 kilometres each way to the nearest Medicare office is not great, but if you are a pensioner with mobility problems and can only get there by bus it is very inconvenient. The Charlestown Medicare office is among the top 10 offices in New South Wales in relation to claims. I implore the minister to revisit this issue and look at reopening that office, as well as implementing some strategy to encourage doctors in regional areas, such as the area that I represent, to bulk-bill their patients. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, as somebody who comes from a regional area, you know that it is not good enough to have one rule for the city and places like the North Shore of Sydney, and one rule for the regional areas that we represent. We have health problems, just as people on the North Shore of Sydney do.

The legislation we are considering today seeks to address a few very important issues, including the issue of the management of medicine and the prescribing and supply of medicine within the community. It is an attempt to stop abuse within the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme but, unfortunately, it is poorly conceived legislation. It has problems associated with its practical implementation and operation, and it fails to address the privacy issues that this type of scheme raises—issues that this government has failed to address and that will plague the operation of the scheme. It is a scheme that we need in place to monitor medication usage, to deal with the abuse that takes place in the community and to deal with some of the other problems that exist.

If the government does not address this very serious issue, the operation of the scheme will be plagued by problems. I call on the government to revisit the legislation to address the issues that I have raised and to make a real commitment to Medicare, the kind of commitment that will return bulk-billing to Swansea, to other areas in the Shortland electorate and to the electorate of Page, your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would like a commitment to reopen the Medicare office at Belmont and increased funding for public hospitals throughout Australia.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased that the member for Shortland finally did come to the bill that we are here to speak about, the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000. It was commendable that she spoke about Medicare, but she spoke very little about the bill that we are here to address. The government is very committed to Medicare and to bulk-billing, and that is why we have increased the funding for bulk-billing and opened a number of agencies around Australia. But I would like to speak to the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000.

speech.para: The pharmaceutical scheme has been in Australia for some 50 years, with the aim of providing the Australian community with a range of medicines that are reliable, cost effective and affordable. The system works by subsidising a broad range of approved pharmaceuticals. By February 1999 this covered 559 drug substances—generic drugs—available in 1,354 forms and strengths and marketed as 1,992 different drug brands or products. In 1998-99 the PBS dealt with 129 million prescriptions, at a cost to the government of $2.8 billion. In the year to 30 June 2000, expenditure on the PBS grew by 14 per cent. The purpose of this bill is to build on the current objectives of part VII of the National Health Act of 1953—to assist patients to receive high quality health care through quality use of medicines, to subsidise the cost of prescribed pharmaceuticals and to provide appropriate accountability and expenditure of public funds. Broadly speaking, it requires the inclusion of Medicare numbers on prescriptions for pharmaceutical benefits, and that will ensure that those persons under part VII of the National Health Act will receive those prescriptions.

The bill is motivated by discrepancies identified by the Auditor-General in his report, The Australian National Audit Office Performance Audit, Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, Department of Health and Family Services. The report focused on accountability of the PBS as well as administration by the Health Insurance Commission. In his correspondence with the HIC, the Auditor-General recommended the inclusion of Medicare numbers in the PBS, in order to improve accountability and overcome deficiencies in payments. The PBS operates only in Australia and is available only to Australian residents and visitors from countries that have a reciprocal health care agreement with Australia. Those countries include New Zealand, the UK, Ireland, Italy, Malta, Sweden, Finland and the Netherlands. Under the current PBS, eligible customers fall under one of two categories: general patients or non-cardholders, who pay the first $20.60 for each prescription item; and concessional patients, who hold a health care card—people like pensioners and people with low incomes—who pay $3.30 per prescription item. Overseas visitors from countries without a reciprocal health care agreement are ineligible for the PBS.

When a pharmaceutical benefit has been supplied in accordance with the relevant legislation—part VII of the National Health Act 1953—the dispenser becomes entitled to claim a payment from the Commonwealth which is equal to the difference between the Commonwealth price and the patient contribution. However, a proportion of claims is rejected because they do not comply with statutory requirements. The present legislation provides that dispensers may not supply a pharmaceutical benefit unless they are satisfied that the patient is entitled to a benefit according to section 87(3A) of the National Health Act 1953. However, there are difficulties in pharmacists determining the entitlement status of customers. At the moment, pharmacists routinely ask customers if they have a concession card. If the answer is no, they assume that they are eligible as general patients. However, there is no requirement for those not on a concession card to produce identification to validate their access to the PBS subsidised drug scheme.

When a concessional benefit is obtained under the PBS, the number of the pensioner card, health care card or Commonwealth seniors health card is recorded and included on the dispenser's claim for payment. Copies of card number files are provided by Centrelink to the Health Insurance Commission. In order to identify the person, the HIC attempts to match the cardholder's name and address details on the Centrelink file to the name and address details on its own enrolment file. In a large number of cases, these details cannot be matched. While the holder of a properly issued card is certain to be eligible for Medicare, the lack of reliable matching to HIC enrolment records means that the benefit histories of individual concessional beneficiaries cannot be reliably assembled.

As a consequence of all this, compliance with the rules about the frequency of supply of items cannot be reliably monitored. Non-concessional PBS prescriptions generally do not carry any identifying number for the patient. This lack of an appropriate audit makes it difficult to demonstrate the benefit that has been supplied and the payment that has been made to the dispenser, in accordance with the eligibility requirements of the legislation. Names and addresses supplied on a prescription or concession card are therefore not always the most reliable means to determine a customer's eligibility for the PBS. According to a recent audit by the HIC, there is a significant and increasing degree of insufficient information recorded on prescription forms. The absence of patient detail occurred in 45 per cent of audited prescription forms in 1997-98 and in 72 per cent in 1998-99. In cases where a patient's details do not match HIC enrolment records, the HIC must determine whether the pharmacist is to be reimbursed the subsidised amount, although the pharmacist will not have been in a position to have identified a possible discrepancy in the customer's details.

The proposal of this bill to include a Medicare number on prescriptions will provide a more reliable way of identifying unentitled non-residents and will serve as an effective audit trail of those who may engage in activities that are not fitting with the legislation. It is important that we have a reliable system that has integrity. There have been breaches and abuses in the past. Chemist shoppers have existed for some time. There are people out there who breach the PBS by applying for the maximum number of repeat prescriptions within 21 days, and most of these tend to be older customers who feel that they must have all these prescriptions filled, even though they do not use all of them. There have been cases of chemists having returned to them a large number of drugs which were supplied because older people wanted to have the scripts filled `just in case' but never used them.

The HIC estimates that in 1998-99 a large number of people were involved in this sort of activity. The inclusion of the Medicare number on prescriptions will give a greater ability to verify patient eligibility. It will assist in improving the identification of patients, and it will enable better management of the PBS. I must commend these particular aspects of this bill. The bill is a good instrument which will make sure that those eligible people will be able to use their Medicare card. The opposition has quoted examples of people not having their Medicare card: indigenous Australians in remote areas, minors living on the streets, patients in emergency circumstances and persons covered by reciprocal health agreements. There are provisions in the bill for the minister to determine alternative arrangements to prove eligibility, such as presentation of a passport.

Under sections 135AA and 135AB of the National Health Act, privacy protection is already established, therefore ensuring that Medicare numbers remain private and confidential and are not used for purposes other than to ensure entitlement to pharmaceutical benefits. In a number of committees I have served on—in particular, the inquiry into tax file numbers with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration—I have seen that strict privacy provisions do exist with Medicare numbers already, so the opposition's concerns about the privacy aspects are well taken care of under these provisions. The PBS claims that the data held by the Commonwealth is protected by stringent secrecy provisions under the National Health Act of 1953 and their binding guidelines issued by the Privacy Commissioner.

This bill is about protecting public moneys through better identification of people obtaining benefits under the PBS. Improved PBS entitlement monitoring will result in savings of $5.7 million in 2000-01, $18 million in 2001-02 and $20.7 million in 2002-03. The use of PBS grew by 14 per cent in the year to June 2000. Given the rate of growth of the PBS expenditure, there is a strong public interest in ensuring its accountability and integrity. The specific objective of this bill is to remedy the deficiency in the accountability for the PBS by demonstrating that benefits have been supplied only to people who are eligible, without breaching legitimate access, while protecting the privacy of the Medicare number which is being used for that purpose. I therefore urge the House to support this bill.

talk.start.para: —The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000, which was first introduced on 6 September, aims to amend the National Health Act 1953. It proposes to require the inclusion of Medicare numbers on prescriptions for pharmaceuticals under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Labor have some concerns regarding this bill. We share the AMA's concern about privacy, timing and the financial impact of this bill. This bill will require doctors and other people prescribing pharmaceuticals to put the patient's Medicare number on each prescription. This requirement endeavours to check eligibility for people to obtain pharmaceuticals under the PBS. Benefits under this scheme were first made available to the Australian public in 1948. The scheme provides the community with access to necessary medicines at an affordable price. To access benefits, people must pay the first $20.50 for each prescription item. People who hold a health care card must pay $3.30 per item. Under the scheme there is a safety net to guard against large annual expenses for individuals or families. The scheme allows for a reduction in cost for general consumers when expenditure reaches $631.20 and for cardholders when expenditure reaches $171.60.

speech.para: The proposed changes to this scheme are to be implemented in three stages leading up to July 2001, when the new arrangement will become mandatory. When the changes are fully implemented, the government will not pay the pharmacist unless the patient's Medicare number and expiry date are detailed on the prescription. Not only will the pharmacist be responsible for the collection of this information but, if the number does not match Health Insurance Commission data, they will have to find the customer in order to correct or verify the Medicare number or not get paid by the government.

There is provision in the bill to allow pharmacists and doctors to retain Medicare numbers for future use. The bill requires pharmacists to maintain privacy and to ask permission to keep the Medicare number. This move leaves people vulnerable to breaches of privacy—confidential personal information is at risk. Currently there are two major ways in which people obtain pharmaceutical benefits without being entitled to them. Overseas visitors who are not entitled to benefits access subsidised medication through the scheme. Visitors from countries other than those with whom Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement are not entitled to benefits but are generally assumed to be eligible by pharmacists unless there is a reason to think otherwise. There is no requirement for people who are not on any concession card to produce identification to receive medications.

The other issue of concern about access with the current regime is doctor shopping. As we are all aware, people go to different doctors, get prescriptions for the same drug and get these prescriptions filled at various pharmacists that sell the drugs. This practice is of great concern and costs taxpayers a lot of money. It is estimated by the Health Insurance Commission that in 1998-99 around 8½ thousand people engaged in doctor shopping, with an average cost of $21.68 per prescription. The potential cost to the taxpayer could be enormous. Unfortunately, the measures in this bill will not do much to control doctor shopping as the arrangements are still easy to get around. It will not be necessary to have your Medicare card to obtain medication; you will only have to quote the number and the expiry date. Ineligible people will be able to access pharmaceuticals in the same way as they did before this legislation—for example, people could borrow or steal a card or impersonate somebody they know.

The issue is: what is the government intending to do with Medicare numbers once the new system is in place? Will it compare data to try to curb doctor shopping? If so, how would it then deal with privacy concerns? Privacy is very important, and there are too many unanswered questions within this legislation. It also forms our most pressing objection to the bill. What the government proposes is to effectively use the Medicare number as the unique patient identifier without first putting in place the critically important privacy regime. It is possible that this step could lead to further expansion of the power to record and store Medicare numbers. Without the appropriate privacy measures this is a dangerous prospect.

This bill makes it possible for major breaches of confidentiality to occur, and we all know how personal and private the information is relating to one's medical records. To introduce changes that make this information vulnerable is an absolute breach of the trust that Australians place in the government to protect their civil liberties. While the proposed legislation is a small step down that road, there are examples in other countries where this sort of access to information, no matter what the safeguard, is used in a very negative way. Dr Kerryn Phelps, the federal President of the AMA, gave this example to the Health Online summit in August this year:

quote.para: Consumers ... increasingly understand that access to data on their individual health history, its current status and, with advances in genetic research, its potential status, may provide means to: exploit, stigmatise, discriminate and disadvantage an individual in every single aspect of their lives—employment, finances, insurance, housing, education, access to a range of private and public services and travel. A recent survey showed that more than a third of all Fortune 500 companies check medical records before they hire or promote and 10 per cent did not inform employees of this practice.
Over 200 instances of loss of employment, insurance cover or benefits, as a result of access to personal genetic information have been documented in the United States.

speech.para: The bill forms a part of the government's plan called Better Medication Management System. Further legislation has been foreshadowed by the government to implement other aspects of this plan. The government says that the privacy measures will be dealt with at that stage. That is just not good enough. To say that it will deal with such an important consideration at a later date is simply too late. The government, in introducing this bill without adequate consideration for privacy, is already putting people's confidential medical information at risk. The government should ensure the safety of the program before introduction, not just hope for the best.

The introduction of this bill and its implications in relation to the Better Medication Management System is of great concern to the Australian Medical Association, and they have detailed their concerns in a position paper in which they say:

quote.para: The fact that under the Act the supplier/dispenser and the prescriber would be authorised to record and hold the Medicare number means that without doubt, the Medicare number would become a part of the Better Medication Management System record, where a patient has consented to the number being recorded and held.

speech.para: The AMA went on to say:

quote.para: Importantly, passage of this Bill would pave the way for the Better Medication Management System to legitimately include the Medicare number in operation of the Better Medication Management System by prescribers and suppliers. That the Bill gives the authority for prescribers to record and hold the numbers ensures that a field could be included to insert the Medicare number. While at this stage it appears that, under the Act, consent will be required to record and hold the Medicare number, consent to participate in the Better Medication Management System would undoubtedly incorporate a general consent to the requirements of the Better Medication Management System which would include consent to record the Medicare number if the field exists. It is unlikely that a separate consent would be established and we have already seen resistance when different levels of consent to specific areas of the Better Medication Management System have been raised.

speech.para: Their report concluded:

quote.para: The fact is that if a person consents to the recording and holding of their Medicare number in relation to a Pharmaceutical Benefits item, that Medicare number will be recorded for each and every prescription Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme or not. Should the Better Medication Management System incorporate the Medicare number, for which this legislation would provide the means and authority, the Better Medication Management System also becomes an entitlement monitoring system as well as linked to a vast array of data that is not relevant to that purpose.

speech.para: The timing of the introduction of this bill is unrealistic and ill-prepared. The three-phase introduction by July 2001 is thought by pharmacists' and doctors' groups to be rushed and unrealistic.

The first stage will focus on encouraging people to give their Medicare numbers, and pharmacists being authorised, but not required, to collect Medicare numbers. At stage 2, pharmacists will be required to put Medicare numbers on all prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. They are authorised to ask for the number and prohibited from supplying the medication unless they are satisfied that the patient is entitled to the medication. The final stage requires that Medicare numbers and expiry dates are detailed on all prescriptions or pharmacists will not be paid for the prescriptions.

The second concern in relation to the timetabling of this issue is the lack of preparation and appropriate debate about privacy legislation. As I said earlier, there is much public concern about privacy and medical records. A Roy Morgan survey in July this year found that 66 per cent of consumers would not consider their records safe if maintained and safeguarded by the government. This is an appalling statistic, revealing how little faith the Australian public have in the Howard government's regard for their privacy. We have seen example after example of systems failing to protect people's privacy, and Australians quite rightly do not trust the government to get it right this time. In light of these concerns, one would imagine that the government would go to great lengths to ensure that the privacy legislation in relation to this bill was thorough and well prepared, that extensive debate had occurred and consultation with consumers was far reaching and that expert groups had been fully listened to and their opinions taken into account. Instead, what has been the response from the government on the fundamental issue of privacy? `Oh, we'll worry about that later.'

Prue Power, the Director of General Practice of the AMA, talked about some of their issues with regard to the government's approach to privacy in her introductory statement to the Senate Select Committee on Information Technologies. She said:

quote.para: To say that there is a lot of work to do in the area of public confidence in relation to privacy and electronic health record systems is clearly an understatement. It is in this context, for example, that we continually question the government's timetable for the Better Medication Management System that has parallel legislation drafting and a consultation phase of just two months.

speech.para: Ms Power went on to say:

quote.para: The fact is that getting highly sensitive issues like privacy right takes time and not only involves the complex areas of consent and access to technological factors, including technical security. There is also another important point here: implementation timetables also have to address the pace of technology take-up in the health sector, particularly at the GP level. GPs, in particular, I believe, are eager to realise the as yet unimaginable benefits of e-health systems. The capacity to share patient care information with other medical practitioners and the benefits to patient health outcomes are eagerly anticipated. A rigorous privacy framework with consent as central and reliable technical standards, including security, can protect the ethical requirements of the profession.

... the AMA's view is that it should not support electronic health information system initiatives which do not place privacy as central to the operation of the system. We are concerned at the piecemeal approach to privacy legislation and the numerous smaller initiatives that are being developed in isolation from one another, particularly in isolation from the larger HealthConnect proposal. Arguments that these initiatives stand alone are simply not true. They will ultimately be an integral component of the broader HealthConnect and in our view must be subject to the same stringent establishment of the essential building blocks, with privacy as a highest priority.

speech.para: I am very sceptical about the so-called cost savings predicted by the government in relation to this bill. Pharmacists will incur extra costs in the collection and recording of Medicare numbers and will also be responsible for chasing customers whose information was incorrectly supplied. Walk into any pharmacy in my electorate of Bass and it is abundantly clear that pharmacists are not people with an abundance of time on their hands. Undoubtedly, pharmacists will have to absorb the cost for these incorrect details, as it is completely impractical to suggest that they will be able to track people down who have supplied their details incorrectly.

The predictions that the government has made about the potential cost savings of this bill are based on some very shaky figures. Firstly, the savings are predicted to come through people failing to obtain pharmaceuticals through the entitlement scheme which they are not eligible for. The problem with these estimates is that we are unable to know how much of this ineligible claiming occurs. It is therefore extremely difficult to predict with any measure of accuracy what the savings may be. Secondly, the predictions that were made in the 2000 budget of savings of $18 million did not take into account that pharmacists will need to be reimbursed for the extra time and costs associated with the legislation. This cost is likely to cancel out any savings gained.

We are very encouraged by the opportunities that new technologies present for health services in Australia. We want to ensure that Australia is in a position to grab these advantages with both hands when they become available, but not at the expense of people's privacy. By ensuring that the appropriate legislation is in place before technological change is introduced, we can ensure that the Australian public gains maximum benefits from technological advances with no compromise on privacy. The ALP will ensure that data is not used inappropriately and that commercial interests do not interfere with intended health outcomes. Some of the ways that we would encourage the medical profession to embrace new technologies are through the use of tele health, to give doctors and nurses access to higher quality resources or consultations, access to up-to-the-minute information through the use of intranets, and electronic prescriptions to make communication between doctors and pharmacists more efficient and clear. The key to the uptake of the new technology is the appropriate training, and we must ensure that this is readily accessible so that health professionals are able to get maximum benefit for themselves and their patients. We believe that managing health information electronically is crucial to improving the quality and safety of health services. However, this can only be done when a rigorous system of privacy protection is in place. The ALP would intend to instigate a full public inquiry into this issue and, after listening to what Australians have to say, would develop a strong privacy regime built around a unique patient identifier based on the Medicare card. We would ensure that legislation is in place that prevents this information from being used for any other purpose. Full consent from patient and doctor would be required for any access.

We strongly support people's right to information about their health care. We recognise that many Australians do not feel that they have the information they need to make informed choices about their health. We acknowledge people's right to be thoroughly informed about their conditions, treatment options and risks, costs of treatment and health record. We believe that if people have access to this kind of information they will participate more fully in the management of their own health. Only by paying close attention to this kind of legislation can we ensure that Australians have the health systems and the levels of privacy that they require and that they deserve. People must have complete trust in their general practitioner. To ensure that people are able to access the health services that they need with confidence, we as legislators must ensure that the systems are in place to protect people's privacy so that that trust is never at risk of being betrayed. We have an obligation to the Australian public to provide high quality, safe and confidential health services.

talk.start.para: —The basic aim of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is to assist patients to receive high quality health care through quality use of medicines, to subsidise the costs of prescribed pharmaceuticals and to provide appropriate accountability for expenditure of public funds. That last part of the sentence about expenditure of public funds leads me to say that the aim of this National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 is, by and large, to ensure that only those persons entitled to receive pharmaceutical benefits under the National Health Act actually receive them. I understand the value of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme in the last 12 months was $3.1 billion, and under this bill there is an estimated saving to the taxpayers of Australia of about $20 million per annum, once it gets up and going. I should declare my interest in this, being a pharmacist myself. I would not be surprised if the savings were actually greater than $20 million per annum.

speech.para: One of the things that strike me in my job as a pharmacist is that, because we have had the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and Medicare in place for so long, people in Australia really have no perception of the value of the medication they are getting. It would not be unusual at all for a patient to be on a lipid lowering drug, an ulcer drug and a blood pressure medication, for example, and if they were on a pension they could pay of the order of $10 a month and receive drugs to the value of about $200 a month. Because of the centralised system we have been able to have in Australia because of our small population, compared with the US for example, we have been able to put the squeeze on the drug companies. I think government from both sides of the parliament has done that quite successfully in the past. But the fact that we have been able to do that and the fact that we have had the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme in for so long means that people have very little perception of the value of their drugs. This is one of the prime reasons why we have the problems that have necessitated our introduction of legislation like this. Anecdotes indicate that people from overseas often have a greater understanding of the savings or the cheap price of drugs under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme than do Australians themselves.

There are several reasons why we need to have this legislation. We have Australian citizens sending overseas, to family or for commercial gain, medicines obtained under the PBS. We have overseas visitors in Australia who are not entitled to receive drugs under the PBS obtaining these drugs. Another reason which is not insignificant is the hoarding that takes place within our own community. Again, I do not think people have a real perception of the value of the drugs that they have. In my previous role it would be not unusual at all, where someone unfortunately has passed away, for the relatives to bring into the pharmacy a garbage bag full of drugs that are out of date. It would be nothing to have $500, $600 or $700 worth of drugs that people have just shoved into their cupboard with no perception of the value and the cost to the taxpayer.

There are three stages of implementation of this bill. The first stage allows Medicare numbers to be collected and placed on the prescription. Stage two requires Medicare numbers to be collected by the pharmacy and placed on prescriptions, for the purpose of determining entitlement to the pharmaceutical benefits. This is planned to start from 1 January. Stage three actually prevents payments to pharmacists for dispensing prescriptions for pharmaceutical benefits where the entitlement has not been established properly. On this point I agree with some of the previous speakers, in that I really cannot see that this is going to be achieved by 1 July 2001. Hence I commend the minister for proposing amendments that will give him the ability to put off this date of 1 July.

One of the things that the minister or the department and the Pharmacy Guild are talking about at the moment is to provide the pharmacy with an electronic swipe so that they would be able to swipe the Medicare number, to take away the need to write the number on the script. To me, an obvious thing in developing this technology would be for the same thing to be done for the pension card. As it is at the moment, when a person walks into the pharmacy they have to produce their pension card, and it takes some little time to write that number on. If that could also be swiped by the same swipe machine, that would make up for some of the time that is taken with this new demand put on the pharmacist's time. I would implore anyone not to underestimate the time taken to do this. It is not just a simple matter of a swipe card, especially in the early implementation stage. You will find that pharmacists and pharmacy staff will spend probably five minutes a patient explaining why they have to do this. The first reply will be, `But I didn't have to provide a Medicare card last time I was in here.' Staff will say, `That is new legislation.' The response will be, `But the pharmacy down the road doesn't make me do that.' So there is a certain length of time that is involved in implementing this system. Whenever there is a major change, those on the front line spend quite a lot of time implementing, on behalf of the government, these changes.

Again, I would commend the minister for having a very constructive dialogue with the Pharmacy Guild. I understand, having spoken to the guild, that the government is very much aware of the guild's position on this. Part of the negotiations with the guild, I understand, have led to the ability of the guild to be involved in the education process of consumers, doctors and pharmacists. That will perhaps take away some of the angst that is caused at the coalface by implementation of rules such as these.

The minister, as I said, by instrument, can make alternative arrangements, or the pharmacy can make alternative arrangements in the situation where a person comes into the pharmacy without their Medicare card—for example, indigenous persons who live in remote areas, minors who live on the streets, patients in emergency circumstances, and perhaps persons covered by reciprocal health care agreements. I understand that pharmacies will be issued with a series of `dummy numbers', which will be able to be keyed into the computers to allow the prescriptions to be dispensed. There will be a close monitoring of the use of these dummy numbers, which I think is fair enough. Despite the clear professionalism of the group of people to whom we are referring, as in any group of people there are probably some who will take advantage and not bother to go through the process of educating their patients to bring their Medicare cards in and who will perhaps overuse these numbers. The monitoring of the use of these numbers is quite fair enough. One issue that is slightly disturbing to me is one I noticed in some of the briefing notes. It probably comes back to a bit of a lack of understanding by some of the departmental people in negotiating this with the government and the Pharmacy Guild. There was talk about dispensers facing additional time costs in obtaining Medicare numbers. The briefing notes say:

quote.para: Since dispensing and claiming of payment are handled by pharmacy software, there should be little or no impact on time costs in these areas.

speech.para: I have already addressed this, and I think it needs to be very clear that, despite the claiming of payment being handled by software, there certainly will be an impact on the time taken to do this, especially in the initial stages. Another thing that caused me a little bit of angst was the comment:

quote.para: ... there will be arrangements in place to enable eligible people who cannot provide a Medicare number to access benefits, there will be no adverse health impact for these consumers.

speech.para: The briefing note goes on to say:

quote.para: Consumers will be able to access better help from the HIC in obtaining PBS prescription histories in order to assist them to develop the necessary documentation for accessing the PBS safety net.

speech.para: On the ground, this simply does not happen. The primary person whose role it is and who the patients go to for assistance to develop the necessary documentation for accessing their PBS safety net is the pharmacist. People who are designing the fine bits of this legislation need to sit down and speak with people who are actually working on the ground, so that the true benefits and the true costs are really assessed.

Of course, dispensers are restricted by confidentiality. I understand some of the concerns expressed by speakers opposite, but the way I understand it is that there are basically going to be three columns of information. We have the Health Insurance Commission records of visits to the doctor, so they have their Medicare history. They will have, in a completely separate database, access to the figures which will be provided by the pharmacy. And, when and if the time comes, with the patient's consent, there will be medical records which will be obtainable as well. My understanding is that at no stage can the government or the Health Insurance Commission access those three different, completely independent lists of information except in some cases where there is a suspicion of doctor-shopping, when some of the information, I understand, with the permission of the Privacy Commissioner, is able to be used.

In short, I think saving $20 million is a good thing, and the government should be commended for that. The department, I understand, is liaising very effectively with the Pharmacy Guild. I have had very good comments back from representatives of the Pharmacy Guild saying that the representatives of the department have been very proactive and very understanding in listening to their concerns. That also is good. The minister has the ability to delay stage 3, which is absolutely essential. I would put my house on it that we will not be ready for this to go by 1 July, but the fact that the minister has had the foresight to put in that amendment is terrific. I have some concerns about whether the department has sufficient knowledge of on-the-ground impacts, but overall the bill is extremely worthy. I am very happy to support it and, as I mentioned earlier, I would not be surprised if the savings to the taxpayer were quite a bit in excess of $20 million, which I believe to be a somewhat conservative figure.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr WOOLDRIDGE
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank honourable members for their contribution to this debate on the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000. When introducing the bill, I emphasised that the legislation is to help the government ensure that pharmaceutical benefits are being directed to people eligible to receive them. The bill will require the inclusion of Medicare numbers on claim forms for pharmaceutical benefits. The legislation ensures that pharmaceutical benefits system medicines continue to be provided to those who are eligible, while strengthening our capacity to deny access to those who are ineligible. It is estimated that over $20 million a year is spent providing PBS medicines to patients who are not eligible.

speech.para: The new arrangements will be introduced in stages. The first stage will commence with a communication campaign to ensure consumers are made aware of the new arrangements. It will also allow, but does not require, pharmacists and doctors to collect and retain Medicare numbers with consent. During the second stage, from 1 January 2001, consumers will be encouraged to present their Medicare cards as a normal part of having a prescription dispensed. In this phase the pharmacist is required to ask all consumers for their Medicare number. However, if a person does not provide their Medicare number there is no financial consequence for either the consumer or the pharmacist. This is a phase-in period during which the education campaign will continue to assist consumers, pharmacists and doctors. After full implementation, from 1 July 2001 or such later date as is prescribed, there will be no government payment to the pharmacist for prescriptions without a Medicare number unless one of the specified circumstances applies. This will mean that pharmacists will need to be sure of a patient's PBS eligibility before the supply of the medicine.

Special numbers have been developed to ensure access for members of particular groups who are eligible for the PBS but may not be able to provide Medicare numbers: for example, some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who do not use Medicare cards to access services. Special numbers would also be used to provide subsidised medications in emergencies. The bill also allows the minister to determine circumstances where the pharmacist will be paid for the legitimate supply of pharmaceuticals, even though the Medicare number on the claim does not match the Medicare number on HIC records. This is to ensure that a pharmacist, who in good faith complies in all respects with the legislation, is not financially disadvantaged through a mismatching with HIC records.

The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 extends protection under the National Health Act to cover all aspects of the use of the Medicare number and other identifying data for the purposes of pharmaceutical benefits entitlement monitoring. The Privacy Commission has issued guidelines under section 135AA of the National Health Act for required data and medical claims information and pharmaceutical claims information to be kept separate by the HIC. Adherence to this guideline is well established by the Health Insurance Commission. This bill inserts proposed section 135AA(11) into the act in such a way that these Privacy Commissioner guidelines apply to the Medicare numbers that will be stored with other PBS claims data as a consequence of the bill. Further, Medicare numbers obtained under the bill are only able to be used for PBS purposes as set out in proposed section 135AAA(2)(c).

In response to concerns raised by the member for Jagajaga, I want to make it clear that, in taking a decision on this bill, one is not taking a decision on other government initiatives that may arise. This does not in any way lock Australia into a particular outcome on the use of a universal patient identifier. There is a long way to go on this important issue and the relative merits of other proposals can be debated when the legislation for these proposals is brought forward. On the issue of time frame and the concerns that our community will not be ready, the amendments to this legislation will enable me, as the minister, to delay implementation should it be determined that 1 July 2001 is not appropriate. The bill ensures that PBS medicines continue to be provided to those who are eligible while strengthening our capacity to deny access to those who are ineligible. This bill preserves and strengthens the PBS and the benefits it provides for the Australian community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
